    38	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 1
    39	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    40	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    41	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession
    42	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.
    43	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    44	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHowever little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his
    45	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds
    46	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property
    47	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof some one or other of their daughters.
    48	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    49	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that
    50	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield Park is let at last?”
    51	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    52	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet replied that he had not.
    53	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    54	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she
    55	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttold me all about it.”
    56	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    57	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet made no answer.
    58	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    59	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you not want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife impatiently.
    60	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    61	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.”
    62	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    63	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was invitation enough.
    64	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    65	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken
    66	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came
    67	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdown on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much
    68	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelighted with it, that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he
    69	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to
    70	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe in the house by the end of next week.”
    71	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    72	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is his name?”
    73	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    74	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Bingley.”
    75	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    76	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is he married or single?”
    77	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    78	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! Single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or
    79	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfive thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!”
    80	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    81	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How so? How can it affect them?”
    82	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    83	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Mr. Bennet,” replied his wife, “how can you be so tiresome! You
    84	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.”
    85	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    86	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is that his design in settling here?”
    87	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    88	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Design! Nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he
    89	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as
    90	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as he comes.”
    91	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    92	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send
    93	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are
    94	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley may like you the best of the
    95	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty.”
    96	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
    97	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but
    98	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five
    99	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty.”
   100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.”
   102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into
   104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe neighbourhood.”
   105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is more than I engage for, I assure you.”
   107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would
   109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to
   110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgo, merely on that account, for in general, you know, they visit no
   111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnewcomers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to
   112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit him if you do not.”
   113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are over-scrupulous, surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very
   115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my
   116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls; though
   117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.”
   118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the
   120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so
   121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving _her_ the preference.”
   122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They have none of them much to recommend them,” replied he; “they are
   124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of
   125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquickness than her sisters.”
   126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Bennet, how _can_ you abuse your own children in such a way? You
   128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake delight in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves.”
   129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They
   131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration
   132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese last twenty years at least.”
   133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Ah, you do not know what I suffer.”
   135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four
   137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand a year come into the neighbourhood.”
   138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not
   140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit them.”
   141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them
   143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall.”
   144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour,
   146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had
   147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen insufficient to make his wife understand his character. _Her_ mind
   148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas less difficult to develop. She was a woman of mean understanding,
   149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented,
   150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her
   151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters married; its solace was visiting and news.
   152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 2
   156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley. He
   159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring
   160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was
   161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpaid she had no knowledge of it. It was then disclosed in the following
   162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner. Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he
   163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuddenly addressed her with:
   164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy.”
   166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes,” said her mother
   168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresentfully, “since we are not to visit.”
   169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you forget, mamma,” said Elizabeth, “that we shall meet him at the
   171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassemblies, and that Mrs. Long promised to introduce him.”
   172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces
   174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion
   175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her.”
   176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do
   178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot depend on her serving you.”
   179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply, but, unable to contain
   181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself, began scolding one of her daughters.
   182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Don’t keep coughing so, Kitty, for Heaven’s sake! Have a little
   184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces.”
   185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,” said her father; “she times
   187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem ill.”
   188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not cough for my own amusement,” replied Kitty fretfully. “When is
   190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour next ball to be, Lizzy?”
   191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To-morrow fortnight.”
   193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye, so it is,” cried her mother, “and Mrs. Long does not come back
   195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill the day before; so it will be impossible for her to introduce him,
   196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor she will not know him herself.”
   197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce
   199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley to _her_.”
   200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him
   202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself; how can you be so teasing?”
   203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I honour your circumspection. A fortnight’s acquaintance is certainly
   205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a
   206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortnight. But if _we_ do not venture somebody else will; and after all,
   207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Long and her neices must stand their chance; and, therefore, as
   208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will
   209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake it on myself.”
   210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense,
   212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnonsense!”
   213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?” cried he. “Do
   215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on
   216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you _there_. What say you,
   217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary? For you are a young lady of deep reflection, I know, and read
   218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat books and make extracts.”
   219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary wished to say something sensible, but knew not how.
   221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“While Mary is adjusting her ideas,” he continued, “let us return to Mr.
   223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley.”
   224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sick of Mr. Bingley,” cried his wife.
   226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did not you tell me that before? If
   228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI had known as much this morning I certainly would not have called
   229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we
   230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot escape the acquaintance now.”
   231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished; that of Mrs.
   233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though, when the first tumult of joy
   234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the
   235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile.
   236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should
   238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpersuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to
   239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! and it is such a
   240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood joke, too, that you should have gone this morning and never said a
   241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tword about it till now.”
   242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you choose,” said Mr. Bennet; and,
   244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.
   245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What an excellent father you have, girls!” said she, when the door was
   247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshut. “I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;
   248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor me, either, for that matter. At our time of life it is not so
   249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasant, I can tell you, to be making new acquaintances every day; but
   250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor your sakes, we would do anything. Lydia, my love, though you _are_
   251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next
   252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tball.”
   253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh!” said Lydia stoutly, “I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the
   255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoungest, I’m the tallest.”
   256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon he would
   258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturn Mr. Bennet’s visit, and determining when they should ask him to
   259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdinner.
   260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 3
   264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNot all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five
   267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters, could ask on the subject, was sufficient to draw from her
   268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thusband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley. They attacked him
   269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin various ways--with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and
   270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all, and they were at
   271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour,
   272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Lucas. Her report was highly favourable. Sir William had been
   273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelighted with him. He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely
   274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable, and, to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly
   275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a large party. Nothing could be more delightful! To be fond of
   276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively
   277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thopes of Mr. Bingley’s heart were entertained.
   278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,”
   280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, “and all the others equally well
   281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarried, I shall have nothing to wish for.”
   282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn a few days Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet’s visit, and sat about
   284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten minutes with him in his library. He had entertained hopes of being
   285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmitted to a sight of the young ladies, of whose beauty he had
   286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard much; but he saw only the father. The ladies were somewhat more
   287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortunate, for they had the advantage of ascertaining from an upper
   288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twindow that he wore a blue coat, and rode a black horse.
   289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAn invitation to dinner was soon afterwards dispatched; and already
   291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad Mrs. Bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to her
   292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thousekeeping, when an answer arrived which deferred it all. Mr. Bingley
   293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas obliged to be in town the following day, and, consequently, unable
   294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto accept the honour of their invitation, etc. Mrs. Bennet was quite
   295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisconcerted. She could not imagine what business he could have in town
   296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that
   297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the might be always flying about from one place to another, and never
   298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettled at Netherfield as he ought to be. Lady Lucas quieted her fears
   299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta little by starting the idea of his being gone to London only to get
   300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta large party for the ball; and a report soon followed that Mr. Bingley
   301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas to bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen with him to the assembly.
   302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe girls grieved over such a number of ladies, but were comforted the
   303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday before the ball by hearing, that instead of twelve he brought only
   304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsix with him from London--his five sisters and a cousin. And when
   305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe party entered the assembly room it consisted of only five
   306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taltogether--Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and
   307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanother young man.
   308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley was good-looking and gentlemanlike; he had a pleasant
   310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountenance, and easy, unaffected manners. His sisters were fine women,
   311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith an air of decided fashion. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely
   312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention
   313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien, and
   314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe report which was in general circulation within five minutes
   315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year. The gentlemen
   316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he
   317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great
   318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust
   319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be
   320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproud; to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all
   321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this large estate in Derbyshire could then save him from having a most
   322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforbidding, disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared
   323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith his friend.
   324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal
   326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeople in the room; he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance,
   327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving
   328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone himself at Netherfield. Such amiable qualities must speak for
   329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthemselves. What a contrast between him and his friend! Mr. Darcy danced
   330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, declined being
   331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the evening in
   332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalking about the room, speaking occasionally to one of his own party.
   333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis character was decided. He was the proudest, most disagreeable man
   334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the world, and everybody hoped that he would never come there again.
   335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAmongst the most violent against him was Mrs. Bennet, whose dislike of
   336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by his
   337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving slighted one of her daughters.
   338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit
   340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdown for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been
   341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstanding near enough for her to hear a conversation between him and Mr.
   342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes, to press his friend
   343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto join it.
   344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Come, Darcy,” said he, “I must have you dance. I hate to see you
   346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstanding about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better
   347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdance.”
   348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am
   350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this
   351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not
   352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanother woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to
   353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstand up with.”
   354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I would not be so fastidious as you are,” cried Mr. Bingley, “for a
   356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in
   357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy life as I have this evening; and there are several of them you see
   358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncommonly pretty.”
   359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,” said Mr.
   361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.
   362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! She is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one
   364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I
   365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdare say very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.”
   366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Which do you mean?” and turning round he looked for a moment at
   368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, till catching her eye, he withdrew his own and coldly said:
   369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; I am in no
   370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted
   371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby other men. You had better return to your partner and enjoy her
   372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiles, for you are wasting your time with me.”
   373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley followed his advice. Mr. Darcy walked off; and Elizabeth
   375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremained with no very cordial feelings toward him. She told the story,
   376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, with great spirit among her friends; for she had a lively,
   377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplayful disposition, which delighted in anything ridiculous.
   378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family. Mrs.
   380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield
   381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she had been
   382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistinguished by his sisters. Jane was as much gratified by this as
   383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther mother could be, though in a quieter way. Elizabeth felt Jane’s
   384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure. Mary had heard herself mentioned to Miss Bingley as the most
   385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccomplished girl in the neighbourhood; and Catherine and Lydia had been
   386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortunate enough never to be without partners, which was all that they
   387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad yet learnt to care for at a ball. They returned, therefore, in good
   388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits to Longbourn, the village where they lived, and of which they
   389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere the principal inhabitants. They found Mr. Bennet still up. With
   390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta book he was regardless of time; and on the present occasion he had a
   391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised
   392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch splendid expectations. He had rather hoped that his wife’s views on
   393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe stranger would be disappointed; but he soon found out that he had a
   394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifferent story to hear.
   395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! my dear Mr. Bennet,” as she entered the room, “we have had a most
   397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelightful evening, a most excellent ball. I wish you had been there.
   398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane was so admired, nothing could be like it. Everybody said how well
   399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with
   400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther twice! Only think of _that_, my dear; he actually danced with her
   401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwice! and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second
   402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime. First of all, he asked Miss Lucas. I was so vexed to see him stand
   403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup with her! But, however, he did not admire her at all; indeed, nobody
   404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going
   405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdown the dance. So he inquired who she was, and got introduced, and
   406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tasked her for the two next. Then the two third he danced with Miss King,
   407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane again,
   408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the two sixth with Lizzy, and the _Boulanger_--”
   409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If he had had any compassion for _me_,” cried her husband impatiently,
   411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“he would not have danced half so much! For God’s sake, say no more of
   412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this partners. Oh that he had sprained his ankle in the first dance!”
   413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! my dear, I am quite delighted with him. He is so excessively
   415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thandsome! And his sisters are charming women. I never in my life saw
   416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything more elegant than their dresses. I dare say the lace upon Mrs.
   417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHurst’s gown--”

   419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHere she was interrupted again. Mr. Bennet protested against any
   420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdescription of finery. She was therefore obliged to seek another branch
   421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the subject, and related, with much bitterness of spirit and some
   422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texaggeration, the shocking rudeness of Mr. Darcy.
   423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I can assure you,” she added, “that Lizzy does not lose much by not
   425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuiting _his_ fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at
   426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall worth pleasing. So high and so conceited that there was no enduring
   427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very
   428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my
   429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear, to have given him one of your set-downs. I quite detest the man.”
   430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 4
   434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in
   437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther praise of Mr. Bingley before, expressed to her sister just how very
   438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch she admired him.
   439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is just what a young man ought to be,” said she, “sensible,
   441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!--so much
   442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tease, with such perfect good breeding!”
   443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought
   445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikewise to be, if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.”
   446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I
   448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not expect such a compliment.”
   449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did not you? I did for you. But that is one great difference between
   451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus. Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never. What
   452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help
   453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman
   454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is
   455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a
   456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstupider person.”
   457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dear Lizzy!”
   459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! you are a great deal too apt, you know, to like people in general.
   461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYou never see a fault in anybody. All the world are good and agreeable
   462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in your
   463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlife.”
   464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I would not wish to be hasty in censuring anyone; but I always speak
   466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat I think.”
   467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I know you do; and it is _that_ which makes the wonder. With _your_
   469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of
   470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers! Affectation of candour is common enough--one meets with it
   471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverywhere. But to be candid without ostentation or design--to take the
   472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood of everybody’s character and make it still better, and say nothing
   473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the bad--belongs to you alone. And so you like this man’s sisters,
   474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo, do you? Their manners are not equal to his.”
   475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly not--at first. But they are very pleasing women when you
   477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconverse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother, and keep
   478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming
   479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbour in her.”
   480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced; their behaviour at
   482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more
   483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister,
   484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand with a judgement too unassailed by any attention to herself, she
   485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas very little disposed to approve them. They were in fact very fine
   486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies; not deficient in good humour when they were pleased, nor in the
   487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpower of making themselves agreeable when they chose it, but proud and
   488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceited. They were rather handsome, had been educated in one of the
   489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst private seminaries in town, had a fortune of twenty thousand
   490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpounds, were in the habit of spending more than they ought, and of
   491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassociating with people of rank, and were therefore in every respect
   492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentitled to think well of themselves, and meanly of others. They were of
   493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta respectable family in the north of England; a circumstance more deeply
   494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpressed on their memories than that their brother’s fortune and their
   495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town had been acquired by trade.
   496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred
   498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an
   499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testate, but did not live to do it. Mr. Bingley intended it likewise, and
   500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes made choice of his county; but as he was now provided with a
   501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those
   502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the
   503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to
   504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpurchase.
   505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis sisters were anxious for his having an estate of his own; but,
   507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough he was now only established as a tenant, Miss Bingley was by no
   508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeans unwilling to preside at his table--nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had
   509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarried a man of more fashion than fortune, less disposed to consider
   510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this house as her home when it suited her. Mr. Bingley had not been of
   511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tage two years, when he was tempted by an accidental recommendation
   512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto look at Netherfield House. He did look at it, and into it for
   513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf-an-hour--was pleased with the situation and the principal
   514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trooms, satisfied with what the owner said in its praise, and took it
   515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately.
   516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBetween him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of
   518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat opposition of character. Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the
   519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teasiness, openness, and ductility of his temper, though no disposition
   520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he
   521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever appeared dissatisfied. On the strength of Darcy’s regard, Bingley
   522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad the firmest reliance, and of his judgement the highest opinion.
   523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn understanding, Darcy was the superior. Bingley was by no means
   524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeficient, but Darcy was clever. He was at the same time haughty,
   525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treserved, and fastidious, and his manners, though well-bred, were not
   526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinviting. In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage. Bingley
   527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas sure of being liked wherever he appeared, Darcy was continually
   528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgiving offense.
   529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently
   531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacteristic. Bingley had never met with more pleasant people or
   532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprettier girls in his life; everybody had been most kind and attentive
   533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto him; there had been no formality, no stiffness; he had soon felt
   534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquainted with all the room; and, as to Miss Bennet, he could not
   535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceive an angel more beautiful. Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a
   536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcollection of people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for
   537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnone of whom he had felt the smallest interest, and from none received
   538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teither attention or pleasure. Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty,
   539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut she smiled too much.
   540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Hurst and her sister allowed it to be so--but still they admired
   542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther and liked her, and pronounced her to be a sweet girl, and one
   543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhom they would not object to know more of. Miss Bennet was therefore
   544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testablished as a sweet girl, and their brother felt authorized by such
   545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommendation to think of her as he chose.
   546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 5
   550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWithin a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets
   553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere particularly intimate. Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade
   554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin Meryton, where he had made a tolerable fortune, and risen to the
   555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thonour of knighthood by an address to the king during his mayoralty.
   556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe distinction had perhaps been felt too strongly. It had given him a
   557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisgust to his business, and to his residence in a small market town;
   558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, in quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house
   559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge,
   560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere he could think with pleasure of his own importance, and,
   561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunshackled by business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all
   562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe world. For, though elated by his rank, it did not render him
   563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupercilious; on the contrary, he was all attention to everybody. By
   564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnature inoffensive, friendly, and obliging, his presentation at St.
   565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJames’s had made him courteous.
   566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a
   568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvaluable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. The eldest
   569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was
   570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s intimate friend.
   571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThat the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over
   573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly
   574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.
   575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte,” said Mrs. Bennet with civil
   577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tself-command to Miss Lucas. “_You_ were Mr. Bingley’s first choice.”
   578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”
   580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! you mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice. To be
   582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed I rather believe he
   583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something
   584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout Mr. Robinson.”
   585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson; did not
   587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI mention it to you? Mr. Robinson’s asking him how he liked our Meryton
   588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many
   589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpretty women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest? and his
   590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswering immediately to the last question: ‘Oh! the eldest Miss Bennet,
   591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeyond a doubt; there cannot be two opinions on that point.’”
   592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Upon my word! Well, that is very decided indeed--that does seem as
   594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif--but, however, it may all come to nothing, you know.”
   595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_My_ overhearings were more to the purpose than _yours_, Eliza,” said
   597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte. “Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend,
   598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis he?--poor Eliza!--to be only just _tolerable_.”
   599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I beg you would not put it into Lizzy’s head to be vexed by his
   601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\till-treatment, for he is such a disagreeable man, that it would be quite
   602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta misfortune to be liked by him. Mrs. Long told me last night that he
   603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsat close to her for half-an-hour without once opening his lips.”
   604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you quite sure, ma’am?--is not there a little mistake?” said Jane.
   606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I certainly saw Mr. Darcy speaking to her.”
   607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye--because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he
   609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not help answering her; but she said he seemed quite angry at
   610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing spoke to.”
   611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bingley told me,” said Jane, “that he never speaks much,
   613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunless among his intimate acquaintances. With _them_ he is remarkably
   614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable.”
   615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not believe a word of it, my dear. If he had been so very
   617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable, he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can guess how it
   618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas; everybody says that he is eat up with pride, and I dare say he had
   619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had come to
   620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe ball in a hack chaise.”
   621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not mind his not talking to Mrs. Long,” said Miss Lucas, “but I
   623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twish he had danced with Eliza.”
   624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Another time, Lizzy,” said her mother, “I would not dance with _him_,
   626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif I were you.”
   627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I believe, ma’am, I may safely promise you _never_ to dance with him.”
   629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His pride,” said Miss Lucas, “does not offend _me_ so much as pride
   631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so
   632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery fine a young man, with family, fortune, everything in his favour,
   633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a _right_
   634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be proud.”
   635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is very true,” replied Elizabeth, “and I could easily forgive
   637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_his_ pride, if he had not mortified _mine_.”
   638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her
   640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have
   641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human
   642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us
   643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some
   644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different
   645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthings, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may
   646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of
   647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us.”
   648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy,” cried a young Lucas, who came with
   650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this sisters, “I should not care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of
   651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfoxhounds, and drink a bottle of wine a day.”
   652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Then you would drink a great deal more than you ought,” said Mrs.
   654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet; “and if I were to see you at it, I should take away your bottle
   655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdirectly.”
   656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe boy protested that she should not; she continued to declare that she
   658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould, and the argument ended only with the visit.
   659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 6
   663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield. The visit
   666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas soon returned in due form. Miss Bennet’s pleasing manners grew on
   667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe goodwill of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and though the mother was
   668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound to be intolerable, and the younger sisters not worth speaking to,
   669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta wish of being better acquainted with _them_ was expressed towards
   670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe two eldest. By Jane, this attention was received with the greatest
   671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure, but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in their treatment
   672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof everybody, hardly excepting even her sister, and could not like them;
   673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough their kindness to Jane, such as it was, had a value as arising in
   674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall probability from the influence of their brother’s admiration. It
   675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas generally evident whenever they met, that he _did_ admire her and
   676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto _her_ it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference
   677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she had begun to entertain for him from the first, and was in a
   678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway to be very much in love; but she considered with pleasure that it
   679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not likely to be discovered by the world in general, since Jane
   680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunited, with great strength of feeling, a composure of temper and a
   681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuniform cheerfulness of manner which would guard her from the suspicions
   682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the impertinent. She mentioned this to her friend Miss Lucas.
   683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It may perhaps be pleasant,” replied Charlotte, “to be able to impose
   685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be
   686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill
   687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and
   688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in
   689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every
   690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all
   691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_begin_ freely--a slight preference is natural enough; but there are
   692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without
   693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencouragement. In nine cases out of ten a women had better show _more_
   694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he
   695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.”
   696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If I can
   698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton, indeed, not to
   699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscover it too.”
   700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane’s disposition as you do.”
   702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavour to conceal
   704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, he must find it out.”
   705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But, though Bingley and Jane
   707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and, as they
   708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that
   709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should
   710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore make the most of every half-hour in which she can command his
   711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention. When she is secure of him, there will be more leisure for
   712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfalling in love as much as she chooses.”
   713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your plan is a good one,” replied Elizabeth, “where nothing is in
   715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquestion but the desire of being well married, and if I were determined
   716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it. But
   717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese are not Jane’s feelings; she is not acting by design. As yet,
   718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard nor of its
   719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonableness. She has known him only a fortnight. She danced four
   720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house,
   721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand has since dined with him in company four times. This is not quite
   722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to make her understand his character.”
   723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not as you represent it. Had she merely _dined_ with him, she might
   725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must
   726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremember that four evenings have also been spent together--and four
   727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevenings may do a great deal.”
   728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; these four evenings have enabled them to ascertain that they
   730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboth like Vingt-un better than Commerce; but with respect to any other
   731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleading characteristic, I do not imagine that much has been unfolded.”
   732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well,” said Charlotte, “I wish Jane success with all my heart; and
   734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif she were married to him to-morrow, I should think she had as good a
   735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchance of happiness as if she were to be studying his character for a
   736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwelvemonth. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If
   737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other or
   738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever so similar beforehand, it does not advance their felicity in the
   739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleast. They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to
   740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as
   741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your
   742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlife.”
   743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not
   745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.”
   746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOccupied in observing Mr. Bingley’s attentions to her sister, Elizabeth
   748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas far from suspecting that she was herself becoming an object of some
   749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest in the eyes of his friend. Mr. Darcy had at first scarcely
   750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tallowed her to be pretty; he had looked at her without admiration at the
   751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tball; and when they next met, he looked at her only to criticise. But no
   752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsooner had he made it clear to himself and his friends that she hardly
   753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad a good feature in her face, than he began to find it was rendered
   754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. To
   755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying. Though he had
   756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry
   757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her form, he was forced to acknowledge her figure to be light and
   758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasing; and in spite of his asserting that her manners were not those
   759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the fashionable world, he was caught by their easy playfulness. Of
   760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis she was perfectly unaware; to her he was only the man who made
   761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself agreeable nowhere, and who had not thought her handsome enough
   762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto dance with.
   763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe began to wish to know more of her, and as a step towards conversing
   765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith her himself, attended to her conversation with others. His doing so
   766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrew her notice. It was at Sir William Lucas’s, where a large party were
   767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassembled.
   768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What does Mr. Darcy mean,” said she to Charlotte, “by listening to my
   770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation with Colonel Forster?”
   771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.”
   773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But if he does it any more I shall certainly let him know that I see
   775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by
   776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.”
   777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn his approaching them soon afterwards, though without seeming to have
   779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany intention of speaking, Miss Lucas defied her friend to mention such
   780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta subject to him; which immediately provoking Elizabeth to do it, she
   781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturned to him and said:
   782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did you not think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly
   784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell just now, when I was teasing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at
   785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton?”
   786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With great energy; but it is always a subject which makes a lady
   788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenergetic.”
   789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are severe on us.”
   791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It will be _her_ turn soon to be teased,” said Miss Lucas. “I am going
   793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.”
   794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me
   796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto play and sing before anybody and everybody! If my vanity had taken
   797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta musical turn, you would have been invaluable; but as it is, I would
   798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treally rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of
   799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thearing the very best performers.” On Miss Lucas’s persevering, however,
   800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe added, “Very well, if it must be so, it must.” And gravely glancing
   801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Mr. Darcy, “There is a fine old saying, which everybody here is of
   802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcourse familiar with: ‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge’; and I
   803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall keep mine to swell my song.”
   804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer performance was pleasing, though by no means capital. After a song
   806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that
   807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her
   808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in
   809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always
   810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpatient for display.
   811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her
   813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplication, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited
   814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she
   815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had been listened to with
   816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch more pleasure, though not playing half so well; and Mary, at the
   817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tend of a long concerto, was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by
   818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tScotch and Irish airs, at the request of her younger sisters, who,
   819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith some of the Lucases, and two or three officers, joined eagerly in
   820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdancing at one end of the room.
   821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of
   823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpassing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too
   824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch engrossed by his thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was
   825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this neighbour, till Sir William thus began:
   826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There
   828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis nothing like dancing after all. I consider it as one of the first
   829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefinements of polished society.”
   830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst
   832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe less polished societies of the world. Every savage can dance.”
   833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSir William only smiled. “Your friend performs delightfully,” he
   835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt
   836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.”
   837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”
   839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do
   841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou often dance at St. James’s?”
   842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Never, sir.”
   844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”
   846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”
   848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have a house in town, I conclude?”
   850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy bowed.
   852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I had once had some thought of fixing in town myself--for I am fond
   854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of
   855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon would agree with Lady Lucas.”
   856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe paused in hopes of an answer; but his companion was not disposed
   858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was
   859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstruck with the action of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to
   860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther:
   861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow
   863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You
   864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot refuse to dance, I am sure when so much beauty is before you.”
   865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy who, though
   866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly
   867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William:
   868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

   870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.”
   871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of
   873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther hand, but in vain. Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at
   874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.
   875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny
   877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the
   878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us
   879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor one half-hour.”
   880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy is all politeness,” said Elizabeth, smiling.
   882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is, indeed; but, considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza,
   884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe cannot wonder at his complaisance--for who would object to such a
   885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartner?”
   886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth looked archly, and turned away. Her resistance had not
   888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinjured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some
   889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley:
   890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I can guess the subject of your reverie.”
   892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should imagine not.”
   894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
