   896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin this manner--in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion.
   897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI was never more annoyed! The insipidity, and yet the noise--the
   898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothingness, and yet the self-importance of all those people! What would
   899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI give to hear your strictures on them!”
   900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more
   902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure
   903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.”
   904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he
   906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.
   907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy replied with great intrepidity:
   908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Elizabeth Bennet.”
   910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Elizabeth Bennet!” repeated Miss Bingley. “I am all astonishment.
   912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHow long has she been such a favourite?--and pray, when am I to wish you
   913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjoy?”
   914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady’s
   916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love
   917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto matrimony, in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy.”
   918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nay, if you are serious about it, I shall consider the matter is
   920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsolutely settled. You will be having a charming mother-in-law, indeed;
   921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, of course, she will always be at Pemberley with you.”
   922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe listened to her with perfect indifference while she chose to
   924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her
   925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat all was safe, her wit flowed long.
   926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 7
   930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet’s property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two
   933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed,
   934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother’s
   935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply
   936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and
   937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad left her four thousand pounds.
   938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had a sister married to a Mr. Phillips, who had been a clerk to
   940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir father and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in
   941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon in a respectable line of trade.
   942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most
   944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconvenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted
   945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and
   946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto a milliner’s shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family,
   947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions;
   948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir minds were more vacant than their sisters’, and when nothing
   949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning
   950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news
   951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some
   952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with
   953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnews and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the
   954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the
   955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theadquarters.
   956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir visits to Mrs. Phillips were now productive of the most
   958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinteresting intelligence. Every day added something to their knowledge
   959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the officers’ names and connections. Their lodgings were not long a
   960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecret, and at length they began to know the officers themselves. Mr.
   961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPhillips visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a store of
   962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelicity unknown before. They could talk of nothing but officers; and
   963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley’s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation
   964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the
   965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregimentals of an ensign.
   966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr.
   968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet coolly observed:
   969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two
   971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but
   972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI am now convinced.”
   973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine was disconcerted, and made no answer; but Lydia, with perfect
   975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindifference, continued to express her admiration of Captain Carter,
   976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her hope of seeing him in the course of the day, as he was going the
   977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext morning to London.
   978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am astonished, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that you should be so
   980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly
   981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof anybody’s children, it should not be of my own, however.”
   982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If my children are silly, I must hope to be always sensible of it.”
   984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes--but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.”
   986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I
   988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must
   989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly
   990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfoolish.”
   991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
   992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of
   993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir father and mother. When they get to our age, I dare say they will
   994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when
   995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI liked a red coat myself very well--and, indeed, so I do still at my
   996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year,
   997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould want one of my girls I shall not say nay to him; and I thought
   998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William’s in
   999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this regimentals.”
  1000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mamma,” cried Lydia, “my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain
  1002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCarter do not go so often to Miss Watson’s as they did when they first
  1003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcame; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke’s library.”
  1004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with
  1006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited
  1007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor an answer. Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was
  1008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teagerly calling out, while her daughter read,
  1009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well,
  1011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”
  1012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is from Miss Bingley,” said Jane, and then read it aloud.
  1014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR FRIEND,--
  1016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me,
  1018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives,
  1019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor a whole day’s tete-a-tete between two women can never end without a
  1020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquarrel. Come as soon as you can on receipt of this. My brother and the
  1021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen are to dine with the officers.--Yours ever,
  1022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“CAROLINE BINGLEY”
  1024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With the officers!” cried Lydia. “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of
  1026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_that_.”
  1027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dining out,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that is very unlucky.”
  1029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.
  1031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to
  1033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\train; and then you must stay all night.”
  1034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That would be a good scheme,” said Elizabeth, “if you were sure that
  1036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey would not offer to send her home.”
  1037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley’s chaise to go to Meryton,
  1039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the Hursts have no horses to theirs.”
  1040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I had much rather go in the coach.”
  1042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are
  1044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are they not?”
  1045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”
  1047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother’s purpose
  1049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be answered.”
  1050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses
  1052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere engaged. Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her
  1053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a
  1054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbad day. Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before
  1055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit rained hard. Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was
  1056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelighted. The rain continued the whole evening without intermission;
  1057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane certainly could not come back.
  1058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said Mrs. Bennet more than
  1060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonce, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own. Till the
  1061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her
  1062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontrivance. Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield
  1063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrought the following note for Elizabeth:
  1064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAREST LIZZY,--
  1066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be
  1068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will not
  1069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thear of my returning till I am better. They insist also on my seeing Mr.
  1070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJones--therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been
  1071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto me--and, excepting a sore throat and headache, there is not much the
  1072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmatter with me.--Yours, etc.”
  1073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note
  1075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness--if she
  1076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of
  1077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley, and under your orders.”
  1078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! I am not afraid of her dying. People do not die of little trifling
  1080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcolds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays there, it is
  1081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall very well. I would go and see her if I could have the carriage.”
  1082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, feeling really anxious, was determined to go to her, though
  1084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe carriage was not to be had; and as she was no horsewoman, walking
  1085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas her only alternative. She declared her resolution.
  1086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How can you be so silly,” cried her mother, “as to think of such a
  1088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get
  1089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere.”
  1090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want.”
  1092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the
  1094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thorses?”
  1095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, indeed, I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing
  1097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.”
  1098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every
  1100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion,
  1101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”
  1102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We will go as far as Meryton with you,” said Catherine and Lydia.
  1104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off
  1105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether.
  1106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may
  1108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee something of Captain Carter before he goes.”
  1109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn Meryton they parted; the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one
  1111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the officers’ wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing
  1112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfield after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing
  1113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover puddles with impatient activity, and finding herself at last
  1114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithin view of the house, with weary ankles, dirty stockings, and a face
  1115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglowing with the warmth of exercise.
  1116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was shown into the breakfast-parlour, where all but Jane were
  1118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassembled, and where her appearance created a great deal of surprise.
  1119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThat she should have walked three miles so early in the day, in such
  1120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdirty weather, and by herself, was almost incredible to Mrs. Hurst and
  1121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley; and Elizabeth was convinced that they held her in contempt
  1122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor it. She was received, however, very politely by them; and in their
  1123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrother’s manners there was something better than politeness; there
  1124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas good humour and kindness. Mr. Darcy said very little, and Mr.
  1125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHurst nothing at all. The former was divided between admiration of the
  1126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion, and doubt as
  1127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the occasion’s justifying her coming so far alone. The latter was
  1128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthinking only of his breakfast.
  1129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered. Miss
  1131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet had slept ill, and though up, was very feverish, and not
  1132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell enough to leave her room. Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her
  1133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately; and Jane, who had only been withheld by the fear of giving
  1134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talarm or inconvenience from expressing in her note how much she longed
  1135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor such a visit, was delighted at her entrance. She was not equal,
  1136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, to much conversation, and when Miss Bingley left them
  1137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether, could attempt little besides expressions of gratitude for the
  1138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textraordinary kindness she was treated with. Elizabeth silently attended
  1139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther.
  1140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen breakfast was over they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth
  1142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegan to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and
  1143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsolicitude they showed for Jane. The apothecary came, and having
  1144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texamined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught
  1145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it;
  1146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadvised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts. The advice
  1147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head
  1148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tached acutely. Elizabeth did not quit her room for a moment; nor were
  1149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe other ladies often absent; the gentlemen being out, they had, in
  1150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfact, nothing to do elsewhere.
  1151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go, and very
  1153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunwillingly said so. Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only
  1154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern
  1155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin parting with her, that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer
  1156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the chaise to an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present.
  1157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was dispatched to
  1158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn to acquaint the family with her stay and bring back a supply
  1159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof clothes.
  1160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 8
  1164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six
  1167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was summoned to dinner. To the civil inquiries which then
  1168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the
  1169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch superior solicitude of Mr. Bingley’s, she could not make a very
  1170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourable answer. Jane was by no means better. The sisters, on hearing
  1171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how
  1172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked
  1173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their
  1174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindifference towards Jane when not immediately before them restored
  1175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth to the enjoyment of all her former dislike.
  1176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could
  1178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard with any complacency. His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his
  1179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattentions to herself most pleasing, and they prevented her feeling
  1180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the
  1181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers. She had very little notice from any but him. Miss Bingley was
  1182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr.
  1183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to
  1184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teat, drink, and play at cards; who, when he found her to prefer a plain
  1185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.
  1186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley
  1188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegan abusing her as soon as she was out of the room. Her manners were
  1189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpronounced to be very bad indeed, a mixture of pride and impertinence;
  1190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had no conversation, no style, no beauty. Mrs. Hurst thought the
  1191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsame, and added:
  1192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent
  1194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really
  1195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooked almost wild.”
  1196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She did, indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very
  1198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnonsensical to come at all! Why must _she_ be scampering about the
  1199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountry, because her sister had a cold? Her hair, so untidy, so blowsy!”
  1200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep
  1202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin mud, I am absolutely certain; and the gown which had been let down to
  1203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thide it not doing its office.”
  1204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,” said Bingley; “but this was
  1206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably
  1207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat quite
  1208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tescaped my notice.”
  1209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley; “and I am
  1211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinclined to think that you would not wish to see _your_ sister make such
  1212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan exhibition.”
  1213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly not.”
  1215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is,
  1217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabove her ankles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! What could she mean by
  1218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit? It seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence,
  1219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta most country-town indifference to decorum.”
  1220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,” said
  1222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley.
  1223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am afraid, Mr. Darcy,” observed Miss Bingley in a half whisper, “that
  1225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine eyes.”
  1226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not at all,” he replied; “they were brightened by the exercise.” A
  1228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshort pause followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again:
  1229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have an excessive regard for Miss Jane Bennet, she is really a very
  1231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsweet girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with
  1232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is
  1233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno chance of it.”
  1234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I think I have heard you say that their uncle is an attorney in
  1236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton.”
  1237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.”
  1239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is capital,” added her sister, and they both laughed heartily.
  1241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If they had uncles enough to fill _all_ Cheapside,” cried Bingley, “it
  1243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould not make them one jot less agreeable.”
  1244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any
  1246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsideration in the world,” replied Darcy.
  1247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their
  1249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of
  1250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir dear friend’s vulgar relations.
  1251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith a renewal of tenderness, however, they returned to her room on
  1253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee.
  1254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was still very poorly, and Elizabeth would not quit her at all, till
  1255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlate in the evening, when she had the comfort of seeing her sleep, and
  1256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen it seemed to her rather right than pleasant that she should go
  1257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdownstairs herself. On entering the drawing-room she found the whole
  1258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty at loo, and was immediately invited to join them; but suspecting
  1259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem to be playing high she declined it, and making her sister the
  1260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcuse, said she would amuse herself for the short time she could stay
  1261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelow, with a book. Mr. Hurst looked at her with astonishment.
  1262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you prefer reading to cards?” said he; “that is rather singular.”
  1264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, “despises cards. She is a great
  1266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treader, and has no pleasure in anything else.”
  1267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,” cried Elizabeth; “I am
  1269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.”
  1270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and
  1272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI hope it will be soon increased by seeing her quite well.”
  1273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards the
  1275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttable where a few books were lying. He immediately offered to fetch her
  1276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers--all that his library afforded.
  1277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own
  1279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcredit; but I am an idle fellow, and though I have not many, I have more
  1280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan I ever looked into.”
  1281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth assured him that she could suit herself perfectly with those
  1283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the room.
  1284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am astonished,” said Miss Bingley, “that my father should have left
  1286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso small a collection of books. What a delightful library you have at
  1287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley, Mr. Darcy!”
  1288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It ought to be good,” he replied, “it has been the work of many
  1290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenerations.”
  1291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And then you have added so much to it yourself, you are always buying
  1293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbooks.”
  1294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as
  1296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese.”
  1297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of
  1299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat noble place. Charles, when you build _your_ house, I wish it may be
  1300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf as delightful as Pemberley.”
  1301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I wish it may.”
  1303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that
  1305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a
  1306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfiner county in England than Derbyshire.”
  1307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With all my heart; I will buy Pemberley itself if Darcy will sell it.”
  1309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am talking of possibilities, Charles.”
  1311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get
  1313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley by purchase than by imitation.”
  1314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was so much caught with what passed, as to leave her very
  1316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle attention for her book; and soon laying it wholly aside, she drew
  1317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnear the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his
  1318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teldest sister, to observe the game.
  1319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley; “will
  1321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe be as tall as I am?”
  1322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s height, or
  1324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trather taller.”
  1325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me
  1327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso much. Such a countenance, such manners! And so extremely accomplished
  1328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”
  1329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience
  1331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be so very accomplished as they all are.”
  1332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?”
  1334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and
  1336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnet purses. I scarcely know anyone who cannot do all this, and I am sure
  1337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being
  1338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinformed that she was very accomplished.”
  1339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has
  1341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no
  1342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\totherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen. But I am very
  1343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfar from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I
  1344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen, in the whole range of my
  1345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance, that are really accomplished.”
  1346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
  1348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your
  1350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidea of an accomplished woman.”
  1351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, I do comprehend a great deal in it.”
  1353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! certainly,” cried his faithful assistant, “no one can be really
  1355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testeemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met
  1356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing,
  1357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and besides
  1358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of
  1359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word
  1360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be but half-deserved.”
  1361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“All this she must possess,” added Darcy, “and to all this she must
  1363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyet add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by
  1364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textensive reading.”
  1365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.
  1367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI rather wonder now at your knowing _any_.”
  1368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all
  1370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis?”
  1371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never saw such a woman. I never saw such capacity, and taste, and
  1373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplication, and elegance, as you describe united.”
  1374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her
  1376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timplied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who
  1377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with
  1378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward. As all
  1379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the
  1380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troom.
  1381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Elizabeth Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her,
  1383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the
  1384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I dare say, it
  1385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsucceeds. But, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
  1386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed,
  1388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“there is a meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend
  1389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is
  1390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdespicable.”
  1391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to
  1393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinue the subject.
  1394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and
  1396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she could not leave her. Bingley urged Mr. Jones being sent for
  1397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could
  1398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most
  1399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teminent physicians. This she would not hear of; but she was not so
  1400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled
  1401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet
  1402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere not decidedly better. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters
  1403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeclared that they were miserable. They solaced their wretchedness,
  1404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, by duets after supper, while he could find no better relief
  1405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every
  1406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.
  1407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 9
  1411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the
  1414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the
  1415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid,
  1416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his
  1417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsisters. In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a
  1418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnote sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her
  1419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town judgement of her situation. The note was immediately dispatched, and
  1420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her
  1421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.
  1422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHad she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been
  1424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was
  1425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her
  1426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trestoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield. She
  1427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould not listen, therefore, to her daughter’s proposal of being carried
  1428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think
  1429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit at all advisable. After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss
  1430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley’s appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all
  1431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattended her into the breakfast parlour. Bingley met them with hopes
  1432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.
  1433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed I have, sir,” was her answer. “She is a great deal too ill to be
  1435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass
  1436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta little longer on your kindness.”
  1437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Removed!” cried Bingley. “It must not be thought of. My sister, I am
  1439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure, will not hear of her removal.”
  1440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may depend upon it, Madam,” said Miss Bingley, with cold civility,
  1442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“that Miss Bennet will receive every possible attention while she
  1443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremains with us.”
  1444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was profuse in her acknowledgments.
  1446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sure,” she added, “if it was not for such good friends I do not
  1448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers
  1449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is
  1450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest
  1451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemper I have ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are
  1452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to _her_. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a
  1453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharming prospect over the gravel walk. I do not know a place in the
  1454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountry that is equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it
  1455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin a hurry, I hope, though you have but a short lease.”
  1456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Whatever I do is done in a hurry,” replied he; “and therefore if I
  1458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five
  1459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tminutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.”
  1460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.
  1462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards her.
  1464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! yes--I understand you perfectly.”
  1466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen
  1468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthrough I am afraid is pitiful.”
  1469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is as it happens. It does not follow that a deep, intricate
  1471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.”
  1472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy,” cried her mother, “remember where you are, and do not run on in
  1474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”
  1475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I did not know before,” continued Bingley immediately, “that you were a
  1477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstudier of character. It must be an amusing study.”
  1478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, but intricate characters are the _most_ amusing. They have at
  1480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleast that advantage.”
  1481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The country,” said Darcy, “can in general supply but a few subjects for
  1483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and
  1484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunvarying society.”
  1485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be
  1487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobserved in them for ever.”
  1488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning
  1490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of _that_
  1491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing on in the country as in town.”
  1492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEverybody was surprised, and Darcy, after looking at her for a moment,
  1494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturned silently away. Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete
  1495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvictory over him, continued her triumph.
  1496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country, for
  1498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal
  1499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasanter, is it not, Mr. Bingley?”
  1500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When I am in the country,” he replied, “I never wish to leave it;
  1502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand when I am in town it is pretty much the same. They have each their
  1503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadvantages, and I can be equally happy in either.”
  1504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye--that is because you have the right disposition. But that
  1506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman,” looking at Darcy, “seemed to think the country was nothing
  1507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat all.”
  1508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, Mamma, you are mistaken,” said Elizabeth, blushing for her
  1510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there was not
  1511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a variety of people to be met with in the country as in the town,
  1512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich you must acknowledge to be true.”
  1513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly, my dear, nobody said there were; but as to not meeting
  1515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith many people in this neighbourhood, I believe there are few
  1516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhoods larger. I know we dine with four-and-twenty families.”
  1517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Bingley to keep his
  1519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountenance. His sister was less delicate, and directed her eyes towards
  1520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy with a very expressive smile. Elizabeth, for the sake of
  1521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaying something that might turn her mother’s thoughts, now asked her if
  1522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte Lucas had been at Longbourn since _her_ coming away.
  1523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, she called yesterday with her father. What an agreeable man Sir
  1525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWilliam is, Mr. Bingley, is not he? So much the man of fashion! So
  1526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenteel and easy! He has always something to say to everybody. _That_
  1527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy themselves very
  1528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportant, and never open their mouths, quite mistake the matter.”
  1529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did Charlotte dine with you?”
  1531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, she would go home. I fancy she was wanted about the mince-pies. For
  1533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy part, Mr. Bingley, I always keep servants that can do their own work;
  1534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_my_ daughters are brought up very differently. But everybody is to
  1535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjudge for themselves, and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls,
  1536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI assure you. It is a pity they are not handsome! Not that I think
  1537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte so _very_ plain--but then she is our particular friend.”
  1538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She seems a very pleasant young woman.”
  1540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! dear, yes; but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself
  1542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thas often said so, and envied me Jane’s beauty. I do not like to boast
  1543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my own child, but to be sure, Jane--one does not often see anybody
  1544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter looking. It is what everybody says. I do not trust my own
  1545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartiality. When she was only fifteen, there was a man at my brother
  1546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner’s in town so much in love with her that my sister-in-law was
  1547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure he would make her an offer before we came away. But, however, he
  1548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not. Perhaps he thought her too young. However, he wrote some verses
  1549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton her, and very pretty they were.”
  1550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And so ended his affection,” said Elizabeth impatiently. “There has
  1552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first
  1553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!”
  1554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have been used to consider poetry as the _food_ of love,” said Darcy.
  1556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Of a fine, stout, healthy love it may. Everything nourishes what is
  1558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstrong already. But if it be only a slight, thin sort of inclination, I
  1559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away.”
  1560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy only smiled; and the general pause which ensued made Elizabeth
  1562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttremble lest her mother should be exposing herself again. She longed to
  1563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeak, but could think of nothing to say; and after a short silence Mrs.
  1564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet began repeating her thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to
  1565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, with an apology for troubling him also with Lizzy. Mr. Bingley was
  1566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunaffectedly civil in his answer, and forced his younger sister to be
  1567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivil also, and say what the occasion required. She performed her part
  1568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindeed without much graciousness, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied, and
  1569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon afterwards ordered her carriage. Upon this signal, the youngest of
  1570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther daughters put herself forward. The two girls had been whispering to
  1571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach other during the whole visit, and the result of it was, that the
  1572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoungest should tax Mr. Bingley with having promised on his first coming
  1573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto the country to give a ball at Netherfield.
  1574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia was a stout, well-grown girl of fifteen, with a fine complexion
  1576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand good-humoured countenance; a favourite with her mother, whose
  1577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection had brought her into public at an early age. She had high
  1578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanimal spirits, and a sort of natural self-consequence, which the
  1579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention of the officers, to whom her uncle’s good dinners, and her own
  1580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teasy manners recommended her, had increased into assurance. She was very
  1581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tequal, therefore, to address Mr. Bingley on the subject of the ball, and
  1582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabruptly reminded him of his promise; adding, that it would be the most
  1583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshameful thing in the world if he did not keep it. His answer to this
  1584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsudden attack was delightful to their mother’s ear:
  1585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and when
  1587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour sister is recovered, you shall, if you please, name the very day of
  1588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe ball. But you would not wish to be dancing when she is ill.”
  1589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia declared herself satisfied. “Oh! yes--it would be much better to
  1591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twait till Jane was well, and by that time most likely Captain Carter
  1592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be at Meryton again. And when you have given _your_ ball,” she
  1593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadded, “I shall insist on their giving one also. I shall tell Colonel
  1594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForster it will be quite a shame if he does not.”
  1595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet and her daughters then departed, and Elizabeth returned
  1597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly to Jane, leaving her own and her relations’ behaviour to the
  1598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremarks of the two ladies and Mr. Darcy; the latter of whom, however,
  1599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not be prevailed on to join in their censure of _her_, in spite of
  1600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall Miss Bingley’s witticisms on _fine eyes_.
  1601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 10
  1605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe day passed much as the day before had done. Mrs. Hurst and Miss
  1608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who
  1609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued, though slowly, to mend; and in the evening Elizabeth joined
  1610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir party in the drawing-room. The loo-table, however, did not appear.
  1611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching
  1612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe progress of his letter and repeatedly calling off his attention by
  1613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmessages to his sister. Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and
  1614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Hurst was observing their game.
  1615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in
  1617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattending to what passed between Darcy and his companion. The perpetual
  1618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommendations of the lady, either on his handwriting, or on the evenness
  1619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his lines, or on the length of his letter, with the perfect unconcern
  1620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith which her praises were received, formed a curious dialogue, and was
  1621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texactly in union with her opinion of each.
  1622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”
  1624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe made no answer.
  1626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You write uncommonly fast.”
  1628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.”
  1630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of a
  1632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyear! Letters of business, too! How odious I should think them!”
  1633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of yours.”
  1635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.”
  1637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have already told her so once, by your desire.”
  1639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend
  1641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpens remarkably well.”
  1642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Thank you--but I always mend my own.”
  1644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How can you contrive to write so even?”
  1646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp;
  1650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful
  1651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss
  1652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGrantley’s.”
  1653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again? At
  1655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent I have not room to do them justice.”
  1656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you
  1658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”
  1659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tease, cannot write ill.”
  1665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.”
  1674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them--by which
  1676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeans my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.”
  1677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elizabeth, “must disarm reproof.”
  1679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an
  1682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindirect boast.”
  1683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And which of the two do you call _my_ little recent piece of modesty?”
  1685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The indirect boast; for you are really proud of your defects in
  1687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twriting, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of
  1688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought and carelessness of execution, which, if not estimable, you
  1689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink at least highly interesting. The power of doing anything with
  1690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquickness is always prized much by the possessor, and often without any
  1691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs.
  1692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet this morning that if you ever resolved upon quitting Netherfield

  1695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlaudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business
  1696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tundone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”
  1697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfoolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour,
  1700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI believe what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this
  1701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless
  1702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprecipitance merely to show off before the ladies.”
  1703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdependent on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were

  1709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgo--and at another word, might stay a month.”
  1710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot do justice to his own disposition. You have shown him off now much
  1713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore than he did himself.”
  1714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am

  1727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to
  1730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet,
  1731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and
  1732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering
  1733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone argument in favour of its propriety.”
  1734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To yield readily--easily--to the _persuasion_ of a friend is no merit
  1736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith you.”
  1737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of

  1741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of
  1742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriendship and affection. A regard for the requester would often make

  1745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the
  1746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstance occurs before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour
  1747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthereupon. But in general and ordinary cases between friend and friend,
  1748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no
  1749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying

  1751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  1837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand if you can compass it, do cure the younger girls of running after

  1842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Have you anything else to propose for my domestic felicity?”

  1844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! yes. Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Phillips be placed

  1854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt that moment they were met from another walk by Mrs. Hurst and

  1865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand immediately said:
  1866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the
  1868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tavenue.”

  1870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Elizabeth, who had not the least inclination to remain with them,
