  1876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then ran gaily off, rejoicing as she rambled about, in the hope of
  1878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing at home again in a day or two. Jane was already so much recovered
  1879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.
  1880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 11
  1884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the ladies removed after dinner, Elizabeth ran up to her
  1887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the
  1888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many
  1889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprofessions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable
  1890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared.
  1891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir powers of conversation were considerable. They could describe an
  1892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentertainment with accuracy, relate an anecdote with humour, and laugh
  1893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat their acquaintance with spirit.
  1894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut when the gentlemen entered, Jane was no longer the first object;
  1896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley’s eyes were instantly turned toward Darcy, and she had
  1897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomething to say to him before he had advanced many steps. He addressed
  1898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself to Miss Bennet, with a polite congratulation; Mr. Hurst also
  1899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade her a slight bow, and said he was “very glad;” but diffuseness
  1900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand warmth remained for Bingley’s salutation. He was full of joy and
  1901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention. The first half-hour was spent in piling up the fire, lest she
  1902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould suffer from the change of room; and she removed at his desire
  1903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the other side of the fireplace, that she might be further from
  1904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe door. He then sat down by her, and talked scarcely to anyone
  1905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telse. Elizabeth, at work in the opposite corner, saw it all with great
  1906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelight.
  1907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen tea was over, Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the
  1909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcard-table--but in vain. She had obtained private intelligence that Mr.
  1910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy did not wish for cards; and Mr. Hurst soon found even his open
  1911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpetition rejected. She assured him that no one intended to play, and
  1912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe silence of the whole party on the subject seemed to justify her. Mr.
  1913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHurst had therefore nothing to do, but to stretch himself on one of the
  1914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsofas and go to sleep. Darcy took up a book; Miss Bingley did the same;
  1915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Mrs. Hurst, principally occupied in playing with her bracelets
  1916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand rings, joined now and then in her brother’s conversation with Miss
  1917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet.
  1918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley’s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Mr.
  1920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy’s progress through _his_ book, as in reading her own; and she
  1921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas perpetually either making some inquiry, or looking at his page. She
  1922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not win him, however, to any conversation; he merely answered her
  1923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquestion, and read on. At length, quite exhausted by the attempt to be
  1924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamused with her own book, which she had only chosen because it was the
  1925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecond volume of his, she gave a great yawn and said, “How pleasant
  1926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is to spend an evening in this way! I declare after all there is no
  1927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a
  1928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbook! When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not
  1929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan excellent library.”
  1930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNo one made any reply. She then yawned again, threw aside her book, and
  1932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcast her eyes round the room in quest for some amusement; when hearing
  1933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet, she turned suddenly
  1934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttowards him and said:
  1935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“By the bye, Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at
  1937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield? I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult
  1938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are
  1939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a
  1940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure.”
  1941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you mean Darcy,” cried her brother, “he may go to bed, if he
  1943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchooses, before it begins--but as for the ball, it is quite a settled
  1944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing; and as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough, I shall send
  1945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tround my cards.”
  1946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should like balls infinitely better,” she replied, “if they were
  1948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcarried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably
  1949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much
  1950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore rational if conversation instead of dancing were made the order of
  1951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe day.”
  1952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say, but it would not be
  1954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnear so much like a ball.”
  1955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley made no answer, and soon afterwards she got up and walked
  1957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout the room. Her figure was elegant, and she walked well; but
  1958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, at whom it was all aimed, was still inflexibly studious. In
  1959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe desperation of her feelings, she resolved on one effort more, and,
  1960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturning to Elizabeth, said:
  1961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a
  1963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturn about the room. I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting so
  1964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong in one attitude.”
  1965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was surprised, but agreed to it immediately. Miss Bingley
  1967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsucceeded no less in the real object of her civility; Mr. Darcy looked
  1968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup. He was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as
  1969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth herself could be, and unconsciously closed his book. He was
  1970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdirectly invited to join their party, but he declined it, observing that
  1971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the could imagine but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down
  1972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe room together, with either of which motives his joining them would
  1973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterfere. “What could he mean? She was dying to know what could be his
  1974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeaning?”--and asked Elizabeth whether she could at all understand him?
  1975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not at all,” was her answer; “but depend upon it, he means to be severe
  1977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton us, and our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing
  1978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout it.”
  1979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley, however, was incapable of disappointing Mr. Darcy in
  1981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything, and persevered therefore in requiring an explanation of his
  1982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo motives.
  1983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have not the smallest objection to explaining them,” said he, as soon
  1985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas she allowed him to speak. “You either choose this method of passing
  1986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe evening because you are in each other’s confidence, and have secret
  1987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures
  1988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappear to the greatest advantage in walking; if the first, I would be
  1989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompletely in your way, and if the second, I can admire you much better
  1990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas I sit by the fire.”
  1991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! shocking!” cried Miss Bingley. “I never heard anything so
  1993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?”
  1994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination,” said Elizabeth. “We
  1996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan all plague and punish one another. Tease him--laugh at him. Intimate
  1997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas you are, you must know how it is to be done.”
  1998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  1999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But upon my honour, I do _not_. I do assure you that my intimacy has
  2000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot yet taught me _that_. Tease calmness of manner and presence of
  2001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmind! No, no; I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will
  2002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot expose ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a
  2003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject. Mr. Darcy may hug himself.”
  2004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!” cried Elizabeth. “That is an
  2006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would
  2007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe a great loss to _me_ to have many such acquaintances. I dearly love a
  2008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlaugh.”
  2009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bingley,” said he, “has given me more credit than can be.
  2011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe wisest and the best of men--nay, the wisest and best of their
  2012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactions--may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in
  2013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlife is a joke.”
  2014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly,” replied Elizabeth--“there are such people, but I hope I
  2016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam not one of _them_. I hope I never ridicule what is wise and good.
  2017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFollies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies, _do_ divert me, I own,
  2018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand I laugh at them whenever I can. But these, I suppose, are precisely
  2019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat you are without.”
  2020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study
  2022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong
  2023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding to ridicule.”
  2024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Such as vanity and pride.”
  2026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride--where there is a real
  2028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuperiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation.”
  2029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth turned away to hide a smile.
  2031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume,” said Miss Bingley;
  2033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“and pray what is the result?”
  2034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it
  2036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself without disguise.”
  2037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No,” said Darcy, “I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough,
  2039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch
  2040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor. It is, I believe, too little yielding--certainly too little for the
  2041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconvenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of others
  2042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso soon as I ought, nor their offenses against myself. My feelings
  2043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper
  2044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould perhaps be called resentful. My good opinion once lost, is lost
  2045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforever.”
  2046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_That_ is a failing indeed!” cried Elizabeth. “Implacable resentment
  2048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_is_ a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well. I
  2049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treally cannot _laugh_ at it. You are safe from me.”
  2050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular
  2052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevil--a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.”
  2053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And _your_ defect is to hate everybody.”
  2055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And yours,” he replied with a smile, “is willfully to misunderstand
  2057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.”
  2058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do let us have a little music,” cried Miss Bingley, tired of a
  2060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation in which she had no share. “Louisa, you will not mind my
  2061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twaking Mr. Hurst?”
  2062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer sister had not the smallest objection, and the pianoforte was
  2064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topened; and Darcy, after a few moments’ recollection, was not sorry for
  2065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit. He began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention.
  2066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 12
  2070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the
  2073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext morning to their mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for
  2074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem in the course of the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who had calculated on
  2075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday, which
  2076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould exactly finish Jane’s week, could not bring herself to receive
  2077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem with pleasure before. Her answer, therefore, was not propitious, at
  2078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleast not to Elizabeth’s wishes, for she was impatient to get home. Mrs.
  2079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage
  2080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley
  2081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them
  2082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery well. Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively
  2083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresolved--nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the
  2084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontrary, as being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long,
  2085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley’s carriage immediately, and at
  2086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlength it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield
  2087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat morning should be mentioned, and the request made.
  2088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe communication excited many professions of concern; and enough was
  2090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid of wishing them to stay at least till the following day to work
  2091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Jane; and till the morrow their going was deferred. Miss Bingley was
  2092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen sorry that she had proposed the delay, for her jealousy and dislike
  2093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof one sister much exceeded her affection for the other.
  2094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe master of the house heard with real sorrow that they were to go so
  2096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon, and repeatedly tried to persuade Miss Bennet that it would not be
  2097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsafe for her--that she was not enough recovered; but Jane was firm where
  2098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe felt herself to be right.
  2099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Mr. Darcy it was welcome intelligence--Elizabeth had been at
  2101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield long enough. She attracted him more than he liked--and Miss
  2102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley was uncivil to _her_, and more teasing than usual to himself.
  2103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration
  2104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould _now_ escape him, nothing that could elevate her with the hope
  2105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof influencing his felicity; sensible that if such an idea had been
  2106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight
  2107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin confirming or crushing it. Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke
  2108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten words to her through the whole of Saturday, and though they were
  2109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat one time left by themselves for half-an-hour, he adhered most
  2110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.
  2111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn Sunday, after morning service, the separation, so agreeable to almost
  2113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall, took place. Miss Bingley’s civility to Elizabeth increased at last
  2114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery rapidly, as well as her affection for Jane; and when they parted,
  2115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her
  2116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto see her either at Longbourn or Netherfield, and embracing her most
  2117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttenderly, she even shook hands with the former. Elizabeth took leave of
  2118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole party in the liveliest of spirits.
  2119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother. Mrs. Bennet
  2121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much
  2122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again. But their
  2123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really
  2124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle. The
  2125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of
  2126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits animation, and almost all its sense by the absence of Jane and
  2127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth.
  2128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey found Mary, as usual, deep in the study of thorough-bass and human
  2130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnature; and had some extracts to admire, and some new observations of
  2131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthreadbare morality to listen to. Catherine and Lydia had information
  2132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor them of a different sort. Much had been done and much had been said
  2133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the regiment since the preceding Wednesday; several of the officers
  2134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad dined lately with their uncle, a private had been flogged, and it
  2135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married.
  2136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 13
  2140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at
  2143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbreakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day,
  2144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecause I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
  2145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure,
  2147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in--and I hope _my_ dinners
  2148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.”
  2149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The person of whom I speak is a gentleman, and a stranger.”
  2151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled. “A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr.
  2153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley, I am sure! Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr.
  2154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley. But--good Lord! how unlucky! There is not a bit of fish to be
  2155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgot to-day. Lydia, my love, ring the bell--I must speak to Hill this
  2156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment.”
  2157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is _not_ Mr. Bingley,” said her husband; “it is a person whom I
  2159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever saw in the whole course of my life.”
  2160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being
  2162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teagerly questioned by his wife and his five daughters at once.
  2163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“About a month ago I received this letter; and about a fortnight ago
  2167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI answered it, for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring
  2168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tearly attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead,
  2169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
  2170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.
  2172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing
  2173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own
  2174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchildren; and I am sure, if I had been you, I should have tried long ago
  2175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto do something or other about it.”
  2176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her the nature of an entail. They
  2178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad often attempted to do it before, but it was a subject on which
  2179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason, and she continued to rail
  2180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of
  2181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfive daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.
  2182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,” said Mr. Bennet, “and
  2184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.
  2185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut if you will listen to his letter, you may perhaps be a little
  2186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoftened by his manner of expressing himself.”
  2187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, that I am sure I shall not; and I think it is very impertinent of
  2189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false
  2190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriends. Why could he not keep on quarreling with you, as his father did
  2191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore him?”
  2192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why, indeed; he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that
  2194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thead, as you will hear.”
  2195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, 15th October.
  2197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dear Sir,--
  2199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured
  2201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather always gave me much uneasiness, and since I have had the
  2202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmisfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach; but
  2203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor some time I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might
  2204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone
  2205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.--‘There, Mrs.
  2206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet.’--My mind, however, is now made up on the subject, for having
  2207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be
  2208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de
  2209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has
  2210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be
  2211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her
  2212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which
  2213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare instituted by the Church of England. As a clergyman, moreover, I
  2214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in
  2215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I
  2216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tflatter myself that my present overtures are highly commendable, and
  2217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate
  2218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the
  2219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffered olive-branch. I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the
  2220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeans of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to apologise for
  2221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible
  2222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamends--but of this hereafter. If you should have no objection to
  2223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting
  2224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o’clock, and
  2225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se’ennight
  2226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollowing, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine
  2227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided
  2228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.--I

  2230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters, your well-wisher and friend,
  2231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“WILLIAM COLLINS”

  2234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,”

  2239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however, and if
  2241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to

  2255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould help it if he could.--Could he be a sensible man, sir?”
  2256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, my dear, I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the
  2258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his
  2259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter, which promises well. I am impatient to see him.”
  2260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In point of composition,” said Mary, “the letter does not seem
  2262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdefective. The idea of the olive-branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I
  2263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink it is well expressed.”
  2264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Catherine and Lydia, neither the letter nor its writer were in any
  2266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdegree interesting. It was next to impossible that their cousin should
  2267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome in a scarlet coat, and it was now some weeks since they had
  2268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived pleasure from the society of a man in any other colour. As for
  2269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir mother, Mr. Collins’s letter had done away much of her ill-will,
  2270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which
  2271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tastonished her husband and daughters.
  2272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins was punctual to his time, and was received with great
  2274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoliteness by the whole family. Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the
  2275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in
  2276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneed of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself. He was a
  2277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttall, heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty. His air was grave and
  2278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstately, and his manners were very formal. He had not been long seated
  2279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of
  2280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters; said he had heard much of their beauty, but that in this

  2282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot doubt her seeing them all in due time disposed of in marriage. This

  2284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, who quarreled with no compliments, answered most readily.

  2287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprove so, for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so
  2288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toddly.”

  2290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”

  2293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust confess. Not that I mean to find fault with _you_, for such things
  2294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI know are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates

  2297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and
  2298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing
  2299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come
  2300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprepared to admire them. At present I will not say more; but, perhaps,
  2301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen we are better acquainted--”
  2302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother. They were not the only objects of Mr. Collins’s admiration. The
  2305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised;
  2306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet’s
  2307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his
  2308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town future property. The dinner too in its turn was highly admired; and
  2309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellency of its
  2310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcooking was owing. But he was set right there by Mrs. Bennet, who
  2311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassured him with some asperity that they were very well able to keep a
  2312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen. He
  2313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegged pardon for having displeased her. In a softened tone she declared
  2314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself not at all offended; but he continued to apologise for about a
  2315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquarter of an hour.
  2316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 14
  2320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDuring dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants
  2323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his
  2324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tguest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to
  2325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady
  2326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for
  2327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this comfort, appeared very remarkable. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen
  2328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter. Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise. The subject elevated him
  2329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto more than usual solemnity of manner, and with a most important aspect
  2330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the protested that “he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in
  2331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta person of rank--such affability and condescension, as he had himself
  2332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texperienced from Lady Catherine. She had been graciously pleased to
  2333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapprove of both of the discourses which he had already had the honour of
  2334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreaching before her. She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings,
  2335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of
  2336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquadrille in the evening. Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many
  2337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeople he knew, but _he_ had never seen anything but affability in her.
  2338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she
  2339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the
  2340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhood nor to his leaving the parish occasionally for a week or
  2341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo, to visit his relations. She had even condescended to advise him to
  2342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had
  2343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonce paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly
  2344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapproved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed
  2345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto suggest some herself--some shelves in the closet up stairs.”
  2346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and
  2348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies
  2349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”
  2350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane
  2352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Rosings Park, her ladyship’s residence.”
  2353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I think you said she was a widow, sir? Has she any family?”
  2355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She has only one daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very
  2357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textensive property.”
  2358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Ah!” said Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than
  2360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany girls. And what sort of young lady is she? Is she handsome?”
  2361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is a most charming young lady indeed. Lady Catherine herself says
  2363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the
  2364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thandsomest of her sex, because there is that in her features which marks
  2365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe young lady of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly
  2366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconstitution, which has prevented her from making that progress in many
  2367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccomplishments which she could not have otherwise failed of, as I am
  2368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinformed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still
  2369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends
  2370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”
  2371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at
  2373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcourt.”
  2374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town;
  2376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand by that means, as I told Lady Catherine one day, has deprived the
  2377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBritish court of its brightest ornament. Her ladyship seemed pleased
  2378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to
  2379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable
  2380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that
  2381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess, and that the most
  2382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\televated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by
  2383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther. These are the kind of little things which please her ladyship, and
  2384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to
  2385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpay.”
  2386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet, “and it is happy for you
  2388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask
  2389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the
  2390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment, or are the result of previous study?”
  2391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I
  2393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant
  2394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to
  2395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive them as unstudied an air as possible.”
  2396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet’s expectations were fully answered. His cousin was as absurd
  2398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas he had hoped, and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment,
  2399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance,
  2400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner
  2401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin his pleasure.
  2402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBy tea-time, however, the dose had been enough, and Mr. Bennet was glad
  2404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto take his guest into the drawing-room again, and, when tea was over,
  2405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad to invite him to read aloud to the ladies. Mr. Collins readily
  2406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassented, and a book was produced; but, on beholding it (for everything
  2407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tannounced it to be from a circulating library), he started back, and
  2408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegging pardon, protested that he never read novels. Kitty stared at
  2409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, and Lydia exclaimed. Other books were produced, and after some
  2410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeliberation he chose Fordyce’s Sermons. Lydia gaped as he opened the
  2411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvolume, and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three
  2412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpages, she interrupted him with:
  2413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Phillips talks of turning away
  2415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRichard; and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me
  2416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more
  2417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.”
  2418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr.
  2420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said:
  2421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books
  2423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit. It amazes
  2424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme, I confess; for, certainly, there can be nothing so advantageous to
  2425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem as instruction. But I will no longer importune my young cousin.”
  2426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThen turning to Mr. Bennet, he offered himself as his antagonist at
  2428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbackgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted
  2429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements.
  2430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet and her daughters apologised most civilly for Lydia’s
  2431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would
  2432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his
  2433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoung cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any
  2434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared
  2435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor backgammon.
  2436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 15
  2440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had
  2443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part
  2444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and
  2445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmiserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he
  2446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad merely kept the necessary terms, without forming at it any useful
  2447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance. The subjection in which his father had brought him up had
  2448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgiven him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a
  2449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in
  2450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tretirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected
  2451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprosperity. A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de
  2452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which
  2453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness,
  2454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a
  2455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of
  2456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
  2457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHaving now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to
  2459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had
  2460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found
  2461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.
  2462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was his plan of amends--of atonement--for inheriting their father’s
  2463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and
  2464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own
  2465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpart.
  2466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis plan did not vary on seeing them. Miss Bennet’s lovely face
  2468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what
  2469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas due to seniority; and for the first evening _she_ was his settled
  2470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchoice. The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a
  2471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquarter of an hour’s tete-a-tete with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a
  2472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally
  2473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress might be found for it at
  2474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general
  2475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to
  2476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther _younger_ daughters, she could not take upon her to say--she could
  2477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot positively answer--but she did not _know_ of any prepossession; her
  2478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_eldest_ daughter, she must just mention--she felt it incumbent on her
  2479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
  2480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth--and it was soon
  2482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone--done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, equally
  2483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
  2484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have
  2486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of
  2487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe day before was now high in her good graces.
  2488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten; every sister
  2490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcept Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them,
  2491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him,
  2492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed
  2493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim after breakfast; and there he would continue, nominally engaged with
  2494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr.
  2495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford. Such
  2496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoings discomposed Mr. Bennet exceedingly. In his library he had been
  2497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told
  2498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room of the
  2499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse, he was used to be free from them there; his civility, therefore,
  2500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their
  2501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker
  2502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan a reader, was extremely pleased to close his large book, and go.
  2503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn pompous nothings on his side, and civil assents on that of his
  2505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton. The attention of
  2506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him. Their eyes were
  2507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately wandering up in the street in quest of the officers, and
  2508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing less than a very smart bonnet indeed, or a really new muslin in
  2509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta shop window, could recall them.
  2510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom
  2512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking
  2513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith another officer on the other side of the way. The officer was
  2514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came
  2515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto inquire, and he bowed as they passed. All were struck with the
  2516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia,
  2517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under
  2518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpretense of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately
  2519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad just gained the pavement when the two gentlemen, turning back, had
  2520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treached the same spot. Mr. Denny addressed them directly, and entreated
  2521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpermission to introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had returned with
  2522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim the day before from town, and he was happy to say had accepted a
  2523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommission in their corps. This was exactly as it should be; for the
  2524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoung man wanted only regimentals to make him completely charming.
  2525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis appearance was greatly in his favour; he had all the best part of
  2526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeauty, a fine countenance, a good figure, and very pleasing address.
  2527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness
  2528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof conversation--a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and
  2529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together
  2530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy
  2531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Bingley were seen riding down the street. On distinguishing the
  2532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies of the group, the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and
  2533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegan the usual civilities. Bingley was the principal spokesman, and
  2534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet the principal object. He was then, he said, on his way to
  2535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn on purpose to inquire after her. Mr. Darcy corroborated
  2536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes
  2537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the
  2538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstranger, and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they
  2539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting.
  2540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBoth changed colour, one looked white, the other red. Mr. Wickham,
  2541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter a few moments, touched his hat--a salutation which Mr. Darcy just
  2542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeigned to return. What could be the meaning of it? It was impossible to
  2543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timagine; it was impossible not to long to know.
  2544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn another minute, Mr. Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what
  2546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpassed, took leave and rode on with his friend.
  2547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of
  2549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Phillip’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s
  2550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpressing entreaties that they should come in, and even in spite of
  2551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Phillips’s throwing up the parlour window and loudly seconding the
  2552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvitation.
  2553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Phillips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest,
  2555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom their recent absence, were particularly welcome, and she was
  2556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as
  2557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing
  2558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout, if she had not happened to see Mr. Jones’s shop-boy in the
  2559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstreet, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to
  2560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility
  2561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas claimed towards Mr. Collins by Jane’s introduction of him. She
  2562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived him with her very best politeness, which he returned with
  2563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas much more, apologising for his intrusion, without any previous
  2564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself,
  2565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who
  2566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduced him to her notice. Mrs. Phillips was quite awed by such an
  2567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon
  2568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tput to an end by exclamations and inquiries about the other; of whom,
  2569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that
  2570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a
  2571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlieutenant’s commission in the ----shire. She had been watching him the
  2572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street, and had Mr.
  2573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the
  2574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccupation, but unluckily no one passed windows now except a few of the
  2575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tofficers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid,
  2576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Phillipses
  2577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on Mr.
  2578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn
  2579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould come in the evening. This was agreed to, and Mrs. Phillips
  2580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprotested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery
  2581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards. The prospect of such
  2582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelights was very cheering, and they parted in mutual good spirits. Mr.
  2583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins repeated his apologies in quitting the room, and was assured
  2584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith unwearying civility that they were perfectly needless.
  2585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass
  2587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either
  2588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor both, had they appeared to be in the wrong, she could no more explain
  2589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch behaviour than her sister.
  2590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mrs. Bennet by admiring
  2592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Phillips’s manners and politeness. He protested that, except Lady
  2593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman;
  2594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but even
  2595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although
  2596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tutterly unknown to her before. Something, he supposed, might be
  2597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so
  2598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch attention in the whole course of his life.
  2599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 16
  2603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their
  2606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for
  2607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach
  2608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and
  2609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room,
  2610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in
  2611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe house.
  2612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr.
  2614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much
  2615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstruck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he
  2616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast
  2617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much
  2618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratification; but when Mrs. Phillips understood from him what
  2619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings was, and who was its proprietor--when she had listened to the
  2620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdescription of only one of Lady Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found
  2621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all
  2622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison
  2623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the housekeeper’s room.
  2624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion,
  2626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and
  2627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the
  2628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen joined them; and he found in Mrs. Phillips a very attentive
  2629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlistener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she
  2630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as
  2631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as she could. To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin,
  2632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine
  2633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir own indifferent imitations of china on the mantelpiece, the
  2634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterval of waiting appeared very long. It was over at last, however.
  2635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe gentlemen did approach, and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room,
  2636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking
  2637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration.
  2638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable,
  2639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemanlike set, and the best of them were of the present party; but
  2640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and
  2641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalk, as _they_ were superior to the broad-faced, stuffy uncle Phillips,
  2642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbreathing port wine, who followed them into the room.
  2643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was
  2645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated
  2646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into
  2647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, made her feel
  2648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered
  2649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinteresting by the skill of the speaker.
  2650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the
  2652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tofficers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young
  2653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind
  2654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlistener in Mrs. Phillips, and was by her watchfulness, most abundantly
  2655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupplied with coffee and muffin. When the card-tables were placed, he
  2656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad the opportunity of obliging her in turn, by sitting down to whist.
  2657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad
  2659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto improve myself, for in my situation in life--” Mrs. Phillips was very
  2660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.
  2661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he
  2663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia. At first there
  2664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most
  2665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets,
  2666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets
  2667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand exclaiming after prizes to have attention for anyone in particular.
  2668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAllowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore
  2669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear
  2670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be
  2671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttold--the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She dared not
  2672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teven mention that gentleman. Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly
  2673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelieved. Mr. Wickham began the subject himself. He inquired how far
  2674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in
  2675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
  2676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrop, added, “He is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I
  2679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstand.”
  2680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes,” replied Mr. Wickham; “his estate there is a noble one. A clear
  2682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten thousand per annum. You could not have met with a person more
  2683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcapable of giving you certain information on that head than myself, for
  2684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI have been connected with his family in a particular manner from my
  2685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinfancy.”
  2686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after

  2691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyesterday. Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy?”
  2692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable.”

  2698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable or otherwise. I am not qualified to form one. I have known him

  2713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thigh and imposing manners, and sees him only as he chooses to be seen.”

  2716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\till-tempered man.” Wickham only shook his head.

  2740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta most respectable, agreeable corps, and my friend Denny tempted me
  2749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfurther by his account of their present quarters, and the very great
  2750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattentions and excellent acquaintances Meryton had procured them.
  2751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSociety, I own, is necessary to me. I have been a disappointed man, and
  2752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy spirits will not bear solitude. I _must_ have employment and society.
  2753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tA military life is not what I was intended for, but circumstances have
  2754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnow made it eligible. The church _ought_ to have been my profession--I
  2755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas brought up for the church, and I should at this time have been in
  2756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossession of a most valuable living, had it pleased the gentleman we
  2757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere speaking of just now.”

  2759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed!”

  2761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes--the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best
  2762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliving in his gift. He was my godfather, and excessively attached to me.
  2763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI cannot do justice to his kindness. He meant to provide for me amply,
  2764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand thought he had done it; but when the living fell, it was given
  2765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telsewhere.”

  2768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be disregarded? Why did you not seek legal redress?”

  2770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to
  2771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive me no hope from law. A man of honour could not have doubted the

  2773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim
  2774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto it by extravagance, imprudence--in short anything or nothing. Certain

  2797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattachment to me irritated him, I believe, very early in life. He had
  2798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood--the sort
  2799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof preference which was often given me.”

  2801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this--though I have never liked
  2802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. I had not thought so very ill of him. I had supposed him to be

  2821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We were born in the same parish, within the same park; the greatest
  2823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpart of our youth was passed together; inmates of the same house,
  2824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsharing the same amusements, objects of the same parental care. _My_
  2825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather began life in the profession which your uncle, Mr. Phillips,
  2826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappears to do so much credit to--but he gave up everything to be of
  2827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuse to the late Mr. Darcy and devoted all his time to the care of the
  2828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley property. He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy, a most
