  2830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe under the greatest obligations to my father’s active superintendence,
  2831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand when, immediately before my father’s death, Mr. Darcy gave him a
  2832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvoluntary promise of providing for me, I am convinced that he felt it to

  2834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  2836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you! If from no better
  2837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmotive, that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest--for
  2838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdishonesty I must call it.”

  2840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It _is_ wonderful,” replied Wickham, “for almost all his actions may
  2841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe traced to pride; and pride had often been his best friend. It has

  2843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnone of us consistent, and in his behaviour to me there were stronger
  2844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpulses even than pride.”
  2845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good?”
  2847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes. It has often led him to be liberal and generous, to give his money
  2849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfreely, to display hospitality, to assist his tenants, and relieve the
  2850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoor. Family pride, and _filial_ pride--for he is very proud of what
  2851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this father was--have done this. Not to appear to disgrace his family,
  2852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto degenerate from the popular qualities, or lose the influence of the
  2853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley House, is a powerful motive. He has also _brotherly_ pride,
  2854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich, with _some_ brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and
  2855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcareful guardian of his sister, and you will hear him generally cried up
  2856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas the most attentive and best of brothers.”
  2857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What sort of girl is Miss Darcy?”
  2859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable. It gives me pain to
  2861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeak ill of a Darcy. But she is too much like her brother--very, very
  2862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproud. As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond
  2863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is
  2864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen,
  2865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her father’s death, her
  2866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her
  2867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teducation.”
  2868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not
  2870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thelp reverting once more to the first, and saying:
  2871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley! How can Mr. Bingley,
  2873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho seems good humour itself, and is, I really believe, truly amiable,
  2874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe in friendship with such a man? How can they suit each other? Do you
  2875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow Mr. Bingley?”
  2876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not at all.”
  2878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is a sweet-tempered, amiable, charming man. He cannot know what Mr.
  2880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy is.”
  2881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Probably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not
  2883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twant abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth
  2884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is
  2885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His
  2886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just,
  2887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsincere, rational, honourable, and perhaps agreeable--allowing something
  2888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor fortune and figure.”
  2889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round
  2891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe other table and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin
  2892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth and Mrs. Phillips. The usual inquiries as to his success were
  2893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade by the latter. It had not been very great; he had lost every
  2894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoint; but when Mrs. Phillips began to express her concern thereupon,
  2895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the assured her with much earnest gravity that it was not of the least
  2896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportance, that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged
  2897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she would not make herself uneasy.
  2898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a
  2900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcard-table, they must take their chances of these things, and happily I
  2901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object. There
  2902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare undoubtedly many who could not say the same, but thanks to Lady
  2903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding
  2904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle matters.”
  2905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for
  2907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relation
  2908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas very intimately acquainted with the family of de Bourgh.
  2909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him
  2911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta living. I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to her
  2912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnotice, but he certainly has not known her long.”
  2913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy
  2915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present Mr. Darcy.”
  2916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, indeed, I did not. I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine’s
  2918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnections. I never heard of her existence till the day before
  2919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyesterday.”
  2920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is
  2922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelieved that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”
  2923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss
  2925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley. Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her
  2926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already
  2927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tself-destined for another.
  2928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her
  2930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughter; but from some particulars that he has related of her ladyship,
  2931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI suspect his gratitude misleads him, and that in spite of her being his
  2932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpatroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”
  2933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have
  2935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot seen her for many years, but I very well remember that I never liked
  2936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent. She has the
  2937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe
  2938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from
  2939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride for her
  2940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an
  2941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding of the first class.”
  2942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and
  2944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey continued talking together, with mutual satisfaction till supper
  2945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tput an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr.
  2946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s attentions. There could be no conversation in the noise
  2947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Mrs. Phillips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to
  2948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverybody. Whatever he said, was said well; and whatever he did, done
  2949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgracefully. Elizabeth went away with her head full of him. She could
  2950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told her, all
  2951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name
  2952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas they went, for neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins were once silent. Lydia
  2953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the
  2954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfish she had won; and Mr. Collins in describing the civility of Mr. and
  2955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Phillips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses
  2956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing
  2957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage
  2958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.
  2959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 17
  2963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth related to Jane the next day what had passed between Mr.
  2966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham and herself. Jane listened with astonishment and concern; she
  2967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr.
  2968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley’s regard; and yet, it was not in her nature to question the
  2969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tveracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham. The
  2970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossibility of his having endured such unkindness, was enough to
  2971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest all her tender feelings; and nothing remained therefore to be
  2972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone, but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each,
  2973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be
  2974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\totherwise explained.
  2975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way
  2977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor other, of which we can form no idea. Interested people have perhaps
  2978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmisrepresented each to the other. It is, in short, impossible for us to
  2979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them,
  2980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout actual blame on either side.”
  2981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say on
  2983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the
  2984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness? Do clear _them_ too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of
  2985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomebody.”
  2986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my
  2988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion. My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light
  2989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such
  2990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta manner, one whom his father had promised to provide for. It is
  2991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpossible. No man of common humanity, no man who had any value for his
  2992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter, could be capable of it. Can his most intimate friends be so
  2993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcessively deceived in him? Oh! no.”
  2994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  2995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I can much more easily believe Mr. Bingley’s being imposed on, than
  2996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Wickham should invent such a history of himself as he gave me
  2997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast night; names, facts, everything mentioned without ceremony. If it
  2998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe not so, let Mr. Darcy contradict it. Besides, there was truth in his
  2999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooks.”
  3000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is difficult indeed--it is distressing. One does not know what to
  3002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink.”
  3003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I beg your pardon; one knows exactly what to think.”
  3005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Jane could think with certainty on only one point--that Mr. Bingley,
  3007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif he _had_ been imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair
  3008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecame public.
  3009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery, where this
  3011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation passed, by the arrival of the very persons of whom they had
  3012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen speaking; Mr. Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal
  3013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvitation for the long-expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed
  3014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the following Tuesday. The two ladies were delighted to see their
  3015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly
  3016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tasked what she had been doing with herself since their separation. To
  3017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding Mrs. Bennet
  3018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas much as possible, saying not much to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to
  3019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe others. They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an
  3020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactivity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if
  3021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teager to escape from Mrs. Bennet’s civilities.
  3022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every
  3024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfemale of the family. Mrs. Bennet chose to consider it as given in
  3025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered
  3026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a
  3027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tceremonious card. Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the
  3028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsociety of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and
  3029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr.
  3030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy’s look
  3031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand behaviour. The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended
  3032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless on any single event, or any particular person, for though they
  3033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham,
  3034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball
  3035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas, at any rate, a ball. And even Mary could assure her family that she
  3036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad no disinclination for it.
  3037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough--I
  3039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements.
  3040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSociety has claims on us all; and I profess myself one of those
  3041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for
  3042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverybody.”
  3043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s spirits were so high on this occasion, that though she did
  3045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking
  3046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if
  3047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s
  3048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no
  3049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke
  3050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teither from the Archbishop, or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to
  3051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdance.
  3052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am by no means of the opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball
  3054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people,
  3055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing
  3056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair
  3057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of
  3058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially,
  3059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right
  3060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcause, and not to any disrespect for her.”
  3061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth felt herself completely taken in. She had fully proposed being
  3063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengaged by Mr. Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins
  3064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstead! her liveliness had never been worse timed. There was no help
  3065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor it, however. Mr. Wickham’s happiness and her own were perforce
  3066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins’s proposal accepted with as
  3067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood a grace as she could. She was not the better pleased with his
  3068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgallantry from the idea it suggested of something more. It now first
  3069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstruck her, that _she_ was selected from among her sisters as worthy
  3070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof being mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a
  3071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors.
  3072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing
  3073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivilities toward herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a
  3074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than
  3075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before
  3076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage
  3077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas extremely agreeable to _her_. Elizabeth, however, did not choose
  3078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the
  3079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequence of any reply. Mr. Collins might never make the offer, and
  3080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill he did, it was useless to quarrel about him.
  3081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIf there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the
  3083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger Miss Bennets would have been in a very pitiable state at this

  3085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton
  3086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonce. No aunt, no officers, no news could be sought after--the very
  3087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy. Even Elizabeth might have
  3088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound some trial of her patience in weather which totally suspended the
  3089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprovement of her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; and nothing less than
  3090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta dance on Tuesday, could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and
  3091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMonday endurable to Kitty and Lydia.
  3092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 18
  3096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTill Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in
  3099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a
  3100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubt of his being present had never occurred to her. The certainty
  3101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that
  3102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight not unreasonably have alarmed her. She had dressed with more than
  3103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tusual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all
  3104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than
  3105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight be won in the course of the evening. But in an instant arose
  3106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted for Mr. Darcy’s
  3107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though
  3108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was
  3109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpronounced by his friend Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who
  3110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttold them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the
  3111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,
  3112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if
  3113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the had not wanted to avoid a certain gentleman here.”
  3114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by
  3116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for
  3117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every
  3118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate
  3119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to
  3120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make.
  3121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAttendance, forbearance, patience with Darcy, was injury to Wickham. She
  3122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away
  3123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in
  3124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.
  3125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect
  3127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her
  3128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits; and having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had
  3129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition
  3130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular
  3131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnotice. The first two dances, however, brought a return of distress;
  3132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were dances of mortification. Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn,
  3133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapologising instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being
  3134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable
  3135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartner for a couple of dances can give. The moment of her release from
  3136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim was ecstasy.
  3137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of
  3139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked. When those dances
  3140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with
  3141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy who took
  3142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that,
  3143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout knowing what she did, she accepted him. He walked away again
  3144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of
  3145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmind; Charlotte tried to console her:
  3146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”
  3148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Heaven forbid! _That_ would be the greatest misfortune of all! To find
  3150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! Do not wish me such an
  3151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevil.”
  3152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her
  3154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her in a whisper, not to be a
  3155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsimpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant
  3156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the eyes of a man ten times his consequence. Elizabeth made no
  3157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which

  3160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit. They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to

  3169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  3171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid.
  3172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  3174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobserve that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones. But
  3175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_now_ we may be silent.”
  3176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”
  3178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Sometimes. One must speak a little, you know. It would look odd to be
  3180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentirely silent for half an hour together; and yet for the advantage of
  3181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_some_, conversation ought to be so arranged, as that they may have the
  3182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrouble of saying as little as possible.”
  3183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you
  3185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timagine that you are gratifying mine?”
  3186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great
  3188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsimilarity in the turn of our minds. We are each of an unsocial,
  3189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttaciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say
  3190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomething that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to
  3191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tposterity with all the eclat of a proverb.”
  3192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,”

  3196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must not decide on my own performance.”
  3198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe made no answer, and they were again silent till they had gone down
  3200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often
  3201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalk to Meryton. She answered in the affirmative, and, unable to resist
  3202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just
  3203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen forming a new acquaintance.”
  3204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe effect was immediate. A deeper shade of _hauteur_ overspread his
  3206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeatures, but he said not a word, and Elizabeth, though blaming herself

  3208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconstrained manner said, “Mr. Wickham is blessed with such happy manners
  3209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas may ensure his _making_ friends--whether he may be equally capable of

  3216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject. At

  3225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisgrace you, and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated,

  3241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWe have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we
  3242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare to talk of next I cannot imagine.”
  3243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What think you of books?” said he, smiling.
  3245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  3247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings.”
  3248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be
  3250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno want of subject. We may compare our different opinions.”

  3271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion,

  3274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“May I ask to what these questions tend?”

  3303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYour sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand
  3304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquestions; and I find that the young man quite forgot to tell you, among
  3305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this other communication, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late
  3306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy’s steward. Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to

  3309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways been remarkably kind to him, though George Wickham has treated
  3310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy in a most infamous manner. I do not know the particulars, but
  3311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI know very well that Mr. Darcy is not in the least to blame, that he

  3313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought that he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to
  3314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself

  3316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it. I pity you,

  3318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidering his descent, one could not expect much better.”

  3320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His guilt and his descent appear by your account to be the same,” said
  3321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse

  3331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy.” She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make
  3332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiries on the same subject of Bingley. Jane met her with a smile of

  3344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing
  3345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfactory to tell you. Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of
  3346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have
  3347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprincipally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct,
  3348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe probity, and honour of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that
  3349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has
  3350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived; and I am sorry to say by his account as well as his sister’s,
  3351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man. I am afraid he has
  3352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen very imprudent, and has deserved to lose Mr. Darcy’s regard.”
  3353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Bingley does not know Mr. Wickham himself?”

  3361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard
  3362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem from Mr. Darcy more than once, but he believes that it was left to

  3367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley’s defense of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but
  3368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsince he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt

  3371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on
  3373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich there could be no difference of sentiment. Elizabeth listened with

  3376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin it. On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew
  3377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

  3379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand told her with great exultation that he had just been so fortunate as
  3380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make a most important discovery.
  3381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now
  3383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the room a near relation of my patroness. I happened to overhear the
  3384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of
  3385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe house the names of his cousin Miss de Bourgh, and of her mother Lady
  3386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine. How wonderfully these sort of things occur! Who would have
  3387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought of my meeting with, perhaps, a nephew of Lady Catherine de
  3388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBourgh in this assembly! I am most thankful that the discovery is made

  3390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before. My total
  3391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”
  3392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are not going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy!”

  3395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed I am. I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier.
  3396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI believe him to be Lady Catherine’s _nephew_. It will be in my power to
  3397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassure him that her ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
  3398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme, assuring him
  3400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction
  3401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that
  3402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either
  3403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside; and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in
  3404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequence, to begin the acquaintance. Mr. Collins listened to her
  3405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the determined air of following his own inclination, and, when she
  3406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tceased speaking, replied thus:
  3407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world in
  3409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour excellent judgement in all matters within the scope of your
  3410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding; but permit me to say, that there must be a wide
  3411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity,
  3412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that
  3413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with
  3414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe highest rank in the kingdom--provided that a proper humility of
  3415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour is at the same time maintained. You must therefore allow me to
  3416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which leads me to
  3417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperform what I look on as a point of duty. Pardon me for neglecting to
  3418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprofit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant
  3419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tguide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by
  3420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teducation and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young
  3421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlady like yourself.” And with a low bow he left her to attack Mr.
  3422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose
  3423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tastonishment at being so addressed was very evident. Her cousin prefaced
  3424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this speech with a solemn bow and though she could not hear a word of
  3425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the
  3426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twords “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed
  3427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther to see him expose himself to such a man. Mr. Darcy was eyeing him
  3428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith unrestrained wonder, and when at last Mr. Collins allowed him time
  3429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto speak, replied with an air of distant civility. Mr. Collins, however,
  3430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy’s contempt seemed
  3431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabundantly increasing with the length of his second speech, and at the
  3432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tend of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way. Mr.
  3433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins then returned to Elizabeth.
  3434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my
  3436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treception. Mr. Darcy seemed much pleased with the attention. He answered
  3437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying
  3438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine’s discernment as to be
  3439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertain she could never bestow a favour unworthily. It was really a very
  3440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thandsome thought. Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”
  3441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned
  3443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther attention almost entirely on her sister and Mr. Bingley; and the
  3444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrain of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to,
  3445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade her perhaps almost as happy as Jane. She saw her in idea settled in
  3446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection
  3447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of
  3448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tendeavouring even to like Bingley’s two sisters. Her mother’s thoughts
  3449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to
  3450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tventure near her, lest she might hear too much. When they sat down to
  3451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which
  3452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplaced them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find
  3453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely,
  3454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topenly, and of nothing else but her expectation that Jane would soon
  3455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe married to Mr. Bingley. It was an animating subject, and Mrs. Bennet
  3456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the
  3457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmatch. His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but
  3458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthree miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and
  3459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of
  3460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as
  3461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could do. It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger
  3462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of
  3463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother rich men; and lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be
  3464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\table to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that
  3465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked. It was
  3466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on
  3467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mrs.
  3468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet to find comfort in staying home at any period of her life. She
  3469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally
  3470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no
  3471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchance of it.
  3472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s
  3474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twords, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible
  3475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhisper; for, to her inexpressible vexation, she could perceive that the
  3476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them. Her
  3477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
  3478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is Mr. Darcy to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him? I am
  3480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say
  3481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing _he_ may not like to hear.”
  3482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower. What advantage can it be for you
  3484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto offend Mr. Darcy? You will never recommend yourself to his friend by
  3485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso doing!”
  3486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNothing that she could say, however, had any influence. Her mother would
  3488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalk of her views in the same intelligible tone. Elizabeth blushed and
  3489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tblushed again with shame and vexation. She could not help frequently

  3492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconvinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her. The expression
  3493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and
  3494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsteady gravity.
  3495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who
  3497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no
  3498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and
  3499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchicken. Elizabeth now began to revive. But not long was the interval of
  3500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttranquillity; for, when supper was over, singing was talked of, and
  3501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty,
  3502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreparing to oblige the company. By many significant looks and silent
  3503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentreaties, did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,
  3504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of
  3505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song. Elizabeth’s
  3506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teyes were fixed on her with most painful sensations, and she watched her
  3507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprogress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very
  3508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\till rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving, amongst the thanks
  3509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the table, the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to
  3510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another.
  3511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was
  3512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweak, and her manner affected. Elizabeth was in agonies. She looked at
  3513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to
  3514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley. She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs
  3515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however,
  3516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timperturbably grave. She looked at her father to entreat his
  3517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterference, lest Mary should be singing all night. He took the hint,
  3518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud, “That will do
  3519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other
  3520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoung ladies have time to exhibit.”
  3521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and
  3523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid
  3524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther anxiety had done no good. Others of the party were now applied to.
  3525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If I,” said Mr. Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I
  3527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an
  3528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tair; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly
  3529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompatible with the profession of a clergyman. I do not mean, however,
  3530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time
  3531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to. The
  3532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trector of a parish has much to do. In the first place, he must make
  3533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not
  3534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffensive to his patron. He must write his own sermons; and the time
  3535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care
  3536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making
  3537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas comfortable as possible. And I do not think it of light importance
  3538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody,
  3539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tespecially towards those to whom he owes his preferment. I cannot acquit
  3540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an
  3541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the
  3542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily.” And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, which had
  3543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room. Many stared--many
  3544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his
  3545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twife seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly,
  3546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand observed in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably
  3547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclever, good kind of young man.
  3548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Elizabeth it appeared that, had her family made an agreement to
  3550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would
  3551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit or

  3554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he
  3555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have witnessed. That his two sisters and Mr. Darcy, however, should
  3556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations, was bad enough,
  3557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the
  3558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.
  3559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe rest of the evening brought her little amusement. She was teased by
  3561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side, and though
  3562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the could not prevail on her to dance with him again, put it out of her
  3563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpower to dance with others. In vain did she entreat him to stand up with
  3564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomebody else, and offer to introduce him to any young lady in the room.
  3565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe assured her, that as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it;
  3566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat his chief object was by delicate attentions to recommend himself to
  3567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her
  3568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole evening. There was no arguing upon such a project. She owed
  3569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and
  3570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins’s conversation to herself.
  3571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was at least free from the offense of Mr. Darcy’s further notice;
  3573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough often standing within a very short distance of her, quite
  3574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisengaged, he never came near enough to speak. She felt it to be the
  3575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprobable consequence of her allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in
  3576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit.
  3577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart, and, by
  3579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta manoeuvre of Mrs. Bennet, had to wait for their carriage a quarter of
  3580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how
  3581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theartily they were wished away by some of the family. Mrs. Hurst and her
  3582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister scarcely opened their mouths, except to complain of fatigue, and

  3586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his
  3587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and
  3588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoliteness which had marked their behaviour to their guests. Darcy said
  3589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing at all. Mr. Bennet, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene.
  3590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley and Jane were standing together, a little detached from the
  3591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trest, and talked only to each other. Elizabeth preserved as steady a
  3592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilence as either Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too

  3594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
  3595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen at length they arose to take leave, Mrs. Bennet was most pressingly
  3597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn, and
  3598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddressed herself especially to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he
  3599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould make them by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without
  3600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe ceremony of a formal invitation. Bingley was all grateful pleasure,
  3601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on
  3602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next
  3603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday for a short time.
  3604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was perfectly satisfied, and quitted the house under the
  3606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of
  3607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly
  3608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four
  3609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmonths. Of having another daughter married to Mr. Collins, she thought
  3610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure.
  3611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the
  3612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tman and the match were quite good enough for _her_, the worth of each
  3613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.
  3614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 19
  3618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe next day opened a new scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins made his
  3621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeclaration in form. Having resolved to do it without loss of time, as
  3622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday, and having
  3623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to himself even at
  3624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe moment, he set about it in a very orderly manner, with all the
  3625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobservances, which he supposed a regular part of the business. On
  3626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinding Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together,
  3627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words:
  3628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth,
  3630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the
  3631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcourse of this morning?”
  3632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBefore Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mrs.
  3634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet answered instantly, “Oh dear!--yes--certainly. I am sure Lizzy
  3635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be very happy--I am sure she can have no objection. Come, Kitty, I
  3636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twant you up stairs.” And, gathering her work together, she was hastening
  3637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taway, when Elizabeth called out:
  3638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dear madam, do not go. I beg you will not go. Mr. Collins must excuse
  3640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme. He can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear. I am
  3641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing away myself.”
  3642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, no, nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you to stay where you are.” And upon
  3644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to
  3645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tescape, she added: “Lizzy, I _insist_ upon your staying and hearing Mr.
  3646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins.”
  3647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth would not oppose such an injunction--and a moment’s
  3649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it
  3650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again and tried to
  3651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceal, by incessant employment the feelings which were divided between
  3652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistress and diversion. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as
  3653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were gone, Mr. Collins began.
  3654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from
  3656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections. You
  3657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould have been less amiable in my eyes had there _not_ been this little
  3658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunwillingness; but allow me to assure you, that I have your respected
  3659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother’s permission for this address. You can hardly doubt the
  3660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpurport of my discourse, however your natural delicacy may lead you to
  3661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as
  3662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as I entered the house, I singled you out as the companion of
  3663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy future life. But before I am run away with by my feelings on this
  3664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject, perhaps it would be advisable for me to state my reasons for
  3665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarrying--and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design
  3666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”
  3667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe idea of Mr. Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away
  3669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith by his feelings, made Elizabeth so near laughing, that she could
  3670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him further,
  3671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand he continued:
  3672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for
  3674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example
  3675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced that it will
  3676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadd very greatly to my happiness; and thirdly--which perhaps I ought
  3677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and
  3678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecommendation of the very noble lady whom I have the honour of calling
  3679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpatroness. Twice has she condescended to give me her opinion (unasked
  3680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I
  3681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleft Hunsford--between our pools at quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was
  3682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarranging Miss de Bourgh’s footstool, that she said, ‘Mr. Collins, you
  3683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust marry. A clergyman like you must marry. Choose properly, choose
  3684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta gentlewoman for _my_ sake; and for your _own_, let her be an active,
  3685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuseful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small
  3686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincome go a good way. This is my advice. Find such a woman as soon as
  3687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou can, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her.’ Allow me, by the
  3688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice
  3689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the
  3690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadvantages in my power to offer. You will find her manners beyond
  3691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be
  3692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacceptable to her, especially when tempered with the silence and
  3693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespect which her rank will inevitably excite. Thus much for my general
  3694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views

  3696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan assure you there are many amiable young women. But the fact is, that
  3697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured
  3698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy
  3699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself without resolving to choose a wife from among his daughters, that
  3700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe loss to them might be as little as possible, when the melancholy
  3701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevent takes place--which, however, as I have already said, may not
  3702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe for several years. This has been my motive, my fair cousin, and
  3703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI flatter myself it will not sink me in your esteem. And now nothing
  3704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremains for me but to assure you in the most animated language of the
  3705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tviolence of my affection. To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and

  3707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds

  3709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdecease, is all that you may ever be entitled to. On that head,
  3710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore, I shall be uniformly silent; and you may assure yourself that
  3711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno ungenerous reproach shall ever pass my lips when we are married.”
  3712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was absolutely necessary to interrupt him now.
  3714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are too hasty, sir,” she cried. “You forget that I have made no
  3716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswer. Let me do it without further loss of time. Accept my thanks for

  3718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour proposals, but it is impossible for me to do otherwise than to
  3719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdecline them.”

  3721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the
  3722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the
  3723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tman whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their
  3724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second, or even a
  3725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthird time. I am therefore by no means discouraged by what you have just
  3726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid, and shall hope to lead you to the altar ere long.”
  3727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  3729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textraordinary one after my declaration. I do assure you that I am not
  3730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone of those young ladies (if such young ladies there are) who are so
  3731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second
  3732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime. I am perfectly serious in my refusal. You could not make _me_
  3733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who
  3734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould make you so. Nay, were your friend Lady Catherine to know me, I
  3735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the
  3736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsituation.”
  3737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Were it certain that Lady Catherine would think so,” said Mr. Collins
  3739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery gravely--“but I cannot imagine that her ladyship would at all
  3740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisapprove of you. And you may be certain when I have the honour of
  3741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeing her again, I shall speak in the very highest terms of your
  3742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmodesty, economy, and other amiable qualification.”
  3743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, Mr. Collins, all praise of me will be unnecessary. You
  3745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust give me leave to judge for myself, and pay me the compliment
  3746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof believing what I say. I wish you very happy and very rich, and by
  3747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefusing your hand, do all in my power to prevent your being otherwise.
  3748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn making me the offer, you must have satisfied the delicacy of your
  3749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings with regard to my family, and may take possession of Longbourn
  3750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testate whenever it falls, without any self-reproach. This matter may
  3751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe considered, therefore, as finally settled.” And rising as she
  3752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthus spoke, she would have quitted the room, had Mr. Collins not thus
  3753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddressed her:
  3754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I
  3756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given
  3757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I
  3758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on
  3759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe first application, and perhaps you have even now said as much to
  3760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the
  3761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfemale character.”
  3762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Really, Mr. Collins,” cried Elizabeth with some warmth, “you puzzle me
  3764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texceedingly. If what I have hitherto said can appear to you in the form
  3765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof encouragement, I know not how to express my refusal in such a way as
  3766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto convince you of its being one.”
  3767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your
  3769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefusal of my addresses is merely words of course. My reasons for
  3770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelieving it are briefly these: It does not appear to me that my hand is
  3771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunworthy of your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would
  3772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections
  3773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the family of de Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are
  3774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further

  3777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tportion is unhappily so small that it will in all likelihood undo
  3778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must

  3781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”

  3783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do assure you, sir, that I have no pretensions whatever to that kind

  3786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain and again for the honour you have done me in your proposals, but
  3787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto accept them is absolutely impossible. My feelings in every respect
  3788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforbid it. Can I speak plainer? Do not consider me now as an elegant
  3789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfemale, intending to plague you, but as a rational creature, speaking
  3790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe truth from her heart.”
  3791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward
  3793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgallantry; “and I am persuaded that when sanctioned by the express

  3795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing acceptable.”

  3797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elizabeth would make
