  3799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the persisted in considering her repeated refusals as flattering
  3800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencouragement, to apply to her father, whose negative might be uttered
  3801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin such a manner as to be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could
  3802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female.
  3803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 20
  3807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of his
  3810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuccessful love; for Mrs. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule
  3811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elizabeth open
  3812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe door and with quick step pass her towards the staircase, than she
  3813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and herself in
  3814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twarm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection. Mr. Collins
  3815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then
  3816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result
  3817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the
  3818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow
  3819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom her bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of her character.
  3820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis information, however, startled Mrs. Bennet; she would have been
  3822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad to be equally satisfied that her daughter had meant to encourage
  3823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim by protesting against his proposals, but she dared not believe it,
  3824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand could not help saying so.
  3825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But, depend upon it, Mr. Collins,” she added, “that Lizzy shall be
  3827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrought to reason. I will speak to her about it directly. She is a very
  3828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theadstrong, foolish girl, and does not know her own interest but I will
  3829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_make_ her know it.”
  3830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pardon me for interrupting you, madam,” cried Mr. Collins; “but if
  3832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether she would
  3833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taltogether be a very desirable wife to a man in my situation, who
  3834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnaturally looks for happiness in the marriage state. If therefore she
  3835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not
  3836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto force her into accepting me, because if liable to such defects of
  3837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemper, she could not contribute much to my felicity.”
  3838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said Mrs. Bennet, alarmed. “Lizzy is
  3840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly headstrong in such matters as these. In everything else she is as
  3841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-natured a girl as ever lived. I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and
  3842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.”
  3843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her
  3845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thusband, called out as she entered the library, “Oh! Mr. Bennet, you
  3846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare wanted immediately; we are all in an uproar. You must come and make
  3847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy marry Mr. Collins, for she vows she will not have him, and if you
  3848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo not make haste he will change his mind and not have _her_.”
  3849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet raised his eyes from his book as she entered, and fixed them
  3851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton her face with a calm unconcern which was not in the least altered by
  3852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther communication.
  3853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when she had
  3855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinished her speech. “Of what are you talking?”
  3856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Of Mr. Collins and Lizzy. Lizzy declares she will not have Mr. Collins,
  3858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Mr. Collins begins to say that he will not have Lizzy.”
  3859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And what am I to do on the occasion? It seems an hopeless business.”
  3861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Speak to Lizzy about it yourself. Tell her that you insist upon her
  3863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarrying him.”
  3864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let her be called down. She shall hear my opinion.”
  3866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the
  3868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlibrary.
  3869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Come here, child,” cried her father as she appeared. “I have sent for
  3871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou on an affair of importance. I understand that Mr. Collins has made
  3872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou an offer of marriage. Is it true?” Elizabeth replied that it was.
  3873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very well--and this offer of marriage you have refused?”
  3874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have, sir.”
  3876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very well. We now come to the point. Your mother insists upon your
  3878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepting it. Is it not so, Mrs. Bennet?”
  3879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, or I will never see her again.”
  3881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth. From this day you must
  3883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe a stranger to one of your parents. Your mother will never see you
  3884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain if you do _not_ marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again
  3885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif you _do_.”
  3886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning,
  3888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut Mrs. Bennet, who had persuaded herself that her husband regarded the

  3890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What do you mean, Mr. Bennet, in talking this way? You promised me to
  3892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_insist_ upon her marrying him.”
  3893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear,” replied her husband, “I have two small favours to request.
  3895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFirst, that you will allow me the free use of my understanding on the
  3896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent occasion; and secondly, of my room. I shall be glad to have the
  3897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlibrary to myself as soon as may be.”
  3898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNot yet, however, in spite of her disappointment in her husband, did
  3900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet give up the point. She talked to Elizabeth again and again;
  3901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoaxed and threatened her by turns. She endeavoured to secure Jane
  3902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her interest; but Jane, with all possible mildness, declined
  3903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterfering; and Elizabeth, sometimes with real earnestness, and
  3904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes with playful gaiety, replied to her attacks. Though her manner
  3905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvaried, however, her determination never did.
  3906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins, meanwhile, was meditating in solitude on what had passed.
  3908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe thought too well of himself to comprehend on what motives his cousin
  3909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould refuse him; and though his pride was hurt, he suffered in no other
  3910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway. His regard for her was quite imaginary; and the possibility of her
  3911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeserving her mother’s reproach prevented his feeling any regret.
  3912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhile the family were in this confusion, Charlotte Lucas came to spend
  3914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe day with them. She was met in the vestibule by Lydia, who, flying to
  3915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such
  3916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfun here! What do you think has happened this morning? Mr. Collins has
  3917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade an offer to Lizzy, and she will not have him.”
  3918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte hardly had time to answer, before they were joined by Kitty,
  3920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the
  3921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbreakfast-room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, than she likewise began on
  3922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe subject, calling on Miss Lucas for her compassion, and entreating
  3923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of all her
  3924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily. “Pray do, my dear Miss Lucas,” she added in a melancholy tone,
  3925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me. I am cruelly used,
  3926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnobody feels for my poor nerves.”
  3927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte’s reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth.
  3929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye, there she comes,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “looking as unconcerned
  3931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided
  3932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe can have her own way. But I tell you, Miss Lizzy--if you take it
  3933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way,
  3934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou will never get a husband at all--and I am sure I do not know who is
  3935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto maintain you when your father is dead. I shall not be able to keep
  3936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou--and so I warn you. I have done with you from this very day. I told
  3937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou in the library, you know, that I should never speak to you again,
  3938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand you will find me as good as my word. I have no pleasure in talking
  3939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto undutiful children. Not that I have much pleasure, indeed, in talking
  3940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto anybody. People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have
  3941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno great inclination for talking. Nobody can tell what I suffer! But it
  3942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis always so. Those who do not complain are never pitied.”
  3943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer daughters listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that
  3945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany attempt to reason with her or soothe her would only increase the
  3946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tirritation. She talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of
  3947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, till they were joined by Mr. Collins, who entered the room with
  3948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, she said to
  3949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe girls, “Now, I do insist upon it, that you, all of you, hold
  3950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour tongues, and let me and Mr. Collins have a little conversation
  3951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether.”
  3952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth passed quietly out of the room, Jane and Kitty followed, but
  3954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia stood her ground, determined to hear all she could; and Charlotte,
  3955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetained first by the civility of Mr. Collins, whose inquiries after
  3956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself and all her family were very minute, and then by a little
  3957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcuriosity, satisfied herself with walking to the window and pretending
  3958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot to hear. In a doleful voice Mrs. Bennet began the projected
  3959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation: “Oh! Mr. Collins!”
  3960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear madam,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point.
  3962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFar be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his
  3963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdispleasure, “to resent the behaviour of your daughter. Resignation
  3964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto inevitable evils is the duty of us all; the peculiar duty of a
  3965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoung man who has been so fortunate as I have been in early preferment;
  3966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand I trust I am resigned. Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt
  3967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand;
  3968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor I have often observed that resignation is never so perfect as
  3969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our
  3970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testimation. You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect
  3971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto your family, my dear madam, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to
  3972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour daughter’s favour, without having paid yourself and Mr. Bennet the
  3973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my
  3974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehalf. My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my
  3975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdismission from your daughter’s lips instead of your own. But we are all
  3976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliable to error. I have certainly meant well through the whole affair.
  3977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMy object has been to secure an amiable companion for myself, with due
  3978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsideration for the advantage of all your family, and if my _manner_
  3979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thas been at all reprehensible, I here beg leave to apologise.”
  3980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 21
  3984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe discussion of Mr. Collins’s offer was now nearly at an end, and
  3987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily
  3988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusions of her
  3989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother. As for the gentleman himself, _his_ feelings were chiefly
  3990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid her,
  3991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut by stiffness of manner and resentful silence. He scarcely ever spoke
  3992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her, and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of
  3993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas, whose
  3994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and
  3995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tespecially to her friend.
  3996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  3997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe morrow produced no abatement of Mrs. Bennet’s ill-humour or ill
  3998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thealth. Mr. Collins was also in the same state of angry pride. Elizabeth
  3999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did
  4000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot appear in the least affected by it. He was always to have gone on
  4001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSaturday, and to Saturday he meant to stay.
  4002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton to inquire if Mr. Wickham
  4004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball.
  4005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their
  4006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt’s where his regret and vexation, and the concern of everybody, was
  4007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell talked over. To Elizabeth, however, he voluntarily acknowledged
  4008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the necessity of his absence _had_ been self-imposed.
  4009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I found,” said he, “as the time drew near that I had better not meet
  4011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy; that to be in the same room, the same party with him for so
  4012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes
  4013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight arise unpleasant to more than myself.”
  4014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe highly approved his forbearance, and they had leisure for a full
  4016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscussion of it, and for all the commendation which they civilly
  4017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with
  4018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to
  4019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther. His accompanying them was a double advantage; she felt all the
  4020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliment it offered to herself, and it was most acceptable as an
  4021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion of introducing him to her father and mother.
  4022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSoon after their return, a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet; it came
  4024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Netherfield. The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little,
  4025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thot-pressed paper, well covered with a lady’s fair, flowing hand; and
  4026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth saw her sister’s countenance change as she read it, and saw
  4027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther dwelling intently on some particular passages. Jane recollected
  4028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself soon, and putting the letter away, tried to join with her usual
  4029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcheerfulness in the general conversation; but Elizabeth felt an anxiety
  4030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the subject which drew off her attention even from Wickham; and no
  4031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from Jane
  4032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvited her to follow her up stairs. When they had gained their own room,
  4033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, taking out the letter, said:
  4034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is from Caroline Bingley; what it contains has surprised me a good
  4036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeal. The whole party have left Netherfield by this time, and are on
  4037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir way to town--and without any intention of coming back again. You
  4038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall hear what she says.”
  4039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information
  4041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly,
  4042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand of their meaning to dine in Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a
  4043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse. The next was in these words: “I do not pretend to regret anything
  4044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI shall leave in Hertfordshire, except your society, my dearest friend;
  4045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut we will hope, at some future period, to enjoy many returns of that
  4046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelightful intercourse we have known, and in the meanwhile may
  4047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved
  4048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcorrespondence. I depend on you for that.” To these highflown
  4049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust;
  4050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand though the suddenness of their removal surprised her, she saw
  4051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing in it really to lament; it was not to be supposed that their
  4052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley’s being there; and as
  4053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the loss of their society, she was persuaded that Jane must cease to
  4054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard it, in the enjoyment of his.
  4055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be
  4057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\table to see your friends before they leave the country. But may we not
  4058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thope that the period of future happiness to which Miss Bingley looks
  4059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforward may arrive earlier than she is aware, and that the delightful
  4060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater
  4061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction as sisters? Mr. Bingley will not be detained in London by
  4062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.”
  4063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Caroline decidedly says that none of the party will return into
  4065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire this winter. I will read it to you:”
  4066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which
  4068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we
  4069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when
  4070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have
  4071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend
  4072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this vacant hours in a comfortless hotel. Many of my acquaintances are
  4073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talready there for the winter; I wish that I could hear that you, my
  4074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdearest friend, had any intention of making one of the crowd--but of
  4075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I despair. I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may
  4076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your
  4077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the
  4078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthree of whom we shall deprive you.”
  4079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is evident by this,” added Jane, “that he comes back no more this
  4081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twinter.”
  4082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is only evident that Miss Bingley does not mean that he _should_.”
  4084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why will you think so? It must be his own doing. He is his own
  4086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster. But you do not know _all_. I _will_ read you the passage which
  4087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticularly hurts me. I will have no reserves from _you_.”
  4088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy is impatient to see his sister; and, to confess the truth,
  4090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_we_ are scarcely less eager to meet her again. I really do not think
  4091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGeorgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments;
  4092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the affection she inspires in Louisa and myself is heightened into
  4093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomething still more interesting, from the hope we dare entertain of
  4094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther being hereafter our sister. I do not know whether I ever before
  4095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned to you my feelings on this subject; but I will not leave the
  4096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountry without confiding them, and I trust you will not esteem them
  4097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunreasonable. My brother admires her greatly already; he will have
  4098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequent opportunity now of seeing her on the most intimate footing;
  4099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a sister’s
  4100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most
  4101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcapable of engaging any woman’s heart. With all these circumstances to
  4102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest
  4103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness
  4104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof so many?”
  4105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What do you think of _this_ sentence, my dear Lizzy?” said Jane as she
  4107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinished it. “Is it not clear enough? Does it not expressly declare that
  4108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCaroline neither expects nor wishes me to be her sister; that she is
  4109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperfectly convinced of her brother’s indifference; and that if she
  4110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuspects the nature of my feelings for him, she means (most kindly!) to
  4111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tput me on my guard? Can there be any other opinion on the subject?”
  4112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, there can; for mine is totally different. Will you hear it?”
  4114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Most willingly.”
  4116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You shall have it in a few words. Miss Bingley sees that her brother is
  4118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin love with you, and wants him to marry Miss Darcy. She follows him
  4119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto town in hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he
  4120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoes not care about you.”
  4121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane shook her head.
  4123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, Jane, you ought to believe me. No one who has ever seen you
  4125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether can doubt his affection. Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot. She
  4126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis not such a simpleton. Could she have seen half as much love in Mr.
  4127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy for herself, she would have ordered her wedding clothes. But the
  4128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcase is this: We are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and she
  4129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis the more anxious to get Miss Darcy for her brother, from the notion
  4130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat when there has been _one_ intermarriage, she may have less trouble
  4131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and
  4132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI dare say it would succeed, if Miss de Bourgh were out of the way. But,
  4133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that because Miss Bingley
  4134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest
  4135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdegree less sensible of _your_ merit than when he took leave of you on
  4136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTuesday, or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead
  4137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.”
  4138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your
  4140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepresentation of all this might make me quite easy. But I know the
  4141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfoundation is unjust. Caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving
  4142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanyone; and all that I can hope in this case is that she is deceiving
  4143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself.”
  4144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is right. You could not have started a more happy idea, since you
  4146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill not take comfort in mine. Believe her to be deceived, by all means.
  4147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYou have now done your duty by her, and must fret no longer.”
  4148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But, my dear sister, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in
  4150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry
  4151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telsewhere?”
  4152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You must decide for yourself,” said Elizabeth; “and if, upon mature
  4154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two sisters is
  4155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you by
  4156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall means to refuse him.”
  4157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How can you talk so?” said Jane, faintly smiling. “You must know that
  4159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could
  4160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot hesitate.”
  4161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I did not think you would; and that being the case, I cannot consider
  4163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour situation with much compassion.”
  4164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But if he returns no more this winter, my choice will never be
  4166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trequired. A thousand things may arise in six months!”
  4167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe idea of his returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost
  4169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontempt. It appeared to her merely the suggestion of Caroline’s
  4170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterested wishes, and she could not for a moment suppose that those
  4171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man
  4172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso totally independent of everyone.
  4173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe represented to her sister as forcibly as possible what she felt
  4175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect.
  4176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane’s temper was not desponding, and she was gradually led to hope,
  4177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that
  4178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley would return to Netherfield and answer every wish of her heart.
  4179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey agreed that Mrs. Bennet should only hear of the departure of the
  4181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman’s conduct;
  4182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut even this partial communication gave her a great deal of concern,
  4183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the ladies should happen
  4184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto go away just as they were all getting so intimate together. After
  4185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlamenting it, however, at some length, she had the consolation that Mr.
  4186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley would be soon down again and soon dining at Longbourn, and the
  4187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that though he had
  4188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen invited only to a family dinner, she would take care to have two
  4189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfull courses.
  4190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 22
  4194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases and again during the
  4197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchief of the day was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to Mr. Collins.
  4198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth took an opportunity of thanking her. “It keeps him in good
  4199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour,” said she, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”
  4200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t Charlotte assured her friend of her satisfaction in being useful, and
  4201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat it amply repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time. This was
  4202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery amiable, but Charlotte’s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth
  4203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad any conception of; its object was nothing else than to secure her
  4204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom any return of Mr. Collins’s addresses, by engaging them towards
  4205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself. Such was Miss Lucas’s scheme; and appearances were so
  4206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourable, that when they parted at night, she would have felt almost
  4207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very
  4208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon. But here she did injustice to the fire and independence of his
  4209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter, for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next
  4210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw
  4211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself at her feet. He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins,
  4212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom a conviction that if they saw him depart, they could not fail to
  4213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known
  4214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill its success might be known likewise; for though feeling almost
  4215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecure, and with reason, for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging,
  4216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday.
  4217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis reception, however, was of the most flattering kind. Miss Lucas
  4218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and
  4219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane. But little had
  4220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited her there.
  4221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn as short a time as Mr. Collins’s long speeches would allow,
  4223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as
  4224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey entered the house he earnestly entreated her to name the day that
  4225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must
  4226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe waived for the present, the lady felt no inclination to trifle with
  4227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this happiness. The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must
  4228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tguard his courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its
  4229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinuance; and Miss Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure
  4230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that
  4231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testablishment were gained.
  4232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSir William and Lady Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent;
  4234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity. Mr. Collins’s present
  4235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances made it a most eligible match for their daughter, to whom
  4236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were
  4237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texceedingly fair. Lady Lucas began directly to calculate, with more
  4238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest than the matter had ever excited before, how many years longer
  4239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet was likely to live; and Sir William gave it as his decided
  4240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion, that whenever Mr. Collins should be in possession of the
  4241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his wife
  4242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould make their appearance at St. James’s. The whole family, in short,
  4243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere properly overjoyed on the occasion. The younger girls formed hopes
  4244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof _coming out_ a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have
  4245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charlotte’s
  4246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdying an old maid. Charlotte herself was tolerably composed. She had
  4247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgained her point, and had time to consider of it. Her reflections were
  4248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin general satisfactory. Mr. Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible
  4249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnor agreeable; his society was irksome, and his attachment to her must
  4250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe imaginary. But still he would be her husband. Without thinking highly
  4251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teither of men or matrimony, marriage had always been her object; it was
  4252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe only provision for well-educated young women of small fortune,
  4253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest
  4254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreservative from want. This preservative she had now obtained; and at
  4255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, she felt all
  4256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe good luck of it. The least agreeable circumstance in the business
  4257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas the surprise it must occasion to Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship
  4258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe valued beyond that of any other person. Elizabeth would wonder,
  4259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand probably would blame her; and though her resolution was not to be
  4260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshaken, her feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation. She resolved
  4261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto give her the information herself, and therefore charged Mr. Collins,
  4262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had
  4263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpassed before any of the family. A promise of secrecy was of course very
  4264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdutifully given, but it could not be kept without difficulty; for the
  4265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcuriosity excited by his long absence burst forth in such very direct
  4266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquestions on his return as required some ingenuity to evade, and he was
  4267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat the same time exercising great self-denial, for he was longing to
  4268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpublish his prosperous love.
  4269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the
  4271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the ladies moved
  4272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the night; and Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality,
  4273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever
  4274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this engagements might allow him to visit them.
  4275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear madam,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly
  4277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and
  4278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as
  4279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossible.”
  4280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were all astonished; and Mr. Bennet, who could by no means wish for
  4282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso speedy a return, immediately said:
  4283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But is there not danger of Lady Catherine’s disapprobation here, my
  4285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood sir? You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of
  4286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffending your patroness.”
  4287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear sir,” replied Mr. Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you
  4289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so
  4290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaterial a step without her ladyship’s concurrence.”
  4291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You cannot be too much upon your guard. Risk anything rather than her
  4293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdispleasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us
  4294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home,
  4295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand be satisfied that _we_ shall take no offence.”
  4296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude is warmly excited by such
  4298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffectionate attention; and depend upon it, you will speedily receive
  4299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom me a letter of thanks for this, and for every other mark of your
  4300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard during my stay in Hertfordshire. As for my fair cousins, though
  4301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now
  4302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my
  4303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin Elizabeth.”
  4304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith proper civilities the ladies then withdrew; all of them equally
  4306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprised that he meditated a quick return. Mrs. Bennet wished to
  4307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of her
  4308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger girls, and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept him.
  4309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe rated his abilities much higher than any of the others; there was
  4310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta solidity in his reflections which often struck her, and though by no
  4311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeans so clever as herself, she thought that if encouraged to read
  4312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand improve himself by such an example as hers, he might become a very
  4313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable companion. But on the following morning, every hope of this
  4314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkind was done away. Miss Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a
  4315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprivate conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before.
  4316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe possibility of Mr. Collins’s fancying himself in love with her
  4318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two; but
  4319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Charlotte could encourage him seemed almost as far from
  4320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossibility as she could encourage him herself, and her astonishment was
  4321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and
  4322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could not help crying out:
  4323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Engaged to Mr. Collins! My dear Charlotte--impossible!”
  4325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her
  4327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstory, gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a
  4328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treproach; though, as it was no more than she expected, she soon regained
  4329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther composure, and calmly replied:
  4330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why should you be surprised, my dear Eliza? Do you think it incredible
  4332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Collins should be able to procure any woman’s good opinion,
  4333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecause he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”
  4334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Elizabeth had now recollected herself, and making a strong effort
  4336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor it, was able to assure with tolerable firmness that the prospect of
  4337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she wished her
  4338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall imaginable happiness.
  4339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte. “You must be surprised,
  4341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery much surprised--so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry
  4342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou. But when you have had time to think it over, I hope you will be
  4343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfied with what I have done. I am not romantic, you know; I never
  4344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas. I ask only a comfortable home; and considering Mr. Collins’s
  4345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter, connection, and situation in life, I am convinced that my
  4346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can boast on
  4347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentering the marriage state.”
  4348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth quietly answered “Undoubtedly;” and after an awkward pause,
  4350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey returned to the rest of the family. Charlotte did not stay much
  4351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger, and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard.
  4352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so
  4353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunsuitable a match. The strangeness of Mr. Collins’s making two offers
  4354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of his being now
  4355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepted. She had always felt that Charlotte’s opinion of matrimony was
  4356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot exactly like her own, but she had not supposed it to be possible
  4357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better
  4358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling to worldly advantage. Charlotte the wife of Mr. Collins was a
  4359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost humiliating picture! And to the pang of a friend disgracing herself
  4360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it
  4361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot she had
  4362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchosen.
  4363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 23
  4367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what
  4370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had heard, and doubting whether she was authorised to mention
  4371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter, to
  4372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tannounce her engagement to the family. With many compliments to them,
  4373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the
  4374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouses, he unfolded the matter--to an audience not merely wondering, but
  4375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness,
  4376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprotested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and
  4377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften uncivil, boisterously exclaimed:
  4378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good Lord! Sir William, how can you tell such a story? Do not you know
  4380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
  4381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne
  4383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout anger such treatment; but Sir William’s good breeding carried
  4384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the
  4385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttruth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the
  4386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost forbearing courtesy.
  4387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant
  4389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by
  4390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and
  4391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tendeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters
  4392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she
  4393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the
  4394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character
  4395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.
  4396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was in fact too much overpowered to say a great deal while
  4398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings
  4399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound a rapid vent. In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving
  4400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins
  4401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be
  4402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappy together; and fourthly, that the match might be broken off. Two
  4403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that
  4404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was the real cause of the mischief; and the other that she
  4405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself had been barbarously misused by them all; and on these two
  4406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoints she principally dwelt during the rest of the day. Nothing could
  4407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsole and nothing could appease her. Nor did that day wear out her
  4408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresentment. A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without
  4409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscolding her, a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William
  4410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor Lady Lucas without being rude, and many months were gone before she
  4411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould at all forgive their daughter.
  4412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such
  4414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for
  4415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had
  4416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and
  4417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore foolish than his daughter!
  4418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane confessed herself a little surprised at the match; but she said
  4420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness;
  4421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable. Kitty
  4422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a
  4423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news
  4424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto spread at Meryton.
  4425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort
  4427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she
  4428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalled at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was,
  4429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough Mrs. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been
  4430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to drive happiness away.
  4431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBetween Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them
  4433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that
  4434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno real confidence could ever subsist between them again. Her
  4435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her
  4436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could
  4437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious,
  4438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas Bingley had now been gone a week and nothing more was heard of his
  4439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturn.
  4440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting
  4442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe days till she might reasonably hope to hear again. The promised
  4443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter of thanks from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to
  4444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir father, and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a
  4445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwelvemonth’s abode in the family might have prompted. After discharging
  4446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many
  4447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection
  4448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was
  4449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmerely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready
  4450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither
  4451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine,
  4452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take
  4453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplace as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable
  4454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\targument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him
  4455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe happiest of men.
  4456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of
  4458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure to Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she was as much disposed to
  4459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplain of it as her husband. It was very strange that he should come
  4460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge; it was also very inconvenient
  4461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand exceedingly troublesome. She hated having visitors in the house
  4462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the
  4463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost disagreeable. Such were the gentle murmurs of Mrs. Bennet, and
  4464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley’s continued
  4465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsence.
  4466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNeither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject. Day after
  4468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the
  4469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treport which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to
  4470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs.
  4471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous
  4472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfalsehood.
  4473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEven Elizabeth began to fear--not that Bingley was indifferent--but that
  4475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this sisters would be successful in keeping him away. Unwilling as
  4476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe was to admit an idea so destructive of Jane’s happiness, and so
  4477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdishonorable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its
  4478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently occurring. The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters
  4479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss
  4480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy and the amusements of London might be too much, she feared, for
  4481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe strength of his attachment.
  4482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs for Jane, _her_ anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more
  4484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpainful than Elizabeth’s, but whatever she felt she was desirous of
  4485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcealing, and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject
  4486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas never alluded to. But as no such delicacy restrained her mother,
  4487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her
  4488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he
  4489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not come back she would think herself very ill used. It needed
  4490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable
  4491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttranquillity.
  4492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins returned most punctually on Monday fortnight, but his
  4494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his
  4495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst introduction. He was too happy, however, to need much attention;
  4496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand luckily for the others, the business of love-making relieved them
  4497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom a great deal of his company. The chief of every day was spent by
  4498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim at Lucas Lodge, and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time
  4499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed.
  4500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state. The very mention of
  4502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour,
  4503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of. The sight
  4504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Miss Lucas was odious to her. As her successor in that house, she
  4505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregarded her with jealous abhorrence. Whenever Charlotte came to see
  4506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and
  4507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that
  4508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself
  4509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her daughters out of the house, as soon as Mr. Bennet were dead. She
  4510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplained bitterly of all this to her husband.
  4511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte
  4513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLucas should ever be mistress of this house, that I should be forced to
  4514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake way for _her_, and live to see her take her place in it!”
  4515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear, do not give way to such gloomy thoughts. Let us hope for
  4517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter things. Let us flatter ourselves that I may be the survivor.”
  4518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet, and therefore, instead of
  4520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaking any answer, she went on as before.
  4521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot bear to think that they should have all this estate. If it was
  4523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot for the entail, I should not mind it.”
  4524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What should not you mind?”
  4526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should not mind anything at all.”
  4528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such
  4530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinsensibility.”
  4531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never can be thankful, Mr. Bennet, for anything about the entail. How
  4533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own
  4534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughters, I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins too!
  4535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhy should _he_ have it more than anybody else?”
  4536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I leave it to yourself to determine,” said Mr. Bennet.
  4538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 24
  4542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley’s letter arrived, and put an end to doubt. The very first
  4545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for
  4546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe winter, and concluded with her brother’s regret at not having had
  4547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left
  4548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe country.
  4549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest
  4551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the
  4552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twriter, that could give her any comfort. Miss Darcy’s praise occupied
  4553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe chief of it. Her many attractions were again dwelt on, and Caroline
  4554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict
  4555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former
  4556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter. She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an
  4557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of
  4558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe latter with regard to new furniture.
  4559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this,
  4561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard it in silent indignation. Her heart was divided between concern
  4562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her sister, and resentment against all others. To Caroline’s
  4563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassertion of her brother’s being partial to Miss Darcy she paid no
  4564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcredit. That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she
  4565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she
  4566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness
  4567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave
  4568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice of his own happiness
  4569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the caprice of their inclination. Had his own happiness, however,
  4570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in
  4571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhatever manner he thought best, but her sister’s was involved in it, as
  4572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe thought he must be sensible himself. It was a subject, in short,
  4573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton which reflection would be long indulged, and must be unavailing. She
  4574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould think of nothing else; and yet whether Bingley’s regard had really
  4575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdied away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether
  4576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the had been aware of Jane’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his
  4577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobservation; whatever were the case, though her opinion of him must be
  4578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaterially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained
  4579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe same, her peace equally wounded.
  4580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tA day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to
  4582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth; but at last, on Mrs. Bennet’s leaving them together, after a
  4583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could
  4584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot help saying:
  4585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, that my dear mother had more command over herself! She can have no
  4587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him. But
  4588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI will not repine. It cannot last long. He will be forgot, and we shall
  4589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall be as we were before.”
  4590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said
  4592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing.
  4593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have
  4595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno reason. He may live in my memory as the most amiable man of my
  4596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance, but that is all. I have nothing either to hope or fear,
  4597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand nothing to reproach him with. Thank God! I have not _that_ pain. A
  4598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle time, therefore--I shall certainly try to get the better.”
  4599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately,
  4601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it
  4602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thas done no harm to anyone but myself.”
  4603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Jane!” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good. Your sweetness
  4605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand disinterestedness are really angelic; I do not know what to say
  4606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto you. I feel as if I had never done you justice, or loved you as you
  4607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeserve.”
  4608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back
  4610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe praise on her sister’s warm affection.
  4611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair. _You_ wish to think all the
  4613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. I only want
  4614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto think _you_ perfect, and you set yourself against it. Do not
  4615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe afraid of my running into any excess, of my encroaching on your
  4616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprivilege of universal good-will. You need not. There are few people
  4617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhom I really love, and still fewer of whom I think well. The more I see
  4618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the world, the more am I dissatisfied with it; and every day confirms
  4619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy belief of the inconsistency of all human characters, and of the
  4620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle dependence that can be placed on the appearance of merit or
  4621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsense. I have met with two instances lately, one I will not mention; the
  4622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother is Charlotte’s marriage. It is unaccountable! In every view it is
  4623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunaccountable!”
  4624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
