  4625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these. They will
  4626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\truin your happiness. You do not make allowance enough for difference
  4627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof situation and temper. Consider Mr. Collins’s respectability, and
  4628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte’s steady, prudent character. Remember that she is one of a
  4629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlarge family; that as to fortune, it is a most eligible match; and be
  4630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that she may feel something like
  4631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard and esteem for our cousin.”
  4632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else
  4634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that
  4635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her
  4636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding than I now do of her heart. My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a
  4637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man; you know he is, as well as
  4638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who married him
  4639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot have a proper way of thinking. You shall not defend her, though
  4640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is Charlotte Lucas. You shall not, for the sake of one individual,
  4641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchange the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade
  4642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of
  4643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdanger security for happiness.”
  4644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied
  4646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it by seeing them happy
  4647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether. But enough of this. You alluded to something else. You
  4648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned _two_ instances. I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat
  4649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking _that person_ to blame, and
  4650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaying your opinion of him is sunk. We must not be so ready to fancy
  4651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tourselves intentionally injured. We must not expect a lively young man
  4652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be always so guarded and circumspect. It is very often nothing but
  4653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tour own vanity that deceives us. Women fancy admiration means more than
  4654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit does.”
  4655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And men take care that they should.”
  4657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If it is designedly done, they cannot be justified; but I have no idea
  4659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine.”
  4660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley’s conduct to design,”
  4662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t said Elizabeth; “but without scheming to do wrong, or to make others
  4663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunhappy, there may be error, and there may be misery. Thoughtlessness,
  4664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twant of attention to other people’s feelings, and want of resolution,
  4665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill do the business.”
  4666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And do you impute it to either of those?”
  4668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; to the last. But if I go on, I shall displease you by saying what
  4670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI think of persons you esteem. Stop me whilst you can.”
  4671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”
  4673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, in conjunction with his friend.”
  4675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot believe it. Why should they try to influence him? They can
  4677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me, no other woman can
  4678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecure it.”
  4679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your first position is false. They may wish many things besides his
  4681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiness; they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they
  4682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great
  4683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnections, and pride.”
  4684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Beyond a doubt, they _do_ wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane;
  4686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing. They have
  4687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknown her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love
  4688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther better. But, whatever may be their own wishes, it is very unlikely
  4689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey should have opposed their brother’s. What sister would think
  4690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very
  4691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjectionable? If they believed him attached to me, they would not try
  4692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto part us; if he were so, they could not succeed. By supposing such an
  4693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection, you make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong, and me most
  4694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunhappy. Do not distress me by the idea. I am not ashamed of having been
  4695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistaken--or, at least, it is light, it is nothing in comparison of what
  4696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters. Let me take it in
  4697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe best light, in the light in which it may be understood.”
  4698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s
  4700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tname was scarcely ever mentioned between them.
  4701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no
  4703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore, and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account
  4704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor it clearly, there was little chance of her ever considering it with
  4705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless perplexity. Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she
  4706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the
  4707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teffect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her
  4708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at
  4709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe time, she had the same story to repeat every day. Mrs. Bennet’s best
  4710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomfort was that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.
  4711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Lizzy,” said he one day,
  4713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“your sister is crossed in love, I find. I congratulate her. Next to
  4714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing married, a girl likes to be crossed a little in love now and then.
  4715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt is something to think of, and it gives her a sort of distinction
  4716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamong her companions. When is your turn to come? You will hardly bear to
  4717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe long outdone by Jane. Now is your time. Here are officers enough in
  4718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country. Let Wickham
  4719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe _your_ man. He is a pleasant fellow, and would jilt you creditably.”
  4720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not
  4722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall expect Jane’s good fortune.”
  4723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“True,” said Mr. Bennet, “but it is a comfort to think that whatever of
  4725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will make
  4726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe most of it.”
  4727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham’s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom
  4729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn
  4730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily. They saw him often, and to his other recommendations was now
  4731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadded that of general unreserve. The whole of what Elizabeth had already
  4732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard, his claims on Mr. Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him,
  4733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was
  4734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleased to know how much they had always disliked Mr. Darcy before they
  4735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad known anything of the matter.
  4736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be
  4738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany extenuating circumstances in the case, unknown to the society
  4739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Hertfordshire; her mild and steady candour always pleaded for
  4740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tallowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes--but by everybody else
  4741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.
  4742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 25
  4746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity,
  4749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of
  4750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSaturday. The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his
  4751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside, by preparations for the reception of his bride; as he had reason
  4752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto hope, that shortly after his return into Hertfordshire, the day would
  4753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe fixed that was to make him the happiest of men. He took leave of his
  4754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelations at Longbourn with as much solemnity as before; wished his fair
  4755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousins health and happiness again, and promised their father another
  4756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter of thanks.
  4757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving
  4759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther brother and his wife, who came as usual to spend the Christmas
  4760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly
  4761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuperior to his sister, as well by nature as education. The Netherfield
  4762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived
  4763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so
  4764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell-bred and agreeable. Mrs. Gardiner, who was several years younger
  4765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Phillips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant
  4766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twoman, and a great favourite with all her Longbourn nieces. Between the
  4767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a particular regard.
  4768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey had frequently been staying with her in town.
  4769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe first part of Mrs. Gardiner’s business on her arrival was to
  4771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistribute her presents and describe the newest fashions. When this was
  4772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone she had a less active part to play. It became her turn to listen.
  4773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of. They
  4774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister. Two of her
  4775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgirls had been upon the point of marriage, and after all there was
  4776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing in it.
  4777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr.
  4779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley if she could. But Lizzy! Oh, sister! It is very hard to think
  4780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she might have been Mr. Collins’s wife by this time, had it not
  4781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen for her own perverseness. He made her an offer in this very room,
  4782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she refused him. The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have
  4783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta daughter married before I have, and that the Longbourn estate is just
  4784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas much entailed as ever. The Lucases are very artful people indeed,
  4785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister. They are all for what they can get. I am sorry to say it of
  4786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, but so it is. It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted
  4787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves
  4788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore anybody else. However, your coming just at this time is the
  4789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us, of
  4790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong sleeves.”
  4791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before,
  4793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her
  4794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the
  4795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation.
  4796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject. “It
  4798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I am
  4799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsorry it went off. But these things happen so often! A young man, such
  4800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl
  4801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor a few weeks, and when accident separates them, so easily forgets
  4802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, that these sort of inconsistencies are very frequent.”
  4803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth, “but it will not
  4805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo for _us_. We do not suffer by _accident_. It does not often
  4806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of
  4807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindependent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in
  4808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlove with only a few days before.”
  4809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But that expression of ‘violently in love’ is so hackneyed, so
  4811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea. It is as
  4812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften applied to feelings which arise from a half-hour’s acquaintance,
  4813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to a real, strong attachment. Pray, how _violent was_ Mr. Bingley’s
  4814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlove?”
  4815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite
  4817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her. Every time
  4818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey met, it was more decided and remarkable. At his own ball he
  4819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffended two or three young ladies, by not asking them to dance; and I
  4820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspoke to him twice myself, without receiving an answer. Could there be
  4821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfiner symptoms? Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”
  4822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes!--of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt. Poor
  4824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane! I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get
  4825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover it immediately. It had better have happened to _you_, Lizzy; you
  4826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould have laughed yourself out of it sooner. But do you think she
  4827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be prevailed upon to go back with us? Change of scene might be
  4828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof service--and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as
  4829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything.”
  4830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded
  4832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her sister’s ready acquiescence.
  4833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I hope,” added Mrs. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to
  4835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis young man will influence her. We live in so different a part of
  4836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go
  4837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout so little, that it is very improbable that they should meet at all,
  4838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunless he really comes to see her.”
  4839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And _that_ is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his
  4841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such
  4842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta part of London! My dear aunt, how could you think of it? Mr. Darcy may
  4843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperhaps have _heard_ of such a place as Gracechurch Street, but he
  4844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould hardly think a month’s ablution enough to cleanse him from its

  4846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever stirs without him.”
  4847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“So much the better. I hope they will not meet at all. But does not Jane
  4849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcorrespond with his sister? _She_ will not be able to help calling.”
  4850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”
  4852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this
  4854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoint, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being
  4855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which
  4856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconvinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely
  4857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thopeless. It was possible, and sometimes she thought it probable, that
  4858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this affection might be reanimated, and the influence of his friends
  4859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuccessfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane’s
  4860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattractions.
  4861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet accepted her aunt’s invitation with pleasure; and the
  4863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingleys were no otherwise in her thoughts at the same time, than as she
  4864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thoped by Caroline’s not living in the same house with her brother,
  4865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe might occasionally spend a morning with her, without any danger of
  4866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeing him.
  4867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Phillipses,
  4869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its
  4870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengagement. Mrs. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment
  4871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family
  4872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdinner. When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always
  4873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade part of it--of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and
  4874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth’s
  4875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twarm commendation, narrowly observed them both. Without supposing them,
  4876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference
  4877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and
  4878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left
  4879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such
  4880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan attachment.
  4881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure,
  4883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunconnected with his general powers. About ten or a dozen years ago,
  4884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very
  4885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpart of Derbyshire to which he belonged. They had, therefore, many
  4886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintances in common; and though Wickham had been little there since
  4887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe death of Darcy’s father, it was yet in his power to give her fresher
  4888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of
  4889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprocuring.
  4890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by
  4892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter perfectly well. Here consequently was an inexhaustible subject
  4893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof discourse. In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute
  4894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdescription which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of
  4895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpraise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both
  4896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim and herself. On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s
  4897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttreatment of him, she tried to remember some of that gentleman’s
  4898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treputed disposition when quite a lad which might agree with it, and
  4899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas confident at last that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam
  4900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.
  4901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 26
  4905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner’s caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given
  4908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone; after
  4909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thonestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:
  4910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because
  4912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking
  4913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topenly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve
  4914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyourself or endeavour to involve him in an affection which the want
  4915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against
  4916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_him_; he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he
  4917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is, you
  4918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all
  4919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpect you to use it. Your father would depend on _your_ resolution and
  4920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.”
  4921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
  4923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”
  4925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, then, you need not be under any alarm. I will take care of
  4927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He shall not be in love with me, if I
  4928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan prevent it.”
  4929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
  4931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I beg your pardon, I will try again. At present I am not in love with
  4933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham; no, I certainly am not. But he is, beyond all comparison,
  4934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe most agreeable man I ever saw--and if he becomes really attached to
  4935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme--I believe it will be better that he should not. I see the imprudence
  4936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof it. Oh! _that_ abominable Mr. Darcy! My father’s opinion of me does
  4937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme the greatest honour, and I should be miserable to forfeit it. My
  4938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather, however, is partial to Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I
  4939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but
  4940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsince we see every day that where there is affection, young people
  4941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare seldom withheld by immediate want of fortune from entering into
  4942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many
  4943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my fellow-creatures if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it
  4944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be wisdom to resist? All that I can promise you, therefore, is not
  4945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be in a hurry. I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his first
  4946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobject. When I am in company with him, I will not be wishing. In short,
  4947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI will do my best.”
  4948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps it will be as well if you discourage his coming here so very
  4950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften. At least, you should not _remind_ your mother of inviting him.”
  4951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth with a conscious smile: “very
  4953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrue, it will be wise in me to refrain from _that_. But do not imagine
  4954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he is always here so often. It is on your account that he has been
  4955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso frequently invited this week. You know my mother’s ideas as to the
  4956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessity of constant company for her friends. But really, and upon my
  4957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thonour, I will try to do what I think to be the wisest; and now I hope
  4958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou are satisfied.”
  4959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer aunt assured her that she was, and Elizabeth having thanked her for
  4961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe kindness of her hints, they parted; a wonderful instance of advice
  4962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing given on such a point, without being resented.
  4963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted
  4965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby the Gardiners and Jane; but as he took up his abode with the Lucases,
  4966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet. His marriage was
  4967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnow fast approaching, and she was at length so far resigned as to think
  4968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that
  4969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe “_wished_ they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding day,
  4970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she
  4971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother’s ungracious and
  4972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her
  4973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout of the room. As they went downstairs together, Charlotte said:
  4974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”
  4976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_That_ you certainly shall.”
  4978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And I have another favour to ask you. Will you come and see me?”
  4980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We shall often meet, I hope, in Hertfordshire.”
  4982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not likely to leave Kent for some time. Promise me, therefore, to
  4984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome to Hunsford.”
  4985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the
  4987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit.
  4988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My father and Maria are coming to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I
  4990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thope you will consent to be of the party. Indeed, Eliza, you will be as
  4991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twelcome as either of them.”
  4992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  4993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe wedding took place; the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from
  4994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe church door, and everybody had as much to say, or to hear, on
  4995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe subject as usual. Elizabeth soon heard from her friend; and their
  4996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcorrespondence was as regular and frequent as it had ever been; that
  4997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit should be equally unreserved was impossible. Elizabeth could never
  4998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddress her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over,
  4999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the
  5000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsake of what had been, rather than what was. Charlotte’s first letters
  5001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere received with a good deal of eagerness; there could not but be
  5002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcuriosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would
  5003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlike Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to
  5004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte
  5005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen. She
  5006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing
  5007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she could not praise. The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and
  5008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine’s behaviour was most
  5009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriendly and obliging. It was Mr. Collins’s picture of Hunsford and
  5010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait
  5011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her own visit there to know the rest.
  5012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane had already written a few lines to her sister to announce their
  5014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsafe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it
  5015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.
  5016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience
  5018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenerally is. Jane had been a week in town without either seeing or
  5019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thearing from Caroline. She accounted for it, however, by supposing that
  5020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been
  5021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlost.
  5022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the
  5024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”
  5025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley.
  5027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very
  5028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming
  5029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto London. I was right, therefore, my last letter had never reached
  5030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther. I inquired after their brother, of course. He was well, but so much
  5031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengaged with Mr. Darcy that they scarcely ever saw him. I found that
  5032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Darcy was expected to dinner. I wish I could see her. My visit was
  5033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out. I dare say I shall
  5034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee them soon here.”
  5035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth shook her head over this letter. It convinced her that
  5037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccident only could discover to Mr. Bingley her sister’s being in town.
  5038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFour weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him. She endeavoured to
  5040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpersuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be
  5041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tblind to Miss Bingley’s inattention. After waiting at home every morning
  5042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the
  5043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and yet more,
  5044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe alteration of her manner would allow Jane to deceive herself no
  5045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger. The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will
  5046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprove what she felt.
  5047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in her
  5049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter judgement, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been
  5050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentirely deceived in Miss Bingley’s regard for me. But, my dear sister,
  5051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I
  5052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstill assert that, considering what her behaviour was, my confidence was
  5053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas natural as your suspicion. I do not at all comprehend her reason for
  5054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishing to be intimate with me; but if the same circumstances were to
  5055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappen again, I am sure I should be deceived again. Caroline did not
  5056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturn my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I
  5057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceive in the meantime. When she did come, it was very evident that
  5058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology, for not
  5059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was
  5060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin every respect so altered a creature, that when she went away I was
  5061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer. I pity,
  5062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough I cannot help blaming her. She was very wrong in singling me out
  5063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas she did; I can safely say that every advance to intimacy began on
  5064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther side. But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been acting
  5065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her brother is the
  5066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcause of it. I need not explain myself farther; and though _we_ know
  5067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she feels it, it will easily
  5068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccount for her behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to
  5069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this sister, whatever anxiety she must feel on his behalf is natural and
  5070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamiable. I cannot but wonder, however, at her having any such fears now,
  5071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecause, if he had at all cared about me, we must have met, long ago.
  5072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something she said
  5073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself; and yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she
  5074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted to persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy. I
  5075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot understand it. If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should
  5076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe almost tempted to say that there is a strong appearance of duplicity
  5077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin all this. But I will endeavour to banish every painful thought,
  5078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand think only of what will make me happy--your affection, and the
  5079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt. Let me hear from you very
  5080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon. Miss Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield
  5081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty. We had better
  5082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot mention it. I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts
  5083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom our friends at Hunsford. Pray go to see them, with Sir William and
  5084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMaria. I am sure you will be very comfortable there.--Yours, etc.”
  5085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis letter gave Elizabeth some pain; but her spirits returned as she
  5087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidered that Jane would no longer be duped, by the sister at least.
  5088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAll expectation from the brother was now absolutely over. She would not
  5089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teven wish for a renewal of his attentions. His character sunk on
  5090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery review of it; and as a punishment for him, as well as a possible
  5091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadvantage to Jane, she seriously hoped he might really soon marry Mr.
  5092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy’s sister, as by Wickham’s account, she would make him abundantly
  5093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregret what he had thrown away.
  5094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise
  5096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth
  5097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to
  5098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself. His apparent partiality had subsided, his attentions were over,
  5099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was the admirer of some one else. Elizabeth was watchful enough to
  5100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain.
  5101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied
  5102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith believing that _she_ would have been his only choice, had fortune
  5103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpermitted it. The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most
  5104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself
  5105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than
  5106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin Charlotte’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence.
  5107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and while able to
  5108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was
  5109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very
  5110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsincerely wish him happy.
  5111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAll this was acknowledged to Mrs. Gardiner; and after relating the
  5113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances, she thus went on: “I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that
  5114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure
  5115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and
  5116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twish him all manner of evil. But my feelings are not only cordial
  5117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttowards _him_; they are even impartial towards Miss King. I cannot find
  5118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to
  5119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink her a very good sort of girl. There can be no love in all this. My
  5120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twatchfulness has been effectual; and though I certainly should be a more
  5121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinteresting object to all my acquaintances were I distractedly in love
  5122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith him, I cannot say that I regret my comparative insignificance.
  5123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tImportance may sometimes be purchased too dearly. Kitty and Lydia take
  5124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this defection much more to heart than I do. They are young in the
  5125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that
  5126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thandsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”
  5127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 27
  5131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise
  5134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and
  5135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes cold, did January and February pass away. March was to take
  5136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth to Hunsford. She had not at first thought very seriously of
  5137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan
  5138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure
  5139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas well as greater certainty. Absence had increased her desire of seeing
  5140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte again, and weakened her disgust of Mr. Collins. There
  5141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas novelty in the scheme, and as, with such a mother and such
  5142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change
  5143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not unwelcome for its own sake. The journey would moreover give her
  5144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have
  5145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen very sorry for any delay. Everything, however, went on smoothly,
  5146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand was finally settled according to Charlotte’s first sketch. She was
  5147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto accompany Sir William and his second daughter. The improvement
  5148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became
  5149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperfect as plan could be.
  5150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her,
  5152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he
  5153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttold her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.
  5154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on
  5156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this side even more. His present pursuit could not make him forget that
  5157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the
  5158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner
  5159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of
  5160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their
  5161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion of her--their opinion of everybody--would always coincide, there
  5162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas a solicitude, an interest which she felt must ever attach her to
  5163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced that,
  5164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable
  5165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand pleasing.
  5166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her
  5168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink him less agreeable. Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a
  5169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say
  5170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much
  5171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelight as the rattle of the chaise. Elizabeth loved absurdities, but
  5172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had known Sir William’s too long. He could tell her nothing new of
  5173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were
  5174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworn out, like his information.
  5175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was a journey of only twenty-four miles, and they began it so early
  5177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to be in Gracechurch Street by noon. As they drove to Mr. Gardiner’s
  5178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoor, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival; when
  5179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey entered the passage she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth,
  5180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and
  5181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlovely as ever. On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls,
  5182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to
  5183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen
  5184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower. All was joy and
  5185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkindness. The day passed most pleasantly away; the morning in bustle and
  5186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshopping, and the evening at one of the theatres.
  5187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt. Their first object was her
  5189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to
  5190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her
  5191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits, there were periods of dejection. It was reasonable, however,
  5192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto hope that they would not continue long. Mrs. Gardiner gave her the
  5193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticulars also of Miss Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and
  5194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and
  5195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the
  5196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance.
  5197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham’s desertion, and
  5199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplimented her on bearing it so well.
  5200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King? I
  5202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould be sorry to think our friend mercenary.”
  5203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs,
  5205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween the mercenary and the prudent motive? Where does discretion end,
  5206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand avarice begin? Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me,
  5207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecause it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get
  5208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is
  5209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmercenary.”
  5210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know
  5212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat to think.”
  5213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is a very good kind of girl, I believe. I know no harm of her.”
  5215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather’s death
  5217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade her mistress of this fortune.”
  5218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No--why should he? If it were not allowable for him to gain _my_
  5220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffections because I had no money, what occasion could there be for
  5221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaking love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally
  5222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoor?”
  5223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But there seems an indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her
  5225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso soon after this event.”
  5226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant
  5228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdecorums which other people may observe. If _she_ does not object to it,
  5229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhy should _we_?”
  5230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_Her_ not objecting does not justify _him_. It only shows her being
  5232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeficient in something herself--sense or feeling.”
  5233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose. _He_ shall be
  5235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmercenary, and _she_ shall be foolish.”
  5236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, Lizzy, that is what I do _not_ choose. I should be sorry, you know,
  5238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire.”
  5239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! if that is all, I have a very poor opinion of young men who live in
  5241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDerbyshire; and their intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not
  5242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch better. I am sick of them all. Thank Heaven! I am going to-morrow
  5243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere I shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality, who has
  5244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneither manner nor sense to recommend him. Stupid men are the only ones
  5245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworth knowing, after all.”
  5246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”
  5248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBefore they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the
  5250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in
  5251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.
  5252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We have not determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mrs. Gardiner,
  5254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“but, perhaps, to the Lakes.”
  5255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNo scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her
  5257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “Oh, my dear,
  5258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity! You
  5259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive me fresh life and vigour. Adieu to disappointment and spleen. What
  5260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare young men to rocks and mountains? Oh! what hours of transport
  5261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe shall spend! And when we _do_ return, it shall not be like other
  5262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttravellers, without being able to give one accurate idea of anything. We
  5263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_will_ know where we have gone--we _will_ recollect what we have seen.
  5264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLakes, mountains, and rivers shall not be jumbled together in our
  5265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timaginations; nor when we attempt to describe any particular scene,
  5266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill we begin quarreling about its relative situation. Let _our_
  5267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of
  5268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttravellers.”
  5269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 28
  5273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEvery object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to
  5276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had
  5277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health,
  5278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.
  5279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in
  5281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsearch of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it in view.
  5282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe palings of Rosings Park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth
  5283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
  5284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length the Parsonage was discernible. The garden sloping to the
  5286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troad, the house standing in it, the green pales, and the laurel hedge,
  5287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything declared they were arriving. Mr. Collins and Charlotte
  5288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate which
  5289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tled by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of
  5290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole party. In a moment they were all out of the chaise, rejoicing
  5291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat the sight of each other. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the
  5292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with
  5293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming when she found herself so affectionately received. She saw
  5294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly that her cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage;
  5295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this formal civility was just what it had been, and he detained her some
  5296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tminutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her
  5297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily. They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the
  5298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they
  5299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious
  5300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformality to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s
  5301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffers of refreshment.
  5302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help
  5304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its
  5305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taspect and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her,
  5306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him. But
  5307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to
  5308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratify him by any sigh of repentance, and rather looked with wonder at
  5309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther friend that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion.
  5310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Mr. Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be
  5311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tashamed, which certainly was not unseldom, she involuntarily turned her
  5312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teye on Charlotte. Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but
  5313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin general Charlotte wisely did not hear. After sitting long enough to
  5314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmire every article of furniture in the room, from the sideboard to
  5315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe fender, to give an account of their journey, and of all that had
  5316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a stroll in the
  5317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgarden, which was large and well laid out, and to the cultivation of
  5318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich he attended himself. To work in this garden was one of his most
  5319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance
  5320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and
  5321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\towned she encouraged it as much as possible. Here, leading the way
  5322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthrough every walk and cross walk, and scarcely allowing them an
  5323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterval to utter the praises he asked for, every view was pointed out
  5324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind. He could number the
  5325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfields in every direction, and could tell how many trees there were in
  5326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe most distant clump. But of all the views which his garden, or which
  5327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe country or kingdom could boast, none were to be compared with the
  5328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprospect of Rosings, afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered
  5329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe park nearly opposite the front of his house. It was a handsome
  5330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmodern building, well situated on rising ground.
  5331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom his garden, Mr. Collins would have led them round his two meadows;
  5333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut the ladies, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white
  5334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte
  5335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook her sister and friend over the house, extremely well pleased,
  5336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprobably, to have the opportunity of showing it without her husband’s
  5337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thelp. It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything
  5338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency of which
  5339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit. When Mr. Collins could be
  5340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforgotten, there was really an air of great comfort throughout, and by
  5341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte’s evident enjoyment of it, Elizabeth supposed he must be often
  5342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforgotten.
  5343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country. It
  5345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas spoken of again while they were at dinner, when Mr. Collins joining
  5346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin, observed:
  5347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine
  5349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tde Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will
  5350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I
  5351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice
  5352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying she
  5353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she
  5354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thonours us during your stay here. Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is
  5355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed
  5356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto walk home. Her ladyship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us. I
  5357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_should_ say, one of her ladyship’s carriages, for she has several.”
  5358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman indeed,” added
  5360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”
  5361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of
  5363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twoman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”
  5364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news,
  5366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand telling again what had already been written; and when it closed,
  5367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, in the solitude of her chamber, had to meditate upon
  5368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte’s degree of contentment, to understand her address in guiding,
  5369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand composure in bearing with, her husband, and to acknowledge that it
  5370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas all done very well. She had also to anticipate how her visit
  5371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould pass, the quiet tenor of their usual employments, the vexatious
  5372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with
  5373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings. A lively imagination soon settled it all.
  5374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAbout the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready
  5376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in
  5377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running
  5378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup stairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her. She opened
  5379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe door and met Maria in the landing place, who, breathless with
  5380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagitation, cried out--
  5381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for
  5383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make
  5384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaste, and come down this moment.”
  5385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more,
  5387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand down they ran into the dining-room, which fronted the lane, in
  5388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquest of this wonder; It was two ladies stopping in a low phaeton at the
  5389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgarden gate.
  5390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs
  5392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her
  5393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughter.”
  5394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not
  5396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them;
  5397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe other is Miss de Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little
  5398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcreature. Who would have thought that she could be so thin and small?”
  5399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.
  5401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhy does she not come in?”
  5402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours
  5404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen Miss de Bourgh comes in.”
  5405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She
  5407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooks sickly and cross. Yes, she will do for him very well. She will
  5408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake him a very proper wife.”
  5409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation
  5411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was
  5412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness
  5413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss de Bourgh looked that
  5414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway.
  5415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and
  5417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe others returned into the house. Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two
  5418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgirls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which
  5419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked
  5420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto dine at Rosings the next day.
  5421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 29
  5425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins’s triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete.
  5428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering
  5429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his
  5430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity
  5431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof doing it should be given so soon, was such an instance of Lady
  5432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine’s condescension, as he knew not how to admire enough.
  5433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by
  5435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at
  5436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it
  5437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who
  5438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there
  5439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t(an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so immediately
  5440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter your arrival!”
  5441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William,
  5443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which
  5444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the court, such
  5445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”
  5446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tScarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their
  5448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully instructing them in what
  5449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and
  5450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.
