  5451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth--
  5453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady
  5455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which
  5456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecomes herself and her daughter. I would advise you merely to put on
  5457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhatever of your clothes is superior to the rest--there is no occasion
  5458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor anything more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you
  5459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank
  5460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreserved.”
  5461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhile they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different
  5463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much
  5464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjected to be kept waiting for her dinner. Such formidable accounts of
  5465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas
  5466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho had been little used to company, and she looked forward to her
  5467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done
  5468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his presentation at St. James’s.
  5469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a
  5471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmile across the park. Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and
  5472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such
  5473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\traptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but
  5474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tslightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the
  5475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally
  5476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
  5477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every
  5479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm.
  5480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s courage did not fail her. She had heard nothing of Lady
  5481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or
  5482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmiraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money or rank she thought
  5483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could witness without trepidation.
  5484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom the entrance-hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a
  5486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trapturous air, the fine proportion and the finished ornaments, they
  5487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollowed the servants through an ante-chamber, to the room where Lady
  5488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting. Her ladyship,
  5489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had
  5490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettled it with her husband that the office of introduction should
  5491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those
  5492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.
  5493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely
  5495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tawed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage
  5496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word;
  5497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge
  5498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her chair, not knowing which way to look. Elizabeth found herself
  5499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her
  5500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomposedly. Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked
  5501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeatures, which might once have been handsome. Her air was not
  5502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her
  5503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitors forget their inferior rank. She was not rendered formidable by
  5504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilence; but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone,
  5505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to
  5506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s mind; and from the observation of the day altogether, she
  5507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelieved Lady Catherine to be exactly what he represented.
  5508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment
  5510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the
  5511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her
  5512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing so thin and so small. There was neither in figure nor face any
  5513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikeness between the ladies. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly; her
  5514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeatures, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very
  5515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance
  5516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening
  5517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before
  5518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther eyes.
  5519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to
  5521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties,
  5522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth
  5523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking at in the summer.
  5524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants and
  5526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had
  5527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her
  5528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish
  5529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing greater. He carved, and ate, and praised with delighted
  5530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talacrity; and every dish was commended, first by him and then by Sir
  5531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWilliam, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law
  5532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear.
  5533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and
  5534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved
  5535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta novelty to them. The party did not supply much conversation. Elizabeth
  5536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated
  5537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh--the former of whom was engaged in
  5538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlistening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all
  5539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdinner-time. Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little
  5540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish, and fearing
  5541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe was indisposed. Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the
  5542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.
  5543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to
  5545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any
  5546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every
  5547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject in so decisive a manner, as proved that she was not used to
  5548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave her judgement controverted. She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic
  5549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcerns familiarly and minutely, gave her a great deal of advice as
  5550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be
  5551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the
  5552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcare of her cows and her poultry. Elizabeth found that nothing was
  5553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeneath this great lady’s attention, which could furnish her with an
  5554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion of dictating to others. In the intervals of her discourse
  5555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and
  5556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew
  5557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe least, and who she observed to Mrs. Collins was a very genteel,
  5558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpretty kind of girl. She asked her, at different times, how many sisters
  5559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of
  5560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they
  5561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been
  5562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther mother’s maiden name? Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of
  5563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther questions but answered them very composedly. Lady Catherine then
  5564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobserved,
  5565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your father’s estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think. For your
  5567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no
  5568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion for entailing estates from the female line. It was not thought
  5569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh’s family. Do you play and sing, Miss
  5570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet?”
  5571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A little.”
  5573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! then--some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our
  5575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstrument is a capital one, probably superior to----You shall try it
  5576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome day. Do your sisters play and sing?”
  5577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“One of them does.”
  5579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why did not you all learn? You ought all to have learned. The Miss
  5581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWebbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours. Do
  5582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou draw?”
  5583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, not at all.”
  5585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What, none of you?”
  5587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not one.”
  5589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother
  5591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
  5592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My mother would have had no objection, but my father hates London.”
  5594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Has your governess left you?”
  5596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We never had any governess.”
  5598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home
  5600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout a governess! I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must
  5601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been quite a slave to your education.”
  5602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could hardly help smiling as she assured her that had not been
  5604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe case.
  5605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Then, who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess, you
  5607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have been neglected.”
  5608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as
  5610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twished to learn never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to
  5611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tread, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be
  5612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidle, certainly might.”
  5613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye, no doubt; but that is what a governess will prevent, and if I had
  5615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknown your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage
  5616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady
  5617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is
  5618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that
  5619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces
  5620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and
  5621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was but the other day that I recommended another young person,
  5622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite
  5623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalf’s
  5624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure. ‘Lady
  5625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your
  5626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
  5627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, ma’am, all.”
  5629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“All! What, all five out at once? Very odd! And you only the second. The
  5631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger ones out before the elder ones are married! Your younger sisters
  5632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust be very young?”
  5633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps _she_ is full young to be
  5635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch in company. But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon
  5636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger sisters, that they should not have their share of society and
  5637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to
  5638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry early. The last-born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth
  5639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas the first. And to be kept back on _such_ a motive! I think it would
  5640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
  5641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Upon my word,” said her ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly
  5643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor so young a person. Pray, what is your age?”
  5644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your
  5646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
  5647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer;
  5649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever
  5650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
  5651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure, therefore you need not
  5653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceal your age.”
  5654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not one-and-twenty.”
  5656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card-tables
  5658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere placed. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat
  5659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdown to quadrille; and as Miss de Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the
  5660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her
  5661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty. Their table was superlatively stupid. Scarcely a syllable was
  5662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson
  5663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressed her fears of Miss de Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or
  5664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving too much or too little light. A great deal more passed at the
  5665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking--stating the mistakes
  5666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself. Mr. Collins
  5667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas employed in agreeing to everything her ladyship said, thanking her
  5668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor every fish he won, and apologising if he thought he won too many.
  5669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSir William did not say much. He was storing his memory with anecdotes
  5670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand noble names.
  5671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose,
  5673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins,
  5674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratefully accepted and immediately ordered. The party then gathered
  5675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tround the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were
  5676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto have on the morrow. From these instructions they were summoned by
  5677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr.
  5678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins’s side and as many bows on Sir William’s they departed. As soon
  5679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her cousin
  5680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which, for
  5681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte’s sake, she made more favourable than it really was. But her
  5682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means satisfy
  5683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her ladyship’s praise
  5684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto his own hands.
  5685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 30
  5689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSir William stayed only a week at Hunsford, but his visit was long
  5692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled,
  5693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not
  5694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his
  5695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country; but
  5696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments,
  5697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her
  5698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin by the alteration, for the chief of the time between breakfast
  5699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden or in
  5700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treading and writing, and looking out of the window in his own book-room,
  5701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards.
  5702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had at first rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer
  5703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dining-parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a
  5704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore pleasant aspect; but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent
  5705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been
  5706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch less in his own apartment, had they sat in one equally lively; and
  5707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
  5708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and
  5710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went
  5711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talong, and how often especially Miss de Bourgh drove by in her phaeton,
  5712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened
  5713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and
  5714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever
  5715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevailed upon to get out.
  5716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tVery few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and
  5718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise;
  5719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings
  5720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many
  5721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her ladyship,
  5722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during
  5723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work,
  5724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement
  5725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the furniture; or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she
  5726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding
  5727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
  5728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in
  5730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommission of the peace of the county, she was a most active magistrate
  5731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her
  5732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to
  5733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the
  5734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvillage to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold
  5735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem into harmony and plenty.
  5736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week;
  5738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one
  5739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcard-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart
  5740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the first. Their other engagements were few, as the style of living
  5741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the neighbourhood in general was beyond Mr. Collins’s reach. This,
  5742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time
  5743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomfortably enough; there were half-hours of pleasant conversation with
  5744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year that she had
  5745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften great enjoyment out of doors. Her favourite walk, and where she
  5746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was
  5747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talong the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was
  5748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and
  5749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.
  5750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn this quiet way, the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away.
  5752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEaster was approaching, and the week preceding it was to bring an
  5753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddition to the family at Rosings, which in so small a circle must be
  5754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportant. Elizabeth had heard soon after her arrival that Mr. Darcy was
  5755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpected there in the course of a few weeks, and though there were not
  5756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany of her acquaintances whom she did not prefer, his coming would
  5757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfurnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and
  5758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley’s designs on him
  5759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently
  5760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdestined by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest
  5761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and
  5762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by
  5763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Lucas and herself.
  5764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking
  5766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane,
  5767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin order to have the earliest assurance of it, and after making his
  5768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbow as the carriage turned into the Park, hurried home with the great
  5769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintelligence. On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his
  5770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespects. There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for
  5771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of
  5772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this uncle Lord ----, and, to the great surprise of all the party, when
  5773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte had seen
  5774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem from her husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running
  5775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding:
  5776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would
  5778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever have come so soon to wait upon me.”
  5779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment,
  5781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly
  5782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafterwards the three gentlemen entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam,
  5783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho led the way, was about thirty, not handsome, but in person and
  5784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddress most truly the gentleman. Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been
  5785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tused to look in Hertfordshire--paid his compliments, with his usual
  5786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treserve, to Mrs. Collins, and whatever might be his feelings toward her
  5787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend, met her with every appearance of composure. Elizabeth merely
  5788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcurtseyed to him without saying a word.
  5789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the
  5791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treadiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but
  5792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and
  5793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgarden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.
  5794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of
  5795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth after the health of her family. She answered him in the usual
  5796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway, and after a moment’s pause, added:
  5797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never
  5799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappened to see her there?”
  5800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was perfectly sensible that he never had; but she wished to see
  5802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between
  5803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe Bingleys and Jane, and she thought he looked a little confused as he
  5804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet. The
  5805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject was pursued no farther, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went
  5806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taway.
  5807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 31
  5811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Fitzwilliam’s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage,
  5814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasures
  5815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their engagements at Rosings. It was some days, however, before they
  5816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived any invitation thither--for while there were visitors in the
  5817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse, they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day,
  5818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were honoured by
  5819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to
  5820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome there in the evening. For the last week they had seen very little
  5821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Lady Catherine or her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam had called at the
  5822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tParsonage more than once during the time, but Mr. Darcy they had seen
  5823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly at church.
  5824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe invitation was accepted of course, and at a proper hour they joined
  5826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe party in Lady Catherine’s drawing-room. Her ladyship received
  5827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so
  5828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact,
  5829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy,
  5830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch more than to any other person in the room.
  5831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them; anything was a
  5833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twelcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mrs. Collins’s pretty friend had
  5834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoreover caught his fancy very much. He now seated himself by her, and
  5835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying
  5836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so
  5837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much
  5838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirit and flow, as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself,
  5839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas well as of Mr. Darcy. _His_ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned
  5840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttowards them with a look of curiosity; and that her ladyship, after a
  5841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not
  5842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscruple to call out:
  5843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking
  5845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.”
  5846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We are speaking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid
  5848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta reply.
  5849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I
  5851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have my share in the conversation if you are speaking of music.
  5852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThere are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment
  5853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt,
  5854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health
  5855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed
  5856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
  5857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
  5859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady
  5861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel
  5862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif she does not practice a good deal.”
  5863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice.
  5865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe practises very constantly.”
  5866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write
  5868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often
  5869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell young ladies that no excellence in music is to be acquired without
  5870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconstant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she
  5871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill never play really well unless she practises more; and though Mrs.
  5872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told
  5873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs.
  5874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJenkinson’s room. She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part
  5875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the house.”
  5876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made
  5878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno answer.
  5879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having
  5881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpromised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument. He
  5882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrew a chair near her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then
  5883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away
  5884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom her, and making with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte
  5885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s
  5886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountenance. Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first
  5887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconvenient pause, turned to him with an arch smile, and said:
  5888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear
  5890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme? I will not be alarmed though your sister _does_ play so well. There
  5891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the
  5892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill of others. My courage always rises at every attempt to intimidate
  5893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme.”
  5894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I shall not say you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could not
  5896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treally believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I have
  5897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know that you find
  5898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact are
  5899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot your own.”
  5900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to
  5902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of
  5903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky
  5904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin meeting with a person so able to expose my real character, in a part
  5905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of
  5906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcredit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all
  5907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire--and, give me leave to
  5908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay, very impolitic too--for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such
  5909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthings may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”
  5910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.
  5912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel
  5914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam. “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”
  5915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You shall hear then--but prepare yourself for something very dreadful.
  5917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know,
  5918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas at a ball--and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced
  5919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain
  5920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a
  5921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”
  5922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly
  5924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeyond my own party.”
  5925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel
  5927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.”
  5928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better, had I sought an
  5930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduction; but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”
  5931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still
  5933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and
  5934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teducation, and who has lived in the world, is ill qualified to recommend
  5935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself to strangers?”
  5936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to
  5938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”
  5939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy,
  5941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot
  5942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcatch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their
  5943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcerns, as I often see done.”
  5944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the
  5946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmasterly manner which I see so many women’s do. They have not the same
  5947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforce or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I
  5948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave always supposed it to be my own fault--because I will not take the
  5949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as
  5950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcapable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
  5951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right. You have employed your
  5953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can
  5954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.”
  5955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHere they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know
  5957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat they were talking of. Elizabeth immediately began playing again.
  5958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said
  5959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Darcy:
  5960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and
  5962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion
  5963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne’s. Anne would have
  5964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”
  5965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth looked at Darcy to see how cordially he assented to his
  5967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin’s praise; but neither at that moment nor at any other could she
  5968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss
  5969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tde Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have
  5970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen just as likely to marry _her_, had she been his relation.
  5971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth’s performance, mixing
  5973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith them many instructions on execution and taste. Elizabeth received
  5974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem with all the forbearance of civility, and, at the request of the
  5975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen, remained at the instrument till her ladyship’s carriage was
  5976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tready to take them all home.
  5977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 32
  5981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane
  5984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village,
  5985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a
  5986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitor. As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to
  5987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe Lady Catherine, and under that apprehension was putting away her
  5988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf-finished letter that she might escape all impertinent questions,
  5989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen the door opened, and, to her very great surprise, Mr. Darcy, and
  5990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy only, entered the room.
  5991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologised for his
  5993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintrusion by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies were
  5994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be within.
  5995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  5996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made,
  5997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed in danger of sinking into total silence. It was absolutely
  5998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary, therefore, to think of something, and in this emergence
  5999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecollecting _when_ she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and
  6000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty
  6001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeparture, she observed:
  6002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!
  6004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you
  6005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day
  6006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
  6007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perfectly so, I thank you.”
  6009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe found that she was to receive no other answer, and, after a short
  6011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpause added:
  6012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever
  6014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturning to Netherfield again?”
  6015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend
  6017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery little of his time there in the future. He has many friends, and
  6018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually
  6019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincreasing.”
  6020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for
  6022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we
  6023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight possibly get a settled family there. But, perhaps, Mr. Bingley did
  6024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as
  6025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor his own, and we must expect him to keep it or quit it on the same
  6026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprinciple.”
  6027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should not be surprised,” said Darcy, “if he were to give it up as
  6029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as any eligible purchase offers.”
  6030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth made no answer. She was afraid of talking longer of his
  6032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the
  6033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttrouble of finding a subject to him.
  6034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe took the hint, and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable
  6036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr.
  6037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins first came to Hunsford.”
  6038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her
  6040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkindness on a more grateful object.”
  6041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Collins appears to be very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
  6043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, indeed, his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one
  6045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made
  6046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding--though
  6047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the
  6048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twisest thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however, and in a
  6049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprudential light it is certainly a very good match for her.”
  6050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It must be very agreeable for her to be settled within so easy a
  6052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistance of her own family and friends.”
  6053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“An easy distance, do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.”
  6055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day’s
  6057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjourney. Yes, I call it a _very_ easy distance.”
  6058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_
  6060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins
  6061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas settled _near_ her family.”
  6062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Anything beyond
  6064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.”
  6065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs he spoke there was a sort of smile which Elizabeth fancied she
  6067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and
  6068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield, and she blushed as she answered:
  6069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her
  6071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many
  6072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvarying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expenses of
  6073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttravelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the
  6074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcase _here_. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not
  6075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my
  6076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend would not call herself _near_ her family under less than _half_
  6077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe present distance.”
  6078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “_You_ cannot
  6080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have
  6081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen always at Longbourn.”
  6082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth looked surprised. The gentleman experienced some change of
  6084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and
  6085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tglancing over it, said, in a colder voice:
  6086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you pleased with Kent?”
  6088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tA short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side
  6090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalm and concise--and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte
  6091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her sister, just returned from her walk. The tete-a-tete surprised
  6092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem. Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding
  6093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Miss Bennet, and after sitting a few minutes longer without saying
  6094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch to anybody, went away.
  6095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was
  6097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgone. “My dear, Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never
  6098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave called us in this familiar way.”
  6099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely,
  6101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teven to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and after various
  6102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from
  6103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable
  6104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom the time of year. All field sports were over. Within doors there
  6105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard-table, but gentlemen cannot
  6106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways be within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the
  6107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the
  6108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither
  6109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost every day. They called at various times of the morning, sometimes
  6110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseparately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their
  6111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt. It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he
  6112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended
  6113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in
  6114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing with him, as well as by his evident admiration of her, of her
  6115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer favourite George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw
  6116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners,
  6117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe believed he might have the best informed mind.
  6118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut why Mr. Darcy came so often to the Parsonage, it was more difficult
  6120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto understand. It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there
  6121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak,
  6122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice--a sacrifice
  6123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto propriety, not a pleasure to himself. He seldom appeared really
  6124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanimated. Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him. Colonel
  6125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity, proved that he was
  6126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenerally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told
  6127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther; and as she would liked to have believed this change the effect
  6128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself
  6129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseriously to work to find it out. She watched him whenever they were at
  6130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success. He
  6131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that
  6132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlook was disputable. It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often
  6133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it
  6134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed nothing but absence of mind.
  6135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his
  6137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs.
  6138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of
  6139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\traising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her
  6140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend’s dislike would
  6141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
  6142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying
  6145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Fitzwilliam. He was beyond comparison the most pleasant man; he
  6146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but,
  6147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage
  6148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the church, and his cousin could have none at all.
  6149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 33
  6153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMore than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park,
  6156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy. She felt all the perverseness of the
  6157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmischance that should bring him where no one else was brought, and, to
  6158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him at first that
  6159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was a favourite haunt of hers. How it could occur a second time,
  6160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore, was very odd! Yet it did, and even a third. It seemed like
  6161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance, for on these occasions it was
  6162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away,
  6163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her. He
  6164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking
  6165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third
  6166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trencontre that he was asking some odd unconnected questions--about
  6167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her
  6168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of
  6169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to
  6170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying
  6171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_there_ too. His words seemed to imply it. Could he have Colonel
  6172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam in his thoughts? She supposed, if he meant anything, he must
  6173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter. It distressed
  6174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the
  6175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpales opposite the Parsonage.
  6176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was engaged one day as she walked, in perusing Jane’s last letter,
  6178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in
  6179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw
  6180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton looking up that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her. Putting away the
  6181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter immediately and forcing a smile, she said:
  6182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”
  6184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally
  6186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo every year, and intend to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are
  6187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou going much farther?”
  6188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, I should have turned in a moment.”
  6190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage
  6192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether.
  6193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
  6195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes--if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He
  6197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarranges the business just as he pleases.”
  6198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least
  6200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure in the great power of choice. I do not know anybody who seems
  6201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.”
  6202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam.
  6204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it
  6205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak
  6206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and
  6207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdependence.”
  6208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of
  6210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teither. Now seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and
  6211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going
  6212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twherever you chose, or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”
  6213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“These are home questions--and perhaps I cannot say that I have
  6215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texperienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater
  6216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweight, I may suffer from want of money. Younger sons cannot marry where
  6217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey like.”
  6218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often
  6220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo.”
  6221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many
  6223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to
  6224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoney.”
  6225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the
  6227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what
  6228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis the usual price of an earl’s younger son? Unless the elder brother is
  6229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.”
  6230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped. To interrupt
  6232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed,
  6233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe soon afterwards said:
  6234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of
  6236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving someone at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a
  6237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps, his sister does as well
  6238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the present, and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he
  6239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikes with her.”
  6240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No,” said Colonel Fitzwilliam, “that is an advantage which he must
  6242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdivide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”
  6243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you indeed? And pray what sort of guardians do you make? Does your
  6245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age are sometimes a
  6246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle difficult to manage, and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she
  6247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay like to have her own way.”
  6248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs she spoke she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner
  6250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to
  6251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other
  6252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgot pretty near the truth. She directly replied:
  6253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare
  6255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a
  6256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and
  6257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.”
  6258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant gentlemanlike man--he
  6260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis a great friend of Darcy’s.”
  6261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! yes,” said Elizabeth drily; “Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr.
  6263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”
  6264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Care of him! Yes, I really believe Darcy _does_ take care of him in
  6266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthose points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in
  6267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tour journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to
  6268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that
  6269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.”
  6270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is it you mean?”
  6272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is a circumstance which Darcy could not wish to be generally known,
  6274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbecause if it were to get round to the lady’s family, it would be an
  6275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunpleasant thing.”
  6276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may depend upon my not mentioning it.”
  6278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be
  6280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley. What he told me was merely this: that he congratulated himself
  6281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most
  6282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other
  6283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticulars, and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing
  6284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from
  6285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.”
  6286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did Mr. Darcy give you reasons for this interference?”
  6288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I understood that there were some very strong objections against the
  6290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlady.”
  6291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And what arts did he use to separate them?”
  6293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He did not talk to me of his own arts,” said Fitzwilliam, smiling. “He
  6295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly told me what I have now told you.”
  6296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with
  6298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindignation. After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she
  6299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas so thoughtful.
  6300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
