  6301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she. “Your
  6302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?”
  6303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?”
  6305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his
  6307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend’s inclination, or why, upon his own judgement alone, he was to
  6308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermine and direct in what manner his friend was to be happy.
  6309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the
  6310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed
  6311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat there was much affection in the case.”
  6312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is not an unnatural surmise,” said Fitzwilliam, “but it is a
  6314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlessening of the honour of my cousin’s triumph very sadly.”
  6315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was spoken jestingly; but it appeared to her so just a picture
  6317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Mr. Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer, and
  6318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore, abruptly changing the conversation talked on indifferent
  6319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmatters until they reached the Parsonage. There, shut into her own room,
  6320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption
  6321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof all that she had heard. It was not to be supposed that any other
  6322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeople could be meant than those with whom she was connected. There
  6323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not exist in the world _two_ men over whom Mr. Darcy could have
  6324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch boundless influence. That he had been concerned in the measures
  6325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttaken to separate Bingley and Jane she had never doubted; but she had
  6326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways attributed to Miss Bingley the principal design and arrangement
  6327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof them. If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, _he_ was
  6328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe cause, his pride and caprice were the cause, of all that Jane had
  6329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuffered, and still continued to suffer. He had ruined for a while
  6330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery hope of happiness for the most affectionate, generous heart in the
  6331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld; and no one could say how lasting an evil he might have inflicted.
  6332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel
  6334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam’s words; and those strong objections probably were, her
  6335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in
  6336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness in London.
  6337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To Jane herself,” she exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of
  6339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjection; all loveliness and goodness as she is!--her understanding
  6340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating. Neither
  6341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould anything be urged against my father, who, though with some
  6342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeculiarities, has abilities Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain, and
  6343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespectability which he will probably never reach.” When she thought of
  6344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther mother, her confidence gave way a little; but she would not allow
  6345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat any objections _there_ had material weight with Mr. Darcy, whose
  6346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride, she was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of
  6347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportance in his friend’s connections, than from their want of sense;
  6348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed
  6349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining Mr.
  6350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley for his sister.
  6351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe agitation and tears which the subject occasioned, brought on a
  6353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theadache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening, that, added to
  6354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined her not to attend her
  6355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea. Mrs. Collins,
  6356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go and as much
  6357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but Mr. Collins
  6358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine’s being rather
  6359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdispleased by her staying at home.
  6360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 34
  6364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself
  6367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for her employment the
  6368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texamination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her
  6369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing in Kent. They contained no actual complaint, nor was there any
  6370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trevival of past occurrences, or any communication of present suffering.
  6371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that
  6372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcheerfulness which had been used to characterise her style, and which,
  6373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself and kindly
  6374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded. Elizabeth
  6375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnoticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an
  6376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention which it had hardly received on the first perusal. Mr. Darcy’s
  6377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict, gave her
  6378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta keener sense of her sister’s sufferings. It was some consolation
  6379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the
  6380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext--and, a still greater, that in less than a fortnight she should
  6381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself be with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of
  6382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther spirits, by all that affection could do.
  6383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe could not think of Darcy’s leaving Kent without remembering that
  6385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear
  6386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he had no intentions at all, and agreeable as he was, she did not
  6387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmean to be unhappy about him.
  6388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhile settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the
  6390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoor-bell, and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its
  6391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in
  6392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.
  6393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently
  6394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the
  6395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troom. In an hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her
  6396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thealth, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better.
  6397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe answered him with cold civility. He sat down for a few moments, and
  6398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen getting up, walked about the room. Elizabeth was surprised, but
  6399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid not a word. After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her
  6400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin an agitated manner, and thus began:
  6401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In vain I have struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be
  6403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love
  6404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou.”
  6405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression. She stared, coloured,
  6407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubted, and was silent. This he considered sufficient encouragement;
  6408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the avowal of all that he felt, and had long felt for her,
  6409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately followed. He spoke well; but there were feelings besides
  6410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthose of the heart to be detailed; and he was not more eloquent on the
  6411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject of tenderness than of pride. His sense of her inferiority--of
  6412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits being a degradation--of the family obstacles which had always
  6413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to
  6414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his
  6415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuit.
  6416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to
  6418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe compliment of such a man’s affection, and though her intentions did
  6419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot vary for an instant, she was at first sorry for the pain he was to
  6420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceive; till, roused to resentment by his subsequent language, she
  6421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlost all compassion in anger. She tried, however, to compose herself to
  6422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswer him with patience, when he should have done. He concluded with
  6423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepresenting to her the strength of that attachment which, in spite
  6424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof all his endeavours, he had found impossible to conquer; and with
  6425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by her acceptance of
  6426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this hand. As he said this, she could easily see that he had no doubt
  6427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof a favourable answer. He _spoke_ of apprehension and anxiety, but
  6428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this countenance expressed real security. Such a circumstance could
  6429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly exasperate farther, and, when he ceased, the colour rose into her
  6430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcheeks, and she said:
  6431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to
  6433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpress a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however
  6434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunequally they may be returned. It is natural that obligation should
  6435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe felt, and if I could _feel_ gratitude, I would now thank you. But I
  6436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot--I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly
  6437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbestowed it most unwillingly. I am sorry to have occasioned pain to
  6438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanyone. It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be
  6439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof short duration. The feelings which, you tell me, have long prevented
  6440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe acknowledgment of your regard, can have little difficulty in
  6441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tovercoming it after this explanation.”
  6442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantelpiece with his eyes fixed
  6444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton her face, seemed to catch her words with no less resentment than
  6445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprise. His complexion became pale with anger, and the disturbance
  6446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his mind was visible in every feature. He was struggling for the
  6447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappearance of composure, and would not open his lips till he believed
  6448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself to have attained it. The pause was to Elizabeth’s feelings
  6449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdreadful. At length, with a voice of forced calmness, he said:
  6450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting!
  6452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI might, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little _endeavour_ at
  6453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivility, I am thus rejected. But it is of small importance.”
  6454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I might as well inquire,” replied she, “why with so evident a desire
  6456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me
  6457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagainst your will, against your reason, and even against your character?
  6458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWas not this some excuse for incivility, if I _was_ uncivil? But I have
  6459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother provocations. You know I have. Had not my feelings decided against
  6460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou--had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you
  6461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has
  6462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most
  6463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeloved sister?”
  6464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs she pronounced these words, Mr. Darcy changed colour; but the emotion
  6466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt her while she
  6467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued:
  6468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have every reason in the world to think ill of you. No motive can
  6470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted _there_. You dare not,
  6471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou cannot deny, that you have been the principal, if not the only means
  6472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof dividing them from each other--of exposing one to the censure of the
  6473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld for caprice and instability, and the other to its derision for
  6474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest
  6475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkind.”
  6476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening
  6478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.
  6479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.
  6480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.
  6482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith assumed tranquillity he then replied: “I have no wish of denying
  6484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your
  6485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister, or that I rejoice in my success. Towards _him_ I have been
  6486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkinder than towards myself.”
  6487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection,
  6489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.
  6490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike
  6492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis founded. Long before it had taken place my opinion of you was
  6493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdecided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received
  6494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to
  6495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
  6496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor under what misrepresentation can you here impose upon others?”
  6497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy,
  6499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.
  6500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Who that knows what his misfortunes have been, can help feeling an
  6502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest in him?”
  6503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy contemptuously; “yes, his misfortunes
  6505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been great indeed.”
  6506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth with energy. “You have reduced
  6508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim to his present state of poverty--comparative poverty. You have
  6509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithheld the advantages which you must know to have been designed for
  6510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. You have deprived the best years of his life of that independence
  6511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this!
  6512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand yet you can treat the mention of his misfortune with contempt and
  6513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tridicule.”
  6514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room,
  6516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me!
  6517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this
  6518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalculation, are heavy indeed! But perhaps,” added he, stopping in
  6519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this walk, and turning towards her, “these offenses might have been
  6520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toverlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the
  6521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These
  6522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater
  6523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpolicy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of
  6524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by
  6525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence.
  6526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and
  6527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjust. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your
  6528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnections?--to congratulate myself on the hope of relations, whose
  6529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcondition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”
  6530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to
  6532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe utmost to speak with composure when she said:
  6533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your
  6535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeclaration affected me in any other way, than as it spared me the concern
  6536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more
  6537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemanlike manner.”
  6538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe saw him start at this, but he said nothing, and she continued:
  6540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You could not have made the offer of your hand in any possible way that
  6542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould have tempted me to accept it.”
  6543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAgain his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at her with an
  6545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpression of mingled incredulity and mortification. She went on:
  6546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“From the very beginning--from the first moment, I may almost say--of
  6548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy acquaintance with you, your manners, impressing me with the fullest
  6549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of
  6550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe feelings of others, were such as to form the groundwork of
  6551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisapprobation on which succeeding events have built so immovable a
  6552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the
  6553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.”
  6554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your
  6556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been.
  6557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best
  6558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishes for your health and happiness.”
  6559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd with these words he hastily left the room, and Elizabeth heard him
  6561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe next moment open the front door and quit the house.
  6562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe tumult of her mind, was now painfully great. She knew not how
  6564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto support herself, and from actual weakness sat down and cried for
  6565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf-an-hour. Her astonishment, as she reflected on what had passed,
  6566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas increased by every review of it. That she should receive an offer of
  6567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage from Mr. Darcy! That he should have been in love with her for
  6568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso many months! So much in love as to wish to marry her in spite of
  6569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall the objections which had made him prevent his friend’s marrying
  6570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther sister, and which must appear at least with equal force in his
  6571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town case--was almost incredible! It was gratifying to have inspired
  6572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunconsciously so strong an affection. But his pride, his abominable
  6573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride--his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to
  6574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane--his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could
  6575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot justify it, and the unfeeling manner in which he had mentioned Mr.
  6576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon
  6577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tovercame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for
  6578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta moment excited. She continued in very agitated reflections till the
  6579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsound of Lady Catherine’s carriage made her feel how unequal she was to
  6580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencounter Charlotte’s observation, and hurried her away to her room.
  6581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 35
  6585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations
  6588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich had at length closed her eyes. She could not yet recover from the
  6589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprise of what had happened; it was impossible to think of anything
  6590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telse; and, totally indisposed for employment, she resolved, soon after
  6591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbreakfast, to indulge herself in air and exercise. She was proceeding
  6592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdirectly to her favourite walk, when the recollection of Mr. Darcy’s
  6593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes coming there stopped her, and instead of entering the park,
  6594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe turned up the lane, which led farther from the turnpike-road. The
  6595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpark paling was still the boundary on one side, and she soon passed one
  6596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the gates into the ground.
  6597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was
  6599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and
  6600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlook into the park. The five weeks which she had now passed in Kent had
  6601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the
  6602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tverdure of the early trees. She was on the point of continuing her walk,
  6603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen she caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which
  6604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tedged the park; he was moving that way; and, fearful of its being Mr.
  6605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, she was directly retreating. But the person who advanced was now
  6606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnear enough to see her, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced
  6607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther name. She had turned away; but on hearing herself called, though
  6608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin a voice which proved it to be Mr. Darcy, she moved again towards the
  6609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgate. He had by that time reached it also, and, holding out a letter,
  6610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure,
  6611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have been walking in the grove some time in the hope of meeting you.
  6612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWill you do me the honour of reading that letter?” And then, with a
  6613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tslight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.
  6614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity,
  6616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth opened the letter, and, to her still increasing wonder,
  6617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter-paper, written
  6618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquite through, in a very close hand. The envelope itself was likewise
  6619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfull. Pursuing her way along the lane, she then began it. It was dated
  6620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Rosings, at eight o’clock in the morning, and was as follows:--
  6621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension
  6623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof its containing any repetition of those sentiments or renewal of those
  6624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffers which were last night so disgusting to you. I write without any
  6625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintention of paining you, or humbling myself, by dwelling on wishes
  6626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich, for the happiness of both, cannot be too soon forgotten; and the
  6627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teffort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion,
  6628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould have been spared, had not my character required it to be written
  6629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand read. You must, therefore, pardon the freedom with which I demand
  6630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour attention; your feelings, I know, will bestow it unwillingly, but I
  6631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdemand it of your justice.
  6632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Two offenses of a very different nature, and by no means of equal
  6634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmagnitude, you last night laid to my charge. The first mentioned was,
  6635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached Mr. Bingley
  6636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom your sister, and the other, that I had, in defiance of various
  6637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclaims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate
  6638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham. Wilfully and
  6639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twantonly to have thrown off the companion of my youth, the acknowledged
  6640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourite of my father, a young man who had scarcely any other
  6641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdependence than on our patronage, and who had been brought up to expect
  6642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits exertion, would be a depravity, to which the separation of two young
  6643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpersons, whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks, could
  6644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbear no comparison. But from the severity of that blame which was last
  6645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnight so liberally bestowed, respecting each circumstance, I shall hope
  6646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be in the future secured, when the following account of my actions
  6647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand their motives has been read. If, in the explanation of them, which
  6648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis due to myself, I am under the necessity of relating feelings which
  6649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay be offensive to yours, I can only say that I am sorry. The necessity
  6650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust be obeyed, and further apology would be absurd.
  6651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I had not been long in Hertfordshire, before I saw, in common with
  6653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young
  6654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twoman in the country. But it was not till the evening of the dance
  6655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Netherfield that I had any apprehension of his feeling a serious
  6656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattachment. I had often seen him in love before. At that ball, while I
  6657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir
  6658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWilliam Lucas’s accidental information, that Bingley’s attentions to
  6659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage.
  6660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe spoke of it as a certain event, of which the time alone could
  6661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe undecided. From that moment I observed my friend’s behaviour
  6662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Miss
  6663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him. Your sister I also
  6664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twatched. Her look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever,
  6665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut without any symptom of peculiar regard, and I remained convinced
  6666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom the evening’s scrutiny, that though she received his attentions
  6667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith pleasure, she did not invite them by any participation of
  6668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsentiment. If _you_ have not been mistaken here, _I_ must have been
  6669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin error. Your superior knowledge of your sister must make the latter
  6670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprobable. If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict
  6671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpain on her, your resentment has not been unreasonable. But I shall not
  6672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscruple to assert, that the serenity of your sister’s countenance and
  6673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tair was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction
  6674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, however amiable her temper, her heart was not likely to be
  6675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teasily touched. That I was desirous of believing her indifferent is
  6676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertain--but I will venture to say that my investigation and decisions
  6677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare not usually influenced by my hopes or fears. I did not believe
  6678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial
  6679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconviction, as truly as I wished it in reason. My objections to the
  6680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage were not merely those which I last night acknowledged to have
  6681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe utmost force of passion to put aside, in my own case; the want of
  6682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnection could not be so great an evil to my friend as to me. But
  6683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere were other causes of repugnance; causes which, though still
  6684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texisting, and existing to an equal degree in both instances, I had
  6685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself endeavoured to forget, because they were not immediately before
  6686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme. These causes must be stated, though briefly. The situation of your
  6687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison to that
  6688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttotal want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by
  6689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your
  6690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather. Pardon me. It pains me to offend you. But amidst your concern
  6691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this
  6692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepresentation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that, to
  6693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure,
  6694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis praise no less generally bestowed on you and your elder sister, than
  6695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is honourable to the sense and disposition of both. I will only say
  6696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfarther that from what passed that evening, my opinion of all parties
  6697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas confirmed, and every inducement heightened which could have led
  6698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme before, to preserve my friend from what I esteemed a most unhappy
  6699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnection. He left Netherfield for London, on the day following, as
  6700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, I am certain, remember, with the design of soon returning.
  6701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The part which I acted is now to be explained. His sisters’ uneasiness
  6703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been equally excited with my own; our coincidence of feeling was
  6704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon discovered, and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in
  6705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in
  6706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon. We accordingly went--and there I readily engaged in the office
  6707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof pointing out to my friend the certain evils of such a choice. I
  6708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdescribed, and enforced them earnestly. But, however this remonstrance
  6709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose
  6710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been
  6711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseconded by the assurance that I hesitated not in giving, of your
  6712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister’s indifference. He had before believed her to return his
  6713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection with sincere, if not with equal regard. But Bingley has great
  6714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnatural modesty, with a stronger dependence on my judgement than on his
  6715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town. To convince him, therefore, that he had deceived himself, was
  6716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno very difficult point. To persuade him against returning into
  6717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire, when that conviction had been given, was scarcely the
  6718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twork of a moment. I cannot blame myself for having done thus much. There
  6719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis but one part of my conduct in the whole affair on which I do not
  6720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the
  6721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeasures of art so far as to conceal from him your sister’s being in
  6722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown. I knew it myself, as it was known to Miss Bingley; but her
  6723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrother is even yet ignorant of it. That they might have met without
  6724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\till consequence is perhaps probable; but his regard did not appear to me
  6725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough extinguished for him to see her without some danger. Perhaps this
  6726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcealment, this disguise was beneath me; it is done, however, and it
  6727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas done for the best. On this subject I have nothing more to say, no
  6728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother apology to offer. If I have wounded your sister’s feelings, it
  6729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas unknowingly done and though the motives which governed me may to
  6730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn
  6731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.
  6732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured
  6734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his
  6735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnection with my family. Of what he has _particularly_ accused me I
  6736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam ignorant; but of the truth of what I shall relate, I can summon more
  6737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan one witness of undoubted veracity.
  6738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who had for many
  6740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyears the management of all the Pemberley estates, and whose good
  6741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to
  6742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe of service to him; and on George Wickham, who was his godson, his
  6743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkindness was therefore liberally bestowed. My father supported him at
  6744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tschool, and afterwards at Cambridge--most important assistance, as his
  6745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town father, always poor from the extravagance of his wife, would have
  6746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen unable to give him a gentleman’s education. My father was not only
  6747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfond of this young man’s society, whose manners were always engaging; he
  6748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad also the highest opinion of him, and hoping the church would be
  6749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this profession, intended to provide for him in it. As for myself, it is
  6750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany, many years since I first began to think of him in a very different
  6751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner. The vicious propensities--the want of principle, which he was
  6752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcareful to guard from the knowledge of his best friend, could not escape
  6753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe observation of a young man of nearly the same age with himself,
  6754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand who had opportunities of seeing him in unguarded moments, which Mr.
  6755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy could not have. Here again I shall give you pain--to what degree
  6756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou only can tell. But whatever may be the sentiments which Mr. Wickham
  6757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thas created, a suspicion of their nature shall not prevent me from
  6758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunfolding his real character--it adds even another motive.
  6759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My excellent father died about five years ago; and his attachment to
  6761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham was to the last so steady, that in his will he particularly
  6762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecommended it to me, to promote his advancement in the best manner
  6763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat his profession might allow--and if he took orders, desired that a
  6764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvaluable family living might be his as soon as it became vacant. There
  6765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas also a legacy of one thousand pounds. His own father did not long
  6766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurvive mine, and within half a year from these events, Mr. Wickham
  6767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrote to inform me that, having finally resolved against taking orders,
  6768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the hoped I should not think it unreasonable for him to expect some more
  6769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediate pecuniary advantage, in lieu of the preferment, by which he
  6770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not be benefited. He had some intention, he added, of studying
  6771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlaw, and I must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would
  6772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe a very insufficient support therein. I rather wished, than believed
  6773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim to be sincere; but, at any rate, was perfectly ready to accede to
  6774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this proposal. I knew that Mr. Wickham ought not to be a clergyman; the

  6776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the church, were it possible that he could ever be in a situation to
  6777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceive it, and accepted in return three thousand pounds. All connection
  6778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween us seemed now dissolved. I thought too ill of him to invite him
  6779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Pemberley, or admit his society in town. In town I believe he chiefly
  6780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlived, but his studying the law was a mere pretence, and being now free
  6781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom all restraint, his life was a life of idleness and dissipation.
  6782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFor about three years I heard little of him; but on the decease of the
  6783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincumbent of the living which had been designed for him, he applied to

  6785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme, and I had no difficulty in believing it, were exceedingly bad. He
  6786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad found the law a most unprofitable study, and was now absolutely
  6787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresolved on being ordained, if I would present him to the living in
  6788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquestion--of which he trusted there could be little doubt, as he was
  6789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell assured that I had no other person to provide for, and I could not
  6790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave forgotten my revered father’s intentions. You will hardly blame
  6791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme for refusing to comply with this entreaty, or for resisting every
  6792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepetition to it. His resentment was in proportion to the distress of
  6793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this circumstances--and he was doubtless as violent in his abuse of me

  6796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast summer he was again most painfully obtruded on my notice.
  6797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must now mention a circumstance which I would wish to forget myself,
  6799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand which no obligation less than the present should induce me to unfold
  6800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto any human being. Having said thus much, I feel no doubt of your
  6801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecrecy. My sister, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to
  6802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe guardianship of my mother’s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.
  6803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAbout a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed
  6804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided
  6805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover it, to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by
  6806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdesign; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him
  6807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Mrs. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and
  6808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby her connivance and aid, he so far recommended himself to Georgiana,
  6809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to
  6810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love, and
  6811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto consent to an elopement. She was then but fifteen, which must be her
  6812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed
  6813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe knowledge of it to herself. I joined them unexpectedly a day or two

  6815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as
  6816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta father, acknowledged the whole to me. You may imagine what I felt and
  6817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow I acted. Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented
  6818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place
  6819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately, and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge. Mr.
  6820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which
  6821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of
  6822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trevenging himself on me was a strong inducement. His revenge would have
  6823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen complete indeed.
  6824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have
  6826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as
  6827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfalse, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr.
  6828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham. I know not in what manner, under what form of falsehood he
  6829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be wondered
  6830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat. Ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning either,
  6831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly not in
  6832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour inclination.
  6833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may possibly wonder why all this was not told you last night; but
  6835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to
  6836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe revealed. For the truth of everything here related, I can appeal more
  6837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticularly to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, from our
  6838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnear relationship and constant intimacy, and, still more, as one of
  6839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe executors of my father’s will, has been unavoidably acquainted
  6840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith every particular of these transactions. If your abhorrence of _me_
  6841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould make _my_ assertions valueless, you cannot be prevented by
  6842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe same cause from confiding in my cousin; and that there may be
  6843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe possibility of consulting him, I shall endeavour to find some
  6844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topportunity of putting this letter in your hands in the course of the
  6845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning. I will only add, God bless you.
  6846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“FITZWILLIAM DARCY”
  6848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 36
  6852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIf Elizabeth, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to
  6855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of
  6856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits contents. But such as they were, it may well be supposed how eagerly
  6857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.
  6858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined. With amazement did
  6859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power;
  6860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation
  6861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal. With a strong
  6862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what
  6863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad happened at Netherfield. She read with an eagerness which hardly
  6864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleft her power of comprehension, and from impatience of knowing what the
  6865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of
  6866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe one before her eyes. His belief of her sister’s insensibility she
  6867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst
  6868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing
  6869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim justice. He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied
  6870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther; his style was not penitent, but haughty. It was all pride and
  6871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinsolence.
  6872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham--when
  6874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe read with somewhat clearer attention a relation of events which,
  6875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which
  6876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself--her
  6877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.
  6878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAstonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished
  6879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!
  6880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”--and when she had
  6881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the
  6882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not
  6883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard it, that she would never look in it again.
  6884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on
  6886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing, she walked on; but it would not do; in half a minute the letter
  6887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas unfolded again, and collecting herself as well as she could, she
  6888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and
  6889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.
  6890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what
  6891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though
  6892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own
  6893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twords. So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the
  6894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill, the difference was great. What Wickham had said of the living
  6895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas fresh in her memory, and as she recalled his very words, it was
  6896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the
  6897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother; and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did
  6898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot err. But when she read and re-read with the closest attention, the
  6899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions
  6900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three
  6901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate. She put down
  6902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be
  6903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpartiality--deliberated on the probability of each statement--but with
  6904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle success. On both sides it was only assertion. Again she read
  6905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton; but every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had
  6906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelieved it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to
  6907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trender Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a
  6908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.
  6909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay at
  6911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham’s charge, exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could
  6912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbring no proof of its injustice. She had never heard of him before his
  6913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentrance into the ----shire Militia, in which he had engaged at the
  6914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpersuasion of the young man who, on meeting him accidentally in town,
  6915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad there renewed a slight acquaintance. Of his former way of life
  6916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what he told himself. As
  6917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his real character, had information been in her power, she had
  6918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever felt a wish of inquiring. His countenance, voice, and manner had
  6919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testablished him at once in the possession of every virtue. She tried
  6920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of
  6921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintegrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of
  6922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those
  6923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcasual errors under which she would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy
  6924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance. But
  6925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno such recollection befriended her. She could see him instantly before
  6926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, in every charm of air and address; but she could remember no more
  6927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubstantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and
  6928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess. After
  6929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to
  6930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tread. But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Miss
  6931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel
  6932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was
  6933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treferred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam
  6934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself--from whom she had previously received the information of his
  6935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnear concern in all his cousin’s affairs, and whose character she had no
  6936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treason to question. At one time she had almost resolved on applying to
  6937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and
  6938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never
  6939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his
  6940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin’s corroboration.
  6941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation
  6943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween Wickham and herself, in their first evening at Mr. Phillips’s.
  6944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMany of his expressions were still fresh in her memory. She was _now_
  6945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstruck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and
  6946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twondered it had escaped her before. She saw the indelicacy of putting
  6947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions
  6948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith his conduct. She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear
  6949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof seeing Mr. Darcy--that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that
  6950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_he_ should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball
  6951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe very next week. She remembered also that, till the Netherfield
  6952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but
  6953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself; but that after their removal it had been everywhere discussed;
  6954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s
  6955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter, though he had assured her that respect for the father would
  6956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways prevent his exposing the son.
  6957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHow differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned!
  6959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and
  6960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer
  6961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything.
  6962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive; he had
  6963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teither been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying
  6964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most
  6965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincautiously shown. Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter
  6966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand fainter; and in farther justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not
  6967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago
  6968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tasserted his blamelessness in the affair; that proud and repulsive as
  6969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their
  6970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance--an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much
  6971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways--seen anything
  6972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust--anything that spoke him
  6973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof irreligious or immoral habits; that among his own connections he was
  6974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testeemed and valued--that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a
  6975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his
  6976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister as to prove him capable of _some_ amiable feeling; that had his
  6977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactions been what Mr. Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of
  6978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and
  6979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat friendship between a person capable of it, and such an amiable man
  6980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas Mr. Bingley, was incomprehensible.
  6981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe grew absolutely ashamed of herself. Of neither Darcy nor Wickham
  6983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould she think without feeling she had been blind, partial, prejudiced,
  6984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsurd.
  6985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How despicably I have acted!” she cried; “I, who have prided myself
  6987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton my discernment! I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have
  6988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified
  6989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy vanity in useless or blameable mistrust! How humiliating is this
  6990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscovery! Yet, how just a humiliation! Had I been in love, I could
  6991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot have been more wretchedly blind! But vanity, not love, has been my
  6992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfolly. Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect
  6993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted
  6994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away, where either were
  6995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcerned. Till this moment I never knew myself.”
  6996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  6997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom herself to Jane--from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts were in a line
  6998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich soon brought to her recollection that Mr. Darcy’s explanation
  6999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_there_ had appeared very insufficient, and she read it again. Widely
  7000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifferent was the effect of a second perusal. How could she deny that
  7001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcredit to his assertions in one instance, which she had been obliged to
  7002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive in the other? He declared himself to be totally unsuspicious of her
  7003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister’s attachment; and she could not help remembering what Charlotte’s
  7004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion had always been. Neither could she deny the justice of his
  7005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdescription of Jane. She felt that Jane’s feelings, though fervent, were
  7006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air
  7007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand manner not often united with great sensibility.
  7008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen she came to that part of the letter in which her family were
  7010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned in terms of such mortifying, yet merited reproach, her sense
  7011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof shame was severe. The justice of the charge struck her too forcibly
  7012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor denial, and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded as
  7013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first
  7014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind
  7015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan on hers.
  7016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe compliment to herself and her sister was not unfelt. It soothed,
  7018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut it could not console her for the contempt which had thus been
  7019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tself-attracted by the rest of her family; and as she considered
  7020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Jane’s disappointment had in fact been the work of her nearest
  7021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt
  7022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby such impropriety of conduct, she felt depressed beyond anything she
  7023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad ever known before.
  7024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every
  7026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvariety of thought--re-considering events, determining probabilities,
  7027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand reconciling herself, as well as she could, to a change so sudden and
  7028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso important, fatigue, and a recollection of her long absence, made
  7029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther at length return home; and she entered the house with the wish
  7030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such
  7031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treflections as must make her unfit for conversation.
  7032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was immediately told that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each
  7034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalled during her absence; Mr. Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take
  7035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleave--but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least
  7036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan hour, hoping for her return, and almost resolving to walk after her
  7037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill she could be found. Elizabeth could but just _affect_ concern
  7038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin missing him; she really rejoiced at it. Colonel Fitzwilliam was no
  7039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger an object; she could think only of her letter.
  7040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 37
  7044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning, and Mr. Collins having
  7047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen in waiting near the lodges, to make them his parting obeisance, was
  7048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\table to bring home the pleasing intelligence, of their appearing in very
  7049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood health, and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected, after the
  7050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmelancholy scene so lately gone through at Rosings. To Rosings he then
  7051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thastened, to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; and on his return
  7052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrought back, with great satisfaction, a message from her ladyship,
  7053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timporting that she felt herself so dull as to make her very desirous of
  7054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving them all to dine with her.
  7055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without recollecting that, had
  7057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe chosen it, she might by this time have been presented to her as
  7058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther future niece; nor could she think, without a smile, of what her
  7059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship’s indignation would have been. “What would she have said? how
  7060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould she have behaved?” were questions with which she amused herself.
  7061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir first subject was the diminution of the Rosings party. “I assure
  7063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, I feel it exceedingly,” said Lady Catherine; “I believe no one
  7064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeels the loss of friends so much as I do. But I am particularly
  7065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattached to these young men, and know them to be so much attached to
  7066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme! They were excessively sorry to go! But so they always are. The
  7067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear Colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy
  7068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed to feel it most acutely, more, I think, than last year. His
  7069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattachment to Rosings certainly increases.”
  7070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins had a compliment, and an allusion to throw in here, which
  7072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.
  7073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine observed, after dinner, that Miss Bennet seemed out of
  7075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits, and immediately accounting for it by herself, by supposing that
  7076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe did not like to go home again so soon, she added:
  7077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But if that is the case, you must write to your mother and beg that
  7079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou may stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your
  7080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompany, I am sure.”
  7081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am much obliged to your ladyship for your kind invitation,” replied
  7083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, “but it is not in my power to accept it. I must be in town
  7084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext Saturday.”
  7085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks. I expected
  7087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou to stay two months. I told Mrs. Collins so before you came. There
  7088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan be no occasion for your going so soon. Mrs. Bennet could certainly
  7089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspare you for another fortnight.”
