  7090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But my father cannot. He wrote last week to hurry my return.”
  7092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! your father of course may spare you, if your mother can. Daughters
  7094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare never of so much consequence to a father. And if you will stay
  7095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanother _month_ complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as
  7096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfar as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as
  7097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDawson does not object to the barouche-box, there will be very good room
  7098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor one of you--and indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I
  7099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.”
  7100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are all kindness, madam; but I believe we must abide by our
  7102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toriginal plan.”
  7103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine seemed resigned. “Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant
  7105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith them. You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea
  7106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof two young women travelling post by themselves. It is highly improper.
  7107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYou must contrive to send somebody. I have the greatest dislike in
  7108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe world to that sort of thing. Young women should always be properly
  7109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tguarded and attended, according to their situation in life. When my
  7110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tniece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her
  7111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving two men-servants go with her. Miss Darcy, the daughter of
  7112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy, of Pemberley, and Lady Anne, could not have appeared with
  7113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpropriety in a different manner. I am excessively attentive to all those
  7114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthings. You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I
  7115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam glad it occurred to me to mention it; for it would really be
  7116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscreditable to _you_ to let them go alone.”
  7117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My uncle is to send a servant for us.”
  7119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! Your uncle! He keeps a man-servant, does he? I am very glad you
  7121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave somebody who thinks of these things. Where shall you change horses?
  7122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOh! Bromley, of course. If you mention my name at the Bell, you will be
  7123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattended to.”
  7124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine had many other questions to ask respecting their journey,
  7126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand as she did not answer them all herself, attention was necessary,
  7127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich Elizabeth believed to be lucky for her; or, with a mind so
  7128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccupied, she might have forgotten where she was. Reflection must be
  7129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treserved for solitary hours; whenever she was alone, she gave way to it
  7130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary
  7131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalk, in which she might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant
  7132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecollections.
  7133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy’s letter she was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart. She
  7135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstudied every sentence; and her feelings towards its writer were at
  7136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttimes widely different. When she remembered the style of his address,
  7137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe was still full of indignation; but when she considered how unjustly
  7138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had condemned and upbraided him, her anger was turned against
  7139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion.
  7140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect; but she
  7141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal,
  7142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again. In her own past
  7143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret; and in
  7144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe unhappy defects of her family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin.
  7145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were hopeless of remedy. Her father, contented with laughing at
  7146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his
  7147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoungest daughters; and her mother, with manners so far from right
  7148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself, was entirely insensible of the evil. Elizabeth had frequently
  7149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunited with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine
  7150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Lydia; but while they were supported by their mother’s indulgence,
  7151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat chance could there be of improvement? Catherine, weak-spirited,
  7152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tirritable, and completely under Lydia’s guidance, had been always
  7153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffronted by their advice; and Lydia, self-willed and careless, would
  7154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscarcely give them a hearing. They were ignorant, idle, and vain. While
  7155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him; and while
  7156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton was within a walk of Longbourn, they would be going there
  7157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforever.
  7158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnxiety on Jane’s behalf was another prevailing concern; and Mr. Darcy’s
  7160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texplanation, by restoring Bingley to all her former good opinion,
  7161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theightened the sense of what Jane had lost. His affection was proved
  7162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto have been sincere, and his conduct cleared of all blame, unless any
  7163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould attach to the implicitness of his confidence in his friend. How
  7164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every
  7165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, Jane had
  7166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen deprived, by the folly and indecorum of her own family!
  7167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen to these recollections was added the development of Wickham’s
  7169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had
  7170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseldom been depressed before, were now so much affected as to make it
  7171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost impossible for her to appear tolerably cheerful.
  7172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of
  7174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther stay as they had been at first. The very last evening was spent
  7175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere; and her ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of
  7176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing,
  7177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right
  7178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway, that Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the
  7179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twork of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh.
  7180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen they parted, Lady Catherine, with great condescension, wished them
  7182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year;
  7183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Miss de Bourgh exerted herself so far as to curtsey and hold out her
  7184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thand to both.
  7185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 38
  7189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn Saturday morning Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few
  7192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tminutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of
  7193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpaying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.
  7194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I know not, Miss Elizabeth,” said he, “whether Mrs. Collins has yet
  7196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very
  7197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for
  7198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit. The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you. We
  7199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow how little there is to tempt anyone to our humble abode. Our plain
  7200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner of living, our small rooms and few domestics, and the little we
  7201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like
  7202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension,
  7203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand that we have done everything in our power to prevent your spending
  7204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour time unpleasantly.”
  7205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was eager with her thanks and assurances of happiness. She
  7207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with
  7208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte, and the kind attentions she had received, must make _her_
  7209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeel the obliged. Mr. Collins was gratified, and with a more smiling
  7210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsolemnity replied:
  7211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It gives me great pleasure to hear that you have passed your time not
  7213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeably. We have certainly done our best; and most fortunately
  7214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving it in our power to introduce you to very superior society, and,
  7215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of varying the
  7216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that your Hunsford
  7217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit cannot have been entirely irksome. Our situation with regard to
  7218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine’s family is indeed the sort of extraordinary advantage
  7219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand blessing which few can boast. You see on what a footing we are. You
  7220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee how continually we are engaged there. In truth I must acknowledge
  7221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, I should
  7222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot think anyone abiding in it an object of compassion, while they are
  7223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsharers of our intimacy at Rosings.”
  7224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWords were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was
  7226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility
  7227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand truth in a few short sentences.
  7228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into
  7230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire, my dear cousin. I flatter myself at least that you will
  7231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe able to do so. Lady Catherine’s great attentions to Mrs. Collins you
  7232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear
  7233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be
  7234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas well to be silent. Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth,
  7235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in
  7236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage. My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of
  7237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthinking. There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of
  7238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharacter and ideas between us. We seem to have been designed for each
  7239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother.”
  7240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was
  7242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe case, and with equal sincerity could add, that she firmly believed
  7243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand rejoiced in his domestic comforts. She was not sorry, however, to
  7244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave the recital of them interrupted by the lady from whom they sprang.
  7245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPoor Charlotte! it was melancholy to leave her to such society! But she
  7246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad chosen it with her eyes open; and though evidently regretting that
  7247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther visitors were to go, she did not seem to ask for compassion. Her
  7248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome and her housekeeping, her parish and her poultry, and all their
  7249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.
  7250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length the chaise arrived, the trunks were fastened on, the parcels
  7252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplaced within, and it was pronounced to be ready. After an affectionate
  7253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparting between the friends, Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by
  7254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins, and as they walked down the garden he was commissioning her
  7255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith his best respects to all her family, not forgetting his thanks
  7256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his
  7257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompliments to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, though unknown. He then handed her
  7258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin, Maria followed, and the door was on the point of being closed,
  7259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had
  7260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies at Rosings.
  7261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But,” he added, “you will of course wish to have your humble respects
  7263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelivered to them, with your grateful thanks for their kindness to you
  7264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile you have been here.”
  7265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth made no objection; the door was then allowed to be shut, and
  7267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe carriage drove off.
  7268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good gracious!” cried Maria, after a few minutes’ silence, “it seems
  7270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut a day or two since we first came! and yet how many things have
  7271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappened!”
  7272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A great many indeed,” said her companion with a sigh.
  7274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We have dined nine times at Rosings, besides drinking tea there twice!
  7276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHow much I shall have to tell!”
  7277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth added privately, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”
  7279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir journey was performed without much conversation, or any alarm; and
  7281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithin four hours of their leaving Hunsford they reached Mr. Gardiner’s
  7282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse, where they were to remain a few days.
  7283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane looked well, and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying her
  7285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of her
  7286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt had reserved for them. But Jane was to go home with her, and at
  7287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.
  7288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was not without an effort, meanwhile, that she could wait even for
  7290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn, before she told her sister of Mr. Darcy’s proposals. To know
  7291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish
  7292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of her own
  7293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvanity she had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation
  7294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto openness as nothing could have conquered but the state of indecision
  7295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin which she remained as to the extent of what she should communicate;
  7296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her fear, if she once entered on the subject, of being hurried
  7297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto repeating something of Bingley which might only grieve her sister
  7298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfurther.
  7299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 39
  7303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was the second week in May, in which the three young ladies set out
  7306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether from Gracechurch Street for the town of ----, in Hertfordshire;
  7307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, as they drew near the appointed inn where Mr. Bennet’s carriage
  7308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman’s
  7309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpunctuality, both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining-room up stairs.
  7310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThese two girls had been above an hour in the place, happily employed
  7311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin visiting an opposite milliner, watching the sentinel on guard, and
  7312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdressing a salad and cucumber.
  7313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly displayed a table set
  7315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming,
  7316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is not this nice? Is not this an agreeable surprise?”
  7317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia, “but you must lend us the
  7319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoney, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then, showing
  7320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther purchases--“Look here, I have bought this bonnet. I do not think
  7321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not. I shall
  7322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpull it to pieces as soon as I get home, and see if I can make it up any
  7323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter.”
  7324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd when her sisters abused it as ugly, she added, with perfect
  7326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunconcern, “Oh! but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and
  7327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen I have bought some prettier-coloured satin to trim it with fresh, I
  7328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink it will be very tolerable. Besides, it will not much signify what
  7329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone wears this summer, after the ----shire have left Meryton, and they
  7330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare going in a fortnight.”
  7331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are they indeed!” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.
  7333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They are going to be encamped near Brighton; and I do so want papa to
  7335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake us all there for the summer! It would be such a delicious scheme;
  7336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand I dare say would hardly cost anything at all. Mamma would like to
  7337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgo too of all things! Only think what a miserable summer else we shall
  7338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave!”
  7339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes,” thought Elizabeth, “_that_ would be a delightful scheme indeed,
  7341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand completely do for us at once. Good Heaven! Brighton, and a whole
  7342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcampful of soldiers, to us, who have been overset already by one poor
  7343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregiment of militia, and the monthly balls of Meryton!”
  7344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down at
  7346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttable. “What do you think? It is excellent news--capital news--and about
  7347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta certain person we all like!”
  7348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told he need
  7350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot stay. Lydia laughed, and said:
  7351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Aye, that is just like your formality and discretion. You thought the
  7353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twaiter must not hear, as if he cared! I dare say he often hears worse
  7354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthings said than I am going to say. But he is an ugly fellow! I am glad
  7355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the is gone. I never saw such a long chin in my life. Well, but now for
  7356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy news; it is about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, is it not?
  7357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThere is no danger of Wickham’s marrying Mary King. There’s for you! She
  7358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis gone down to her uncle at Liverpool: gone to stay. Wickham is safe.”
  7359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And Mary King is safe!” added Elizabeth; “safe from a connection
  7361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudent as to fortune.”
  7362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is a great fool for going away, if she liked him.”
  7364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said Jane.
  7366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sure there is not on _his_. I will answer for it, he never cared
  7368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthree straws about her--who could about such a nasty little freckled
  7369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing?”
  7370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was shocked to think that, however incapable of such
  7372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoarseness of _expression_ herself, the coarseness of the _sentiment_
  7373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas little other than her own breast had harboured and fancied liberal!
  7374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs soon as all had ate, and the elder ones paid, the carriage was
  7376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tordered; and after some contrivance, the whole party, with all their
  7377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboxes, work-bags, and parcels, and the unwelcome addition of Kitty’s and
  7378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia’s purchases, were seated in it.
  7379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How nicely we are all crammed in,” cried Lydia. “I am glad I bought my
  7381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbonnet, if it is only for the fun of having another bandbox! Well, now
  7382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlet us be quite comfortable and snug, and talk and laugh all the way
  7383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome. And in the first place, let us hear what has happened to you all
  7384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsince you went away. Have you seen any pleasant men? Have you had any
  7385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tflirting? I was in great hopes that one of you would have got a husband
  7386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore you came back. Jane will be quite an old maid soon, I declare.
  7387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe is almost three-and-twenty! Lord, how ashamed I should be of not
  7388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing married before three-and-twenty! My aunt Phillips wants you so to
  7389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tget husbands, you can’t think. She says Lizzy had better have taken Mr.
  7390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins; but _I_ do not think there would have been any fun in it. Lord!
  7391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow I should like to be married before any of you; and then I would
  7392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchaperon you about to all the balls. Dear me! we had such a good piece
  7393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof fun the other day at Colonel Forster’s. Kitty and me were to spend
  7394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe day there, and Mrs. Forster promised to have a little dance in the
  7395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevening; (by the bye, Mrs. Forster and me are _such_ friends!) and so
  7396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe asked the two Harringtons to come, but Harriet was ill, and so Pen
  7397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas forced to come by herself; and then, what do you think we did? We
  7398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdressed up Chamberlayne in woman’s clothes on purpose to pass for a
  7399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlady, only think what fun! Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and Mrs.
  7400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForster, and Kitty and me, except my aunt, for we were forced to borrow
  7401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone of her gowns; and you cannot imagine how well he looked! When Denny,
  7402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Wickham, and Pratt, and two or three more of the men came in, they
  7403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not know him in the least. Lord! how I laughed! and so did Mrs.
  7404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForster. I thought I should have died. And _that_ made the men suspect
  7405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomething, and then they soon found out what was the matter.”
  7406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith such kinds of histories of their parties and good jokes, did
  7408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia, assisted by Kitty’s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse her
  7409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompanions all the way to Longbourn. Elizabeth listened as little as she
  7410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould, but there was no escaping the frequent mention of Wickham’s name.
  7411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir reception at home was most kind. Mrs. Bennet rejoiced to see Jane
  7413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin undiminished beauty; and more than once during dinner did Mr. Bennet
  7414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay voluntarily to Elizabeth:
  7415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am glad you are come back, Lizzy.”
  7417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases
  7419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcame to meet Maria and hear the news; and various were the subjects that
  7420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccupied them: Lady Lucas was inquiring of Maria, after the welfare and
  7421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoultry of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly engaged, on one
  7422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane, who sat
  7423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome way below her, and, on the other, retailing them all to the younger
  7424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLucases; and Lydia, in a voice rather louder than any other person’s,
  7425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who
  7426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould hear her.
  7427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! Mary,” said she, “I wish you had gone with us, for we had such fun!
  7429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs we went along, Kitty and I drew up the blinds, and pretended there
  7430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas nobody in the coach; and I should have gone so all the way, if Kitty
  7431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad not been sick; and when we got to the George, I do think we behaved
  7432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery handsomely, for we treated the other three with the nicest cold
  7433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tluncheon in the world, and if you would have gone, we would have treated
  7434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou too. And then when we came away it was such fun! I thought we never
  7435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould have got into the coach. I was ready to die of laughter. And then
  7436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe were so merry all the way home! we talked and laughed so loud, that
  7437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanybody might have heard us ten miles off!”
  7438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo this Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister,
  7440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto depreciate such pleasures! They would doubtless be congenial with the
  7441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenerality of female minds. But I confess they would have no charms for
  7442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_me_--I should infinitely prefer a book.”
  7443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut of this answer Lydia heard not a word. She seldom listened to
  7445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mary at all.
  7446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the girls to walk
  7448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Meryton, and to see how everybody went on; but Elizabeth steadily
  7449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topposed the scheme. It should not be said that the Miss Bennets could
  7450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers.
  7451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThere was another reason too for her opposition. She dreaded seeing Mr.
  7452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible. The
  7453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomfort to _her_ of the regiment’s approaching removal was indeed beyond
  7454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpression. In a fortnight they were to go--and once gone, she hoped
  7455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere could be nothing more to plague her on his account.
  7456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had not been many hours at home before she found that the Brighton
  7458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscheme, of which Lydia had given them a hint at the inn, was under
  7459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequent discussion between her parents. Elizabeth saw directly that her
  7460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were
  7461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat the same time so vague and equivocal, that her mother, though often
  7462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.
  7463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 40
  7467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could
  7470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno longer be overcome; and at length, resolving to suppress every
  7471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticular in which her sister was concerned, and preparing her to be
  7472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprised, she related to her the next morning the chief of the scene
  7473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween Mr. Darcy and herself.
  7474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet’s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly
  7476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpartiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth appear perfectly
  7477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnatural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings. She was
  7478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsorry that Mr. Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so
  7479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle suited to recommend them; but still more was she grieved for the
  7480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunhappiness which her sister’s refusal must have given him.
  7481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said she, “and certainly
  7483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his
  7484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointment!”
  7485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has
  7487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother feelings, which will probably soon drive away his regard for me.
  7488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYou do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”
  7489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Blame you! Oh, no.”
  7491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you blame me for having spoken so warmly of Wickham?”
  7493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No--I do not know that you were wrong in saying what you did.”
  7495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you _will_ know it, when I tell you what happened the very next
  7497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday.”
  7498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far
  7500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas they concerned George Wickham. What a stroke was this for poor Jane!
  7501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho would willingly have gone through the world without believing that
  7502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind, as was here
  7503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcollected in one individual. Nor was Darcy’s vindication, though
  7504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrateful to her feelings, capable of consoling her for such discovery.
  7505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMost earnestly did she labour to prove the probability of error, and
  7506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseek to clear the one without involving the other.
  7507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This will not do,” said Elizabeth; “you never will be able to make both
  7509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof them good for anything. Take your choice, but you must be satisfied
  7510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith only one. There is but such a quantity of merit between them; just
  7511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to make one good sort of man; and of late it has been shifting
  7512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout pretty much. For my part, I am inclined to believe it all Darcy’s;
  7513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut you shall do as you choose.”
  7514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was some time, however, before a smile could be extorted from Jane.
  7516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said she. “Wickham so
  7518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery bad! It is almost past belief. And poor Mr. Darcy! Dear Lizzy, only
  7519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsider what he must have suffered. Such a disappointment! and with the
  7520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknowledge of your ill opinion, too! and having to relate such a thing
  7521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his sister! It is really too distressing. I am sure you must feel it
  7522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso.”
  7523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! no, my regret and compassion are all done away by seeing you so
  7525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfull of both. I know you will do him such ample justice, that I am
  7526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrowing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent. Your profusion
  7527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmakes me saving; and if you lament over him much longer, my heart will
  7528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe as light as a feather.”
  7529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Poor Wickham! there is such an expression of goodness in his
  7531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountenance! such an openness and gentleness in his manner!”
  7532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those
  7534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo young men. One has got all the goodness, and the other all the
  7535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappearance of it.”
  7536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never thought Mr. Darcy so deficient in the _appearance_ of it as you
  7538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tused to do.”
  7539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And yet I meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike
  7541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto him, without any reason. It is such a spur to one’s genius, such an
  7542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topening for wit, to have a dislike of that kind. One may be continually
  7543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabusive without saying anything just; but one cannot always be laughing
  7544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat a man without now and then stumbling on something witty.”
  7545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy, when you first read that letter, I am sure you could not treat
  7547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe matter as you do now.”
  7548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, I could not. I was uncomfortable enough, I may say unhappy. And
  7550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith no one to speak to about what I felt, no Jane to comfort me and say
  7551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I had not been so very weak and vain and nonsensical as I knew I
  7552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad! Oh! how I wanted you!”
  7553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How unfortunate that you should have used such very strong expressions
  7555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin speaking of Wickham to Mr. Darcy, for now they _do_ appear wholly
  7556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tundeserved.”
  7557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly. But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most
  7559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnatural consequence of the prejudices I had been encouraging. There
  7560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis one point on which I want your advice. I want to be told whether I
  7561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tought, or ought not, to make our acquaintances in general understand
  7562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s character.”
  7563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no
  7565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion for exposing him so dreadfully. What is your opinion?”
  7566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That it ought not to be attempted. Mr. Darcy has not authorised me
  7568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make his communication public. On the contrary, every particular
  7569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelative to his sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to
  7570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself; and if I endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of his
  7571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconduct, who will believe me? The general prejudice against Mr. Darcy
  7572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis so violent, that it would be the death of half the good people in
  7573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton to attempt to place him in an amiable light. I am not equal
  7574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto it. Wickham will soon be gone; and therefore it will not signify to
  7575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanyone here what he really is. Some time hence it will be all found out,
  7576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before. At
  7577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent I will say nothing about it.”
  7578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are quite right. To have his errors made public might ruin him for
  7580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever. He is now, perhaps, sorry for what he has done, and anxious to
  7581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tre-establish a character. We must not make him desperate.”
  7582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe tumult of Elizabeth’s mind was allayed by this conversation. She had
  7584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgot rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on her for a fortnight,
  7585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand was certain of a willing listener in Jane, whenever she might wish
  7586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto talk again of either. But there was still something lurking behind,
  7587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof which prudence forbade the disclosure. She dared not relate the other
  7588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf of Mr. Darcy’s letter, nor explain to her sister how sincerely she
  7589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been valued by her friend. Here was knowledge in which no one
  7590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould partake; and she was sensible that nothing less than a perfect
  7591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding between the parties could justify her in throwing off
  7592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis last encumbrance of mystery. “And then,” said she, “if that very
  7593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprobable event should ever take place, I shall merely be able to
  7594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell what Bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner himself. The
  7595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliberty of communication cannot be mine till it has lost all its value!”
  7596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was now, on being settled at home, at leisure to observe the real
  7598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstate of her sister’s spirits. Jane was not happy. She still cherished a
  7599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery tender affection for Bingley. Having never even fancied herself
  7600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin love before, her regard had all the warmth of first attachment,
  7601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, from her age and disposition, greater steadiness than most first
  7602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattachments often boast; and so fervently did she value his remembrance,
  7603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand prefer him to every other man, that all her good sense, and all her
  7604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention to the feelings of her friends, were requisite to check the
  7605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to her own
  7606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thealth and their tranquillity.
  7607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, Lizzy,” said Mrs. Bennet one day, “what is your opinion _now_ of
  7609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis sad business of Jane’s? For my part, I am determined never to speak
  7610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof it again to anybody. I told my sister Phillips so the other day. But
  7611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI cannot find out that Jane saw anything of him in London. Well, he is
  7612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta very undeserving young man--and I do not suppose there’s the least
  7613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchance in the world of her ever getting him now. There is no talk of
  7614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this coming to Netherfield again in the summer; and I have inquired of
  7615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverybody, too, who is likely to know.”
  7616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not believe he will ever live at Netherfield any more.”
  7618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh well! it is just as he chooses. Nobody wants him to come. Though I
  7620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall always say he used my daughter extremely ill; and if I was her, I
  7621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould not have put up with it. Well, my comfort is, I am sure Jane will
  7622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdie of a broken heart; and then he will be sorry for what he has done.”
  7623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut as Elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation,
  7625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe made no answer.
  7626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, Lizzy,” continued her mother, soon afterwards, “and so the
  7628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollinses live very comfortable, do they? Well, well, I only hope
  7629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit will last. And what sort of table do they keep? Charlotte is an
  7630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcellent manager, I dare say. If she is half as sharp as her
  7631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother, she is saving enough. There is nothing extravagant in _their_
  7632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thousekeeping, I dare say.”
  7633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, nothing at all.”
  7635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A great deal of good management, depend upon it. Yes, yes, _they_ will
  7637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake care not to outrun their income. _They_ will never be distressed
  7638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor money. Well, much good may it do them! And so, I suppose, they often
  7639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalk of having Longbourn when your father is dead. They look upon it as
  7640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquite their own, I dare say, whenever that happens.”
  7641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It was a subject which they could not mention before me.”
  7643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No; it would have been strange if they had; but I make no doubt they
  7645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften talk of it between themselves. Well, if they can be easy with an
  7646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testate that is not lawfully their own, so much the better. I should be
  7647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tashamed of having one that was only entailed on me.”
  7648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 41
  7652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe first week of their return was soon gone. The second began. It was
  7655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe last of the regiment’s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies
  7656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the neighbourhood were drooping apace. The dejection was almost
  7657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuniversal. The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat, drink,
  7658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand sleep, and pursue the usual course of their employments. Very
  7659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently were they reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and
  7660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia, whose own misery was extreme, and who could not comprehend such
  7661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thard-heartedness in any of the family.
  7662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good Heaven! what is to become of us? What are we to do?” would they
  7664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toften exclaim in the bitterness of woe. “How can you be smiling so,
  7665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy?”
  7666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir affectionate mother shared all their grief; she remembered what
  7668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had herself endured on a similar occasion, five-and-twenty years
  7669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tago.
  7670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel
  7672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiller’s regiment went away. I thought I should have broken my heart.”
  7673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sure I shall break _mine_,” said Lydia.
  7675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If one could but go to Brighton!” observed Mrs. Bennet.
  7677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes!--if one could but go to Brighton! But papa is so
  7679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable.”
  7680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A little sea-bathing would set me up forever.”
  7682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And my aunt Phillips is sure it would do _me_ a great deal of good,”
  7684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t added Kitty.
  7685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSuch were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through
  7687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn House. Elizabeth tried to be diverted by them; but all sense
  7688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof pleasure was lost in shame. She felt anew the justice of Mr. Darcy’s
  7689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjections; and never had she been so much disposed to pardon his
  7690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterference in the views of his friend.
  7691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut the gloom of Lydia’s prospect was shortly cleared away; for she
  7693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the colonel of
  7694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe regiment, to accompany her to Brighton. This invaluable friend was a
  7695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery young woman, and very lately married. A resemblance in good humour
  7696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand good spirits had recommended her and Lydia to each other, and out of
  7697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir _three_ months’ acquaintance they had been intimate _two_.
  7698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe rapture of Lydia on this occasion, her adoration of Mrs. Forster,
  7700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe delight of Mrs. Bennet, and the mortification of Kitty, are scarcely
  7701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be described. Wholly inattentive to her sister’s feelings, Lydia
  7702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tflew about the house in restless ecstasy, calling for everyone’s
  7703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcongratulations, and laughing and talking with more violence than ever;
  7704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repined at her fate
  7705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin terms as unreasonable as her accent was peevish.
  7706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot see why Mrs. Forster should not ask _me_ as well as Lydia,”
  7708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t said she, “Though I am _not_ her particular friend. I have just as much
  7709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tright to be asked as she has, and more too, for I am two years older.”
  7710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn vain did Elizabeth attempt to make her reasonable, and Jane to make
  7712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther resigned. As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation was so far from
  7713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texciting in her the same feelings as in her mother and Lydia, that she
  7714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidered it as the death warrant of all possibility of common sense
  7715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the latter; and detestable as such a step must make her were it
  7716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknown, she could not help secretly advising her father not to let her
  7717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgo. She represented to him all the improprieties of Lydia’s general
  7718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour, the little advantage she could derive from the friendship of
  7719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a woman as Mrs. Forster, and the probability of her being yet more
  7720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must
  7721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe greater than at home. He heard her attentively, and then said:
  7722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lydia will never be easy until she has exposed herself in some public
  7724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplace or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so
  7725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle expense or inconvenience to her family as under the present
  7726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances.”
  7727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you were aware,” said Elizabeth, “of the very great disadvantage to
  7729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus all which must arise from the public notice of Lydia’s unguarded and
  7730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudent manner--nay, which has already arisen from it, I am sure you
  7731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould judge differently in the affair.”
  7732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Already arisen?” repeated Mr. Bennet. “What, has she frightened away
  7734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome of your lovers? Poor little Lizzy! But do not be cast down. Such

  7736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare not worth a regret. Come, let me see the list of pitiful fellows who
  7737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been kept aloof by Lydia’s folly.”
  7738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed you are mistaken. I have no such injuries to resent. It is not
  7740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof particular, but of general evils, which I am now complaining. Our

  7742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twild volatility, the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark

  7746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther life, she will soon be beyond the reach of amendment. Her character
  7747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be fixed, and she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt

  7756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey are known, and that their sisters will not be often involved in the
  7757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisgrace?”
  7758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet saw that her whole heart was in the subject, and
  7760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffectionately taking her hand said in reply:
  7761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do not make yourself uneasy, my love. Wherever you and Jane are known
  7763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less

  7765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsisters. We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to
  7766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBrighton. Let her go, then. Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will
  7767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkeep her out of any real mischief; and she is luckily too poor to be an
  7768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobject of prey to anybody. At Brighton she will be of less importance
  7769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teven as a common flirt than she has been here. The officers will find
  7770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twomen better worth their notice. Let us hope, therefore, that her being
  7771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere may teach her her own insignificance. At any rate, she cannot grow
  7772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany degrees worse, without authorising us to lock her up for the rest
  7773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her life.”
  7774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion
  7776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry. It was not
  7777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on
  7778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem. She was confident of having performed her duty, and to fret
  7779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her
  7780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisposition.
  7781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHad Lydia and her mother known the substance of her conference with her
  7783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their

  7785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery possibility of earthly happiness. She saw, with the creative eye
  7786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers.
  7787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe saw herself the object of attention, to tens and to scores of them
  7788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat present unknown. She saw all the glories of the camp--its tents
  7789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young
  7790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, she
  7791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaw herself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six
  7792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tofficers at once.
  7793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHad she known her sister sought to tear her from such prospects and such
  7795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trealities as these, what would have been her sensations? They could have
  7796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen understood only by her mother, who might have felt nearly the same.
  7797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia’s going to Brighton was all that consoled her for her melancholy
  7798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconviction of her husband’s never intending to go there himself.
  7799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures
  7801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lydia’s leaving
  7802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome.
  7803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was now to see Mr. Wickham for the last time. Having been
  7805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently in company with him since her return, agitation was pretty
  7806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so. She had even
  7807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlearnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted
  7808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary. In his present
  7809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour to herself, moreover, she had a fresh source of displeasure,
  7810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the inclination he soon testified of renewing those intentions which
  7811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after
  7812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat had since passed, to provoke her. She lost all concern for him in
  7813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinding herself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous
  7814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgallantry; and while she steadily repressed it, could not but feel the
  7815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever
  7816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcause, his attentions had been withdrawn, her vanity would be gratified,
  7817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her preference secured at any time by their renewal.
  7818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn the very last day of the regiment’s remaining at Meryton, he dined,
  7820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith other of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elizabeth

  7822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiry as to the manner in which her time had passed at Hunsford, she
  7823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam’s and Mr. Darcy’s having both spent three
  7824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweeks at Rosings, and asked him, if he was acquainted with the former.
  7825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but with a moment’s
  7827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecollection and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen
  7828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man,
  7829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tasked her how she had liked him. Her answer was warmly in his favour.
  7830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith an air of indifference he soon afterwards added:
  7831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How long did you say he was at Rosings?”

  7834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nearly three weeks.”
  7835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And you saw him frequently?”
  7837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, almost every day.”
  7839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His manners are very different from his cousin’s.”
  7841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, very different. But I think Mr. Darcy improves upon acquaintance.”
  7843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed!” cried Mr. Wickham with a look which did not escape her. “And
  7845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpray, may I ask?--” But checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is
  7846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit in address that he improves? Has he deigned to add aught of civility
  7847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his ordinary style?--for I dare not hope,” he continued in a lower
  7848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand more serious tone, “that he is improved in essentials.”
  7849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, no!” said Elizabeth. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much
  7851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat he ever was.”
  7852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhile she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to
  7854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trejoice over her words, or to distrust their meaning. There was a
