  7859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this mind or his manners were in a state of improvement, but that, from
  7860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknowing him better, his disposition was better understood.”
  7861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated
  7863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlook; for a few minutes he was silent, till, shaking off his
  7864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tembarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of
  7865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccents:
  7866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You, who so well know my feeling towards Mr. Darcy, will readily
  7868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomprehend how sincerely I must rejoice that he is wise enough to assume
  7869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teven the _appearance_ of what is right. His pride, in that direction,
  7870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay be of service, if not to himself, to many others, for it must only
  7871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeter him from such foul misconduct as I have suffered by. I only
  7872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been
  7873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good
  7874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion and judgement he stands much in awe. His fear of her has always
  7875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toperated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be
  7876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I
  7877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam certain he has very much at heart.”
  7878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a
  7880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tslight inclination of the head. She saw that he wanted to engage her on
  7881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge
  7882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. The rest of the evening passed with the _appearance_, on his
  7883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish
  7884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a
  7885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmutual desire of never meeting again.
  7886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the party broke up, Lydia returned with Mrs. Forster to Meryton,
  7888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom whence they were to set out early the next morning. The separation
  7889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic. Kitty was the
  7890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy. Mrs.
  7891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter,
  7892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand impressive in her injunctions that she should not miss the
  7893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible--advice which
  7894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was every reason to believe would be well attended to; and in
  7895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more
  7896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard.
  7897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 42
  7901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHad Elizabeth’s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could
  7904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot have formed a very pleasing opinion of conjugal felicity or domestic
  7905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomfort. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance
  7906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof good humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a
  7907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twoman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in
  7908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir marriage put an end to all real affection for her. Respect,
  7909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\testeem, and confidence had vanished for ever; and all his views
  7910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof domestic happiness were overthrown. But Mr. Bennet was not of
  7911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own
  7912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudence had brought on, in any of those pleasures which too often
  7913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsole the unfortunate for their folly or their vice. He was fond of
  7914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe country and of books; and from these tastes had arisen his principal
  7915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenjoyments. To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted, than as
  7916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement. This is not
  7917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his
  7918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true
  7919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tphilosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.
  7920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her
  7922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather’s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but
  7923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of
  7924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to
  7925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbanish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation
  7926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own
  7927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchildren, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so
  7928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstrongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so
  7929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising
  7930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom so ill-judged a direction of talents; talents, which, rightly used,
  7931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even
  7932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
  7933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure she found little
  7935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment. Their parties
  7936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabroad were less varied than before, and at home she had a mother and
  7937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around
  7938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty
  7939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers
  7940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition
  7941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all
  7942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther folly and assurance by a situation of such double danger as a
  7943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twatering-place and a camp. Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what
  7944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thas been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had been
  7945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking with impatient desire did not, in taking place, bring all the
  7946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction she had promised herself. It was consequently necessary to
  7947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tname some other period for the commencement of actual felicity--to have
  7948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by
  7949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the
  7950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent, and prepare for another disappointment. Her tour to the Lakes
  7951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas now the object of her happiest thoughts; it was her best consolation
  7952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother
  7953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the
  7954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscheme, every part of it would have been perfect.
  7955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for.
  7957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWere the whole arrangement complete, my disappointment would be certain.
  7958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my
  7959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of
  7960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure realised. A scheme of which every part promises delight can
  7961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever be successful; and general disappointment is only warded off by
  7962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe defence of some little peculiar vexation.”
  7963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely
  7965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and
  7966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways very short. Those to her mother contained little else than that
  7967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were just returned from the library, where such and such officers
  7968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as
  7969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which
  7970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a
  7971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tviolent hurry, as Mrs. Forster called her, and they were going off to
  7972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe camp; and from her correspondence with her sister, there was still
  7973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless to be learnt--for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were
  7974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch too full of lines under the words to be made public.
  7975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health, good
  7977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn. Everything wore
  7978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta happier aspect. The families who had been in town for the winter came
  7979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tback again, and summer finery and summer engagements arose. Mrs. Bennet
  7980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas restored to her usual querulous serenity; and, by the middle of
  7981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJune, Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without
  7982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttears; an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth hope that by
  7983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe following Christmas she might be so tolerably reasonable as not to
  7984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious
  7985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in
  7986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton.
  7987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  7988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast
  7989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapproaching, and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter
  7990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrived from Mrs. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and
  7991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcurtailed its extent. Mr. Gardiner would be prevented by business from
  7992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsetting out till a fortnight later in July, and must be in London again
  7993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithin a month, and as that left too short a period for them to go so
  7994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfar, and see so much as they had proposed, or at least to see it with
  7995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe leisure and comfort they had built on, they were obliged to give up
  7996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe Lakes, and substitute a more contracted tour, and, according to the
  7997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent plan, were to go no farther northwards than Derbyshire. In that
  7998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcounty there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three
  7999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweeks; and to Mrs. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction. The
  8000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where
  8001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of
  8002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth,
  8003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDovedale, or the Peak.
  8004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was excessively disappointed; she had set her heart on seeing
  8006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe Lakes, and still thought there might have been time enough. But it
  8007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas her business to be satisfied--and certainly her temper to be happy;
  8008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand all was soon right again.
  8009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith the mention of Derbyshire there were many ideas connected. It was
  8011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its
  8012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\towner. “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity,
  8013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand rob it of a few petrified spars without his perceiving me.”
  8014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe period of expectation was now doubled. Four weeks were to pass away
  8016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore her uncle and aunt’s arrival. But they did pass away, and Mr.
  8017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at
  8018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn. The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two
  8019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyounger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their
  8020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcousin Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and
  8021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every
  8022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway--teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
  8023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the
  8025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement.
  8026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOne enjoyment was certain--that of suitableness of companions;
  8027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear
  8028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinconveniences--cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure--and affection
  8029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand intelligence, which might supply it among themselves if there were
  8030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointments abroad.
  8031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire,
  8033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnor of any of the remarkable places through which their route thither
  8034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlay; Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, etc. are
  8035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsufficiently known. A small part of Derbyshire is all the present
  8036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcern. To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner’s
  8037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer residence, and where she had lately learned some acquaintance
  8038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstill remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the
  8039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprincipal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton,
  8040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth found from her aunt that Pemberley was situated. It was not
  8041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin their direct road, nor more than a mile or two out of it. In
  8042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed
  8043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan inclination to see the place again. Mr. Gardiner declared his
  8044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twillingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.
  8045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard
  8047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso much?” said her aunt; “a place, too, with which so many of your
  8048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintances are connected. Wickham passed all his youth there, you
  8049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow.”
  8050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was distressed. She felt that she had no business at
  8052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it. She
  8053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust own that she was tired of seeing great houses; after going over so
  8054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany, she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.
  8055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house
  8057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trichly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but
  8058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe grounds are delightful. They have some of the finest woods in the
  8059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcountry.”
  8060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth said no more--but her mind could not acquiesce. The
  8062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossibility of meeting Mr. Darcy, while viewing the place, instantly
  8063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccurred. It would be dreadful! She blushed at the very idea, and
  8064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt than to run such
  8065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta risk. But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved
  8066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries to the
  8067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsence of the family were unfavourably answered.
  8068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAccordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid
  8070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhether Pemberley were not a very fine place? what was the name of its
  8071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproprietor? and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for
  8072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question--and her
  8073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talarms now being removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of
  8074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcuriosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the
  8075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnext morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and
  8076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike
  8077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the scheme. To Pemberley, therefore, they were to go.
  8078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 43
  8082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of
  8085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned
  8086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
  8087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe park was very large, and contained great variety of ground. They
  8089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through
  8090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.
  8091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired
  8093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery remarkable spot and point of view. They gradually ascended for
  8094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf-a-mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable
  8095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by
  8096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley House, situated on the opposite side of a valley, into which
  8097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome stone
  8098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbuilding, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of
  8099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thigh woody hills; and in front, a stream of some natural importance was
  8100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tswelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance. Its banks
  8101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere neither formal nor falsely adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She
  8102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural
  8103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were
  8104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that
  8105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
  8106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and,
  8108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of
  8109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been
  8110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the
  8111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to
  8112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twonder at her being where she was.
  8113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe housekeeper came; a respectable-looking elderly woman, much less
  8115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her. They
  8116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollowed her into the dining-parlour. It was a large, well proportioned
  8117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troom, handsomely fitted up. Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went
  8118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto a window to enjoy its prospect. The hill, crowned with wood, which
  8119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the distance,
  8120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas a beautiful object. Every disposition of the ground was good; and
  8121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its
  8122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbanks and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it,
  8123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith delight. As they passed into other rooms these objects were taking
  8124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifferent positions; but from every window there were beauties to be
  8125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen. The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to
  8126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe fortune of its proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of
  8127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine; with less of
  8128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsplendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.
  8129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress! With
  8131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese rooms I might now have been familiarly acquainted! Instead of
  8132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tviewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and
  8133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twelcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt. But no,”--recollecting
  8134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself--“that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to
  8135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
  8136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was a lucky recollection--it saved her from something very like
  8138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregret.
  8139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master was really
  8141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsent, but had not the courage for it. At length however, the question
  8142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs.
  8143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tReynolds replied that he was, adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with
  8144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own
  8145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjourney had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
  8146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer aunt now called her to look at a picture. She approached and saw the
  8148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures,
  8149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover the mantelpiece. Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it.
  8150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe housekeeper came forward, and told them it was a picture of a young
  8151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who had been brought
  8152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” she added;
  8153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
  8154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not
  8156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturn it.
  8157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures,
  8159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“is my master--and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the
  8160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother--about eight years ago.”
  8161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said Mrs. Gardiner,
  8163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking at the picture; “it is a handsome face. But, Lizzy, you can tell
  8164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus whether it is like or not.”
  8165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Reynolds respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this
  8167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintimation of her knowing her master.
  8168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?”
  8170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth coloured, and said: “A little.”
  8172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
  8174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, very handsome.”
  8176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sure I know none so handsome; but in the gallery up stairs you
  8178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill see a finer, larger picture of him than this. This room was my late
  8179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster’s favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to
  8180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe then. He was very fond of them.”
  8181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis accounted to Elizabeth for Mr. Wickham’s being among them.
  8183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Miss Darcy, drawn
  8185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen she was only eight years old.
  8186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?” said Mrs. Gardiner.
  8188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! yes--the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so
  8190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccomplished!--She plays and sings all day long. In the next room is
  8191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta new instrument just come down for her--a present from my master; she
  8192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomes here to-morrow with him.”
  8193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner, whose manners were very easy and pleasant, encouraged her
  8195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcommunicativeness by his questions and remarks; Mrs. Reynolds, either
  8196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of her
  8197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster and his sister.
  8198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?”
  8200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not so much as I could wish, sir; but I dare say he may spend half his
  8202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.”
  8203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Except,” thought Elizabeth, “when she goes to Ramsgate.”
  8205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If your master would marry, you might see more of him.”
  8207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, sir; but I do not know when _that_ will be. I do not know who is
  8209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood enough for him.”
  8210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled. Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is
  8212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”
  8213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I say no more than the truth, and everybody will say that knows him,”
  8215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t replied the other. Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far; and she
  8216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlistened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have
  8217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever known a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever
  8218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsince he was four years old.”
  8219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was praise, of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to her
  8221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tideas. That he was not a good-tempered man had been her firmest opinion.
  8222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer keenest attention was awakened; she longed to hear more, and was
  8223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrateful to her uncle for saying:
  8224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There are very few people of whom so much can be said. You are lucky in
  8226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving such a master.”
  8227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, sir, I know I am. If I were to go through the world, I could
  8229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot meet with a better. But I have always observed, that they who are
  8230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and
  8231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was always the sweetest-tempered, most generous-hearted boy in the
  8232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld.”
  8233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth almost stared at her. “Can this be Mr. Darcy?” thought she.
  8235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“His father was an excellent man,” said Mrs. Gardiner.
  8237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, ma’am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just
  8239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas affable to the poor.”
  8240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more. Mrs.
  8242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tReynolds could interest her on no other point. She related the subjects

  8244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfurniture, in vain. Mr. Gardiner, highly amused by the kind of family
  8245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprejudice to which he attributed her excessive commendation of her
  8246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster, soon led again to the subject; and she dwelt with energy on his
  8247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany merits as they proceeded together up the great staircase.
  8248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  8250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlived; not like the wild young men nowadays, who think of nothing but
  8251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthemselves. There is not one of his tenants or servants but will give
  8252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim a good name. Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never saw
  8253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything of it. To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle away
  8254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlike other young men.”

  8260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps we might be deceived.”
  8262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is not very likely; our authority was too good.”
  8264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn reaching the spacious lobby above they were shown into a very pretty

  8277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis nothing he would not do for her.”
  8278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe picture-gallery, and two or three of the principal bedrooms, were

  8283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy’s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and

  8300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof an intelligent servant? As a brother, a landlord, a master, she
  8301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidered how many people’s happiness were in his guardianship!--how

  8307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgratitude than it had ever raised before; she remembered its warmth, and

  8309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  8314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs they walked across the hall towards the river, Elizabeth turned back

  8319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were within twenty yards of each other, and so abrupt was his

  8321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly met, and the cheeks of both were overspread with the deepest
  8322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tblush. He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from

  8324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least
  8325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof perfect civility.

  8327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach,

  8329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tovercome. Had his first appearance, or his resemblance to the picture

  8336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that
  8337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the uttered was increasing her embarrassment; and every idea of the

  8342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the time of her having left Longbourn, and of her having stayed in
  8343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDerbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the

  8347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoments without saying a word, he suddenly recollected himself, and took

  8350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe others then joined her, and expressed admiration of his figure; but
  8351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth heard not a word, and wholly engrossed by her own feelings,

  8354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld! How strange it must appear to him! In what a disgraceful light

  8364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNever in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never

  8369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and

  8377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Mr. Darcy then
  8378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas. She longed to know what at the moment was passing in his mind--in

  8381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelt himself at ease; yet there had been _that_ in his voice which was
  8382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot like ease. Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in
  8383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeing her she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with

  8385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind

  8393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany, and occasionally part of the stream. Mr. Gardiner expressed a wish

  8397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods,
  8398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts. They crossed
  8399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit by a simple bridge, in character with the general air of the scene;
  8400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited; and the
  8401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvalley, here contracted into a glen, allowed room only for the stream,
  8402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice-wood which bordered it.
  8403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the
  8404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Mrs. Gardiner,
  8405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only

  8407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house

  8409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprogress was slow, for Mr. Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the
  8410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttaste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the

  8414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Mr. Darcy
  8415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapproaching them, and at no great distance. The walk being here
  8416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless sheltered than on the other side, allowed them to see him before

  8418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with
  8419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalmness, if he really intended to meet them. For a few moments, indeed,
  8420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe felt that he would probably strike into some other path. The idea
  8421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlasted while a turning in the walk concealed him from their view; the
  8422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturning past, he was immediately before them. With a glance, she saw
  8423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his
  8424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoliteness, she began, as they met, to admire the beauty of the place;
  8425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when
  8426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of
  8427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley from her might be mischievously construed. Her colour changed,
  8428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she said no more.
  8429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked
  8431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends.
  8432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared;
  8433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the
  8434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance of some of those very people against whom his pride had
  8435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trevolted in his offer to herself. “What will be his surprise,” thought
  8436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe, “when he knows who they are? He takes them now for people of
  8437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfashion.”
  8438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their
  8440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore
  8441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he
  8442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould from such disgraceful companions. That he was _surprised_ by the
  8443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnection was evident; he sustained it, however, with fortitude, and
  8444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso far from going away, turned back with them, and entered into
  8445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation with Mr. Gardiner. Elizabeth could not but be pleased,
  8446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not but triumph. It was consoling that he should know she had
  8447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome relations for whom there was no need to blush. She listened most
  8448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every
  8449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence,
  8450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this taste, or his good manners.
  8451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard Mr. Darcy
  8453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he
  8454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchose while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time
  8455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of
  8456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe stream where there was usually most sport. Mrs. Gardiner, who was
  8457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalking arm-in-arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of wonder.
  8458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment
  8459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust be all for herself. Her astonishment, however, was extreme, and
  8460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered? From what can
  8461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit proceed? It cannot be for _me_--it cannot be for _my_ sake that his
  8462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not work such a
  8463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchange as this. It is impossible that he should still love me.”
  8464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two
  8466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to
  8467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious
  8468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twater-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration. It originated
  8469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found
  8470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred
  8471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther husband’s. Mr. Darcy took her place by her niece, and they walked on
  8472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether. After a short silence, the lady first spoke. She wished him
  8473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the
  8474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplace, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been
  8475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery unexpected--“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that
  8476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and indeed, before we
  8477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleft Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected
  8478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all, and said that
  8479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours
  8480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They
  8481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some
  8482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho will claim an acquaintance with you--Mr. Bingley and his sisters.”
  8483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth answered only by a slight bow. Her thoughts were instantly
  8485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdriven back to the time when Mr. Bingley’s name had been the last
  8486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned between them; and, if she might judge by his complexion, _his_
  8487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmind was not very differently engaged.
  8488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There is also one other person in the party,” he continued after a
  8490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpause, “who more particularly wishes to be known to you. Will you allow
  8491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance
  8492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tduring your stay at Lambton?”
  8493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great
  8495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her to know in what manner she acceded to it. She immediately felt
  8496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her
  8497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust be the work of her brother, and, without looking farther, it was
  8498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made
  8499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim think really ill of her.
  8500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey now walked on in silence, each of them deep in thought. Elizabeth
  8502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and
  8503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleased. His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of
  8504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe highest kind. They soon outstripped the others, and when they had
  8505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were half a quarter of a
  8506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmile behind.
  8507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe then asked her to walk into the house--but she declared herself not
  8509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttired, and they stood together on the lawn. At such a time much might
  8510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been said, and silence was very awkward. She wanted to talk, but
  8511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere seemed to be an embargo on every subject. At last she recollected
  8512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dove Dale
  8513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith great perseverance. Yet time and her aunt moved slowly--and her
  8514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpatience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the tete-a-tete was
  8515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tover. On Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s coming up they were all pressed to go
  8516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and
  8517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey parted on each side with utmost politeness. Mr. Darcy handed the
  8518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him
  8519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twalking slowly towards the house.
  8520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them
  8522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.
  8523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is perfectly well behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.
  8524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There _is_ something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her
  8526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt, “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now
  8527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud, I
  8528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave seen nothing of it.”
  8529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more
  8531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such
  8532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
  8533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham;
  8535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor, rather, he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features
  8536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare perfectly good. But how came you to tell me that he was so
  8537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable?”
  8538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth excused herself as well as she could; said that she had liked
  8540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim better when they had met in Kent than before, and that she had never
  8541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen him so pleasant as this morning.
  8542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied
  8544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him
  8545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat his word, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off
  8546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this grounds.”
  8547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth felt that they had entirely misunderstood his character, but
  8549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid nothing.
  8550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really
  8552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by
  8553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanybody as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured look.
  8554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he
  8555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance that would
  8556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the
  8557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood lady who showed us his house did give him a most flaming character!
  8558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal
  8559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster, I suppose, and _that_ in the eye of a servant comprehends every
  8560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvirtue.”
  8561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of
  8563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this behaviour to Wickham; and therefore gave them to understand, in
  8564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from
  8565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different
  8566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconstruction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor
  8567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In
  8568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary
  8569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttransactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming
  8570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
  8571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned; but as they were now
  8573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapproaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to
  8574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out
  8575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her husband all the interesting spots in its environs to think of
  8576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk they
  8577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former
  8578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of a
  8579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
  8580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth
  8582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing
  8583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above
  8584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.
  8585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 44
  8589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit
  8592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was consequently
  8593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.
  8594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their
  8595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrival at Lambton, these visitors came. They had been walking about the
  8596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplace with some of their new friends, and were just returning to the inn
  8597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a
  8598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcarriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and a lady in
  8599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta curricle driving up the street. Elizabeth immediately recognizing
  8600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of her
  8601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprise to her relations by acquainting them with the honour which she
  8602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpected. Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment
  8603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many
  8604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on
  8605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe business. Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they felt that
  8606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a
  8607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece. While these
  8608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnewly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of
  8609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s feelings was at every moment increasing. She was quite
  8610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamazed at her own discomposure; but amongst other causes of disquiet,
  8611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much
  8612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally
  8613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
  8614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked
  8616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of
  8617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.
  8618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction
  8620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook place. With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new
  8621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself. Since her
  8622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud;
  8623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was
  8624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly exceedingly shy. She found it difficult to obtain even a word from
  8625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther beyond a monosyllable.
  8626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though
  8628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance
  8629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twomanly and graceful. She was less handsome than her brother; but there
  8630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas sense and good humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly
  8631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunassuming and gentle. Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as
  8632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much
  8633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelieved by discerning such different feelings.
  8634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey had not long been together before Mr. Darcy told her that Bingley
  8636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her
  8637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick
  8638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstep was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. All
  8639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still
  8640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected
  8641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again. He
  8642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquired in a friendly, though general way, after her family, and looked
  8643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
  8644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage
  8646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan to herself. They had long wished to see him. The whole party before
  8647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem, indeed, excited a lively attention. The suspicions which had just
  8648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece directed their observation towards
  8649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach with an earnest though guarded inquiry; and they soon drew from
  8650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthose inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew
  8651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat it was to love. Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little
  8652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was
  8653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevident enough.
  8654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, on her side, had much to do. She wanted to ascertain the
  8656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings of each of her visitors; she wanted to compose her own, and
  8657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she
  8658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she
  8659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tendeavoured to give pleasure were prepossessed in her favour. Bingley
  8660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.
  8661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and, oh!
  8663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in
  8664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta like manner. Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on
  8665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion
  8666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance. But,
  8667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his
  8668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane. No look
  8669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappeared on either side that spoke particular regard. Nothing occurred
  8670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween them that could justify the hopes of his sister. On this point
  8671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred
  8672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a
  8673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecollection of Jane not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying
  8674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared. He observed
  8675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone
  8676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since
  8677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply,
  8678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the added, “It is above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of
  8679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNovember, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
  8680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards
  8682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether
  8683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_all_ her sisters were at Longbourn. There was not much in the question,
  8684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which
  8685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgave them meaning.
  8686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself;
  8688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut, whenever she did catch a glimpse, she saw an expression of general
  8689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplaisance, and in all that he said she heard an accent so removed
  8690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom _hauteur_ or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that
  8691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed however
  8692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day. When
  8693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe saw him thus seeking the acquaintance and courting the good opinion
  8694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a
  8695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisgrace--when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the
  8696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last
  8697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlively scene in Hunsford Parsonage--the difference, the change was
  8698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly
  8699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trestrain her astonishment from being visible. Never, even in the company
  8700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations
  8701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from
  8702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tself-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance
  8703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the
  8704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed would draw
  8705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdown the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and
  8706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tRosings.
  8707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir visitors stayed with them above half-an-hour; and when they arose
  8709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing
  8710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner
  8711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Pemberley, before they left the country. Miss Darcy, though with a
  8712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations,
  8713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treadily obeyed. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing
  8714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow _she_, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its
  8715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head. Presuming however,
  8716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than
  8717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of
  8718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsociety, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for
  8719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.
  8720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth
  8722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to
  8723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake after all their Hertfordshire friends. Elizabeth, construing all
  8724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased, and on
  8725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis account, as well as some others, found herself, when their
  8726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitors left them, capable of considering the last half-hour with some
  8727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction, though while it was passing, the enjoyment of it had been
  8728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle. Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her
  8729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their
  8730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
  8731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was
  8733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot their wish to force her communication. It was evident that she was
  8734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of;
  8735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was evident that he was very much in love with her. They saw much to
  8736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest, but nothing to justify inquiry.
  8737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOf Mr. Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far
  8739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find. They could
  8740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character
  8741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom their own feelings and his servant’s report, without any reference
  8742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known
  8743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould not have recognized it for Mr. Darcy. There was now an interest,
  8744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible
  8745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the authority of a servant who had known him since he was four
  8746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyears old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be
  8747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thastily rejected. Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of
  8748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight. They had
  8749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not,
  8750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market-town
  8751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere the family did not visit. It was acknowledged, however, that he
  8752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.
  8753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held
  8755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the
  8756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tson of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known
  8757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind
  8758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, which Mr. Darcy afterwards discharged.
  8759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than
  8761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not
  8762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong enough to determine her feelings towards _one_ in that mansion;
  8763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she lay awake two whole hours endeavouring to make them out. She
  8764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertainly did not hate him. No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she
  8765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him,
  8766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat could be so called. The respect created by the conviction of his
  8767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvaluable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some
  8768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttime ceased to be repugnant to her feeling; and it was now heightened
  8769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto somewhat of a friendlier nature, by the testimony so highly in
  8770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light,
  8771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich yesterday had produced. But above all, above respect and esteem,
