  8772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere was a motive within her of goodwill which could not be overlooked.
  8773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was gratitude; gratitude, not merely for having once loved her,
  8774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and
  8775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations
  8776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccompanying her rejection. He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid
  8777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most
  8778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teager to preserve the acquaintance, and without any indelicate display
  8779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only
  8780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent
  8781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton making her known to his sister. Such a change in a man of so much
  8782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpride exciting not only astonishment but gratitude--for to love, ardent
  8783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlove, it must be attributed; and as such its impression on her was of a
  8784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be
  8785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texactly defined. She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him,
  8786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how
  8787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfar she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would
  8788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her
  8789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on her the renewal of
  8790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this addresses.
  8791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt had been settled in the evening between the aunt and the niece, that
  8793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s in coming to see them on the
  8794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery day of her arrival at Pemberley, for she had reached it only to a
  8795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlate breakfast, ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled,
  8796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that
  8797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following
  8798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning. They were, therefore, to go. Elizabeth was pleased; though when
  8799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
  8800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner left them soon after breakfast. The fishing scheme had been
  8802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trenewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting
  8803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome of the gentlemen at Pemberley before noon.
  8804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 45
  8808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tConvinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had
  8811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toriginated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how unwelcome her
  8812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how
  8813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.
  8814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon,
  8816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer. Its windows
  8817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody
  8818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts
  8819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
  8820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn this house they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there
  8822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in
  8823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon. Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with
  8824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall the embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear
  8825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior
  8826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe belief of her being proud and reserved. Mrs. Gardiner and her niece,
  8827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, did her justice, and pitied her.
  8828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBy Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a curtsey; and,
  8830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be,
  8831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsucceeded for a few moments. It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a
  8832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgenteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind
  8833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the
  8834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from
  8835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, the conversation was carried on. Miss Darcy looked as if she
  8836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a
  8837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshort sentence when there was least danger of its being heard.
  8838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley,
  8840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without
  8841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalling her attention. This observation would not have prevented her
  8842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an
  8843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity
  8844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof saying much. Her own thoughts were employing her. She expected every
  8845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room. She wished, she
  8846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeared that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether
  8847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine. After
  8848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsitting in this manner a quarter of an hour without hearing Miss
  8849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold
  8850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiry after the health of her family. She answered with equal
  8851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
  8852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the
  8854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the
  8855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many
  8856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been
  8857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgiven, to remind her of her post. There was now employment for the whole
  8858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty--for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the
  8859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches soon collected
  8860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem round the table.
  8861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhile thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether
  8863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the
  8864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but
  8865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to
  8866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregret that he came.
  8867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other
  8869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river, and had left him
  8870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to
  8871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGeorgiana that morning. No sooner did he appear than Elizabeth wisely
  8872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed; a resolution the more
  8873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she
  8874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them,
  8875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour
  8876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen he first came into the room. In no countenance was attentive
  8877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcuriosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the
  8878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its
  8879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions
  8880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Mr. Darcy were by no means over. Miss Darcy, on her brother’s
  8881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentrance, exerted herself much more to talk, and Elizabeth saw that he
  8882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded
  8883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side. Miss
  8884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the
  8885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst opportunity of saying, with sneering civility:
  8886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire Militia removed from Meryton?
  8888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey must be a great loss to _your_ family.”
  8889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name; but Elizabeth
  8891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the
  8892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvarious recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress;
  8893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she
  8894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresently answered the question in a tolerably detached tone. While
  8895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy, with a heightened
  8896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with
  8897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfusion, and unable to lift up her eyes. Had Miss Bingley known what
  8898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would
  8899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose
  8900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed
  8901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in
  8902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies
  8903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand absurdities by which some part of her family were connected
  8904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith that corps. Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy’s
  8905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeditated elopement. To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy
  8906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley’s connections
  8907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from the very
  8908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming
  8909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thereafter her own. He had certainly formed such a plan, and without
  8910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss
  8911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern
  8912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the welfare of his friend.
  8913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and
  8915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to
  8916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able
  8917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto speak any more. Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely
  8918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecollected her interest in the affair, and the very circumstance which
  8919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth seemed to have
  8920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfixed them on her more and more cheerfully.
  8921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir visit did not continue long after the question and answer above
  8923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage Miss
  8924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s person,
  8925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour, and dress. But Georgiana would not join her. Her brother’s
  8926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trecommendation was enough to ensure her favour; his judgement could not
  8927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\terr. And he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth as to leave Georgiana
  8928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable. When
  8929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help repeating to
  8930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim some part of what she had been saying to his sister.
  8931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How very ill Miss Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” she
  8933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcried; “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since
  8934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe winter. She is grown so brown and coarse! Louisa and I were agreeing
  8935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat we should not have known her again.”
  8936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHowever little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented
  8938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself with coolly replying that he perceived no other alteration than
  8939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther being rather tanned, no miraculous consequence of travelling in the
  8940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsummer.
  8941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could
  8943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee any beauty in her. Her face is too thin; her complexion has no
  8944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome. Her nose
  8945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twants character--there is nothing marked in its lines. Her teeth are
  8946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes,
  8947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich have sometimes been called so fine, I could never see anything
  8948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textraordinary in them. They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do
  8949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot like at all; and in her air altogether there is a self-sufficiency
  8950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout fashion, which is intolerable.”
  8951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPersuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not
  8953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always
  8954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the
  8955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuccess she expected. He was resolutely silent, however, and, from a
  8956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermination of making him speak, she continued:
  8957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all
  8959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect
  8960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘_She_
  8961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta beauty!--I should as soon call her mother a wit.’ But afterwards she
  8962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at
  8963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone time.”
  8964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but _that_
  8966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas only when I first saw her, for it is many months since I have
  8967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”
  8968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of
  8970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.
  8971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their
  8973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them
  8974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboth. The look and behaviour of everybody they had seen were discussed,
  8975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texcept of the person who had mostly engaged their attention. They talked
  8976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit--of everything but
  8977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of
  8978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, and Mrs. Gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece’s
  8979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeginning the subject.
  8980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 46
  8984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from
  8987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been
  8988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trenewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but
  8989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the
  8990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that
  8991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit had been missent elsewhere. Elizabeth was not surprised at it, as
  8992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane had written the direction remarkably ill.
  8993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  8994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and
  8995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by
  8996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthemselves. The one missent must first be attended to; it had been
  8997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twritten five days ago. The beginning contained an account of all their
  8998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded;
  8999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident
  9000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagitation, gave more important intelligence. It was to this effect:
  9001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a
  9003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you--be
  9004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassured that we are all well. What I have to say relates to poor Lydia.
  9005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAn express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed,
  9006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland
  9007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham! Imagine our
  9008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprise. To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected. I am
  9009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery, very sorry. So imprudent a match on both sides! But I am willing
  9010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.
  9011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step
  9012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t(and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart. His choice is
  9013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.
  9014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOur poor mother is sadly grieved. My father bears it better. How
  9015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthankful am I that we never let them know what has been said against
  9016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim; we must forget it ourselves. They were off Saturday night about
  9017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at
  9018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teight. The express was sent off directly. My dear Lizzy, they must have
  9019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpassed within ten miles of us. Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect
  9020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim here soon. Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of
  9021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir intention. I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor
  9022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother. I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly
  9023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow what I have written.”
  9024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWithout allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing
  9026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat she felt, Elizabeth on finishing this letter instantly seized the
  9027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it
  9028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.
  9029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I
  9031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my
  9032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thead is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent. Dearest
  9033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you,
  9034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand it cannot be delayed. Imprudent as the marriage between Mr. Wickham
  9035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand our poor Lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has
  9036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttaken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone
  9037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Scotland. Colonel Forster came yesterday, having left Brighton the
  9038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday before, not many hours after the express. Though Lydia’s short
  9039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter to Mrs. F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna
  9040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGreen, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W.
  9041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever intended to go there, or to marry Lydia at all, which was
  9042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepeated to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B.
  9043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintending to trace their route. He did trace them easily to Clapham,
  9044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut no further; for on entering that place, they removed into a hackney
  9045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoach, and dismissed the chaise that brought them from Epsom. All that
  9046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis known after this is, that they were seen to continue the London road.
  9047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI know not what to think. After making every possible inquiry on that
  9048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside London, Colonel F. came on into Hertfordshire, anxiously renewing
  9049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem at all the turnpikes, and at the inns in Barnet and Hatfield, but
  9050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout any success--no such people had been seen to pass through. With
  9051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe kindest concern he came on to Longbourn, and broke his apprehensions
  9052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto us in a manner most creditable to his heart. I am sincerely grieved
  9053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor him and Mrs. F., but no one can throw any blame on them. Our
  9054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistress, my dear Lizzy, is very great. My father and mother believe the
  9055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworst, but I cannot think so ill of him. Many circumstances might make
  9056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue
  9057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir first plan; and even if _he_ could form such a design against a
  9058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyoung woman of Lydia’s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose
  9059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther so lost to everything? Impossible! I grieve to find, however, that
  9060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel F. is not disposed to depend upon their marriage; he shook his
  9061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thead when I expressed my hopes, and said he feared W. was not a man to
  9062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe trusted. My poor mother is really ill, and keeps her room. Could she
  9063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texert herself, it would be better; but this is not to be expected. And
  9064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected. Poor Kitty has
  9065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of
  9066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfidence, one cannot wonder. I am truly glad, dearest Lizzy, that you
  9067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now, as the
  9068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return? I am not
  9069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso selfish, however, as to press for it, if inconvenient. Adieu! I
  9070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake up my pen again to do what I have just told you I would not; but
  9071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances are such that I cannot help earnestly begging you all to
  9072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome here as soon as possible. I know my dear uncle and aunt so well,
  9073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something
  9074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore to ask of the former. My father is going to London with Colonel
  9075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForster instantly, to try to discover her. What he means to do I am sure
  9076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI know not; but his excessive distress will not allow him to pursue any
  9077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeasure in the best and safest way, and Colonel Forster is obliged to
  9078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe at Brighton again to-morrow evening. In such an exigence, my
  9079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncle’s advice and assistance would be everything in the world; he will
  9080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness.”
  9081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! where, where is my uncle?” cried Elizabeth, darting from her seat
  9083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas she finished the letter, in eagerness to follow him, without losing
  9084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta moment of the time so precious; but as she reached the door it was
  9085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topened by a servant, and Mr. Darcy appeared. Her pale face and impetuous
  9086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner made him start, and before he could recover himself to speak,
  9087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydia’s situation,
  9088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thastily exclaimed, “I beg your pardon, but I must leave you. I must find
  9089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner this moment, on business that cannot be delayed; I have not
  9090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan instant to lose.”
  9091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than
  9093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoliteness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute;
  9094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut let me, or let the servant go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are
  9095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot well enough; you cannot go yourself.”
  9096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth hesitated, but her knees trembled under her and she felt how
  9098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle would be gained by her attempting to pursue them. Calling back
  9099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless
  9100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and
  9101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistress home instantly.
  9102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn his quitting the room she sat down, unable to support herself, and
  9104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her,
  9105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration,
  9106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let me call your maid. Is there nothing you could take to give you
  9107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent relief? A glass of wine; shall I get you one? You are very ill.”
  9108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, I thank you,” she replied, endeavouring to recover herself. “There
  9110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis nothing the matter with me. I am quite well; I am only distressed by
  9111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn.”
  9112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could
  9114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot speak another word. Darcy, in wretched suspense, could only say
  9115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomething indistinctly of his concern, and observe her in compassionate
  9116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilence. At length she spoke again. “I have just had a letter from Jane,
  9117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith such dreadful news. It cannot be concealed from anyone. My younger
  9118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister has left all her friends--has eloped; has thrown herself into
  9119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe power of--of Mr. Wickham. They are gone off together from Brighton.
  9120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_You_ know him too well to doubt the rest. She has no money, no
  9121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnections, nothing that can tempt him to--she is lost for ever.”
  9122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy was fixed in astonishment. “When I consider,” she added in a yet
  9124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore agitated voice, “that I might have prevented it! I, who knew what
  9125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was. Had I but explained some part of it only--some part of what I
  9126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlearnt, to my own family! Had his character been known, this could not
  9127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave happened. But it is all--all too late now.”
  9128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am grieved indeed,” cried Darcy; “grieved--shocked. But is it
  9130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertain--absolutely certain?”
  9131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes! They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced
  9133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost to London, but not beyond; they are certainly not gone to
  9134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tScotland.”
  9135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?”
  9137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My father is gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle’s
  9139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timmediate assistance; and we shall be off, I hope, in half-an-hour. But
  9140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing can be done--I know very well that nothing can be done. How is
  9141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a man to be worked on? How are they even to be discovered? I have
  9142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot the smallest hope. It is every way horrible!”
  9143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy shook his head in silent acquiescence.
  9145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When _my_ eyes were opened to his real character--Oh! had I known what
  9147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI ought, what I dared to do! But I knew not--I was afraid of doing too
  9148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch. Wretched, wretched mistake!”
  9149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy made no answer. He seemed scarcely to hear her, and was walking
  9151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup and down the room in earnest meditation, his brow contracted, his air
  9152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgloomy. Elizabeth soon observed, and instantly understood it. Her
  9153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpower was sinking; everything _must_ sink under such a proof of family
  9154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace. She could neither
  9155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twonder nor condemn, but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing
  9156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsolatory to her bosom, afforded no palliation of her distress. It
  9157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make her understand her own
  9158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishes; and never had she so honestly felt that she could have loved
  9159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, as now, when all love must be vain.
  9160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut self, though it would intrude, could not engross her. Lydia--the
  9162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumiliation, the misery she was bringing on them all, soon swallowed
  9163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup every private care; and covering her face with her handkerchief,
  9164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was soon lost to everything else; and, after a pause of
  9165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseveral minutes, was only recalled to a sense of her situation by
  9166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe voice of her companion, who, in a manner which, though it spoke
  9167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompassion, spoke likewise restraint, said, “I am afraid you have been
  9168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong desiring my absence, nor have I anything to plead in excuse of my
  9169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstay, but real, though unavailing concern. Would to Heaven that anything
  9170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould be either said or done on my part that might offer consolation to
  9171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch distress! But I will not torment you with vain wishes, which may
  9172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseem purposely to ask for your thanks. This unfortunate affair will, I
  9173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfear, prevent my sister’s having the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley
  9174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto-day.”
  9175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes. Be so kind as to apologise for us to Miss Darcy. Say that
  9177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\turgent business calls us home immediately. Conceal the unhappy truth as
  9178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong as it is possible, I know it cannot be long.”
  9179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe readily assured her of his secrecy; again expressed his sorrow for
  9181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther distress, wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present
  9182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treason to hope, and leaving his compliments for her relations, with only
  9183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone serious, parting look, went away.
  9184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs he quitted the room, Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that they
  9186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as
  9187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as she threw a
  9188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tretrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full
  9189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those
  9190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would
  9191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformerly have rejoiced in its termination.
  9192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIf gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elizabeth’s
  9194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchange of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty. But if
  9195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\totherwise--if regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or
  9196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on
  9197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta first interview with its object, and even before two words have been
  9198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texchanged, nothing can be said in her defence, except that she had given
  9199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomewhat of a trial to the latter method in her partiality for Wickham,
  9200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand that its ill success might, perhaps, authorise her to seek the other
  9201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless interesting mode of attachment. Be that as it may, she saw him
  9202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgo with regret; and in this early example of what Lydia’s infamy must
  9203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproduce, found additional anguish as she reflected on that wretched
  9204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness. Never, since reading Jane’s second letter, had she entertained
  9205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta hope of Wickham’s meaning to marry her. No one but Jane, she thought,
  9206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould flatter herself with such an expectation. Surprise was the least
  9207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her feelings on this development. While the contents of the first
  9208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter remained in her mind, she was all surprise--all astonishment that
  9209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham should marry a girl whom it was impossible he could marry
  9210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor money; and how Lydia could ever have attached him had appeared
  9211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincomprehensible. But now it was all too natural. For such an attachment
  9212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas this she might have sufficient charms; and though she did not suppose
  9213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement without the intention
  9214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof marriage, she had no difficulty in believing that neither her virtue
  9215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnor her understanding would preserve her from falling an easy prey.
  9216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that
  9218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia had any partiality for him; but she was convinced that Lydia
  9219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted only encouragement to attach herself to anybody. Sometimes one
  9220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tofficer, sometimes another, had been her favourite, as their attentions
  9221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\traised them in her opinion. Her affections had continually been
  9222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfluctuating but never without an object. The mischief of neglect and
  9223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistaken indulgence towards such a girl--oh! how acutely did she now
  9224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeel it!
  9225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was wild to be at home--to hear, to see, to be upon the spot to
  9227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshare with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon her, in a
  9228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily so deranged, a father absent, a mother incapable of exertion, and
  9229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trequiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing
  9230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould be done for Lydia, her uncle’s interference seemed of the utmost
  9231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportance, and till he entered the room her impatience was severe. Mr.
  9232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Mrs. Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing by the servant’s
  9233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccount that their niece was taken suddenly ill; but satisfying them
  9234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstantly on that head, she eagerly communicated the cause of their
  9235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsummons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript
  9236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the last with trembling energy.--Though Lydia had never been a
  9237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourite with them, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner could not but be deeply
  9238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafflicted. Not Lydia only, but all were concerned in it; and after the
  9239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner promised every
  9240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassistance in his power. Elizabeth, though expecting no less, thanked
  9241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit,
  9242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything relating to their journey was speedily settled. They were to
  9243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe off as soon as possible. “But what is to be done about Pemberley?”
  9244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t cried Mrs. Gardiner. “John told us Mr. Darcy was here when you sent for
  9245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus; was it so?”
  9246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.
  9248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_That_ is all settled.”
  9249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is all settled?” repeated the other, as she ran into her room to
  9251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprepare. “And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real
  9252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttruth? Oh, that I knew how it was!”
  9253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut wishes were vain, or at least could only serve to amuse her in the
  9255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thurry and confusion of the following hour. Had Elizabeth been at leisure
  9256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was
  9257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of
  9258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to
  9259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their
  9260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsudden departure. An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and Mr.
  9261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner meanwhile having settled his account at the inn, nothing
  9262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremained to be done but to go; and Elizabeth, after all the misery of
  9263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe morning, found herself, in a shorter space of time than she could
  9264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.
  9265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 47
  9269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they
  9272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much
  9273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does on the
  9274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmatter. It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should
  9275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tform such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or
  9276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriendless, and who was actually staying in his colonel’s family, that I
  9277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends
  9278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the
  9279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is
  9280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot adequate to the risk!”
  9281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
  9283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s
  9285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and
  9286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest, for him to be guilty of. I cannot think so very ill of
  9287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham. Can you yourself, Lizzy, so wholly give him up, as to believe
  9288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim capable of it?”
  9289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not, perhaps, of neglecting his own interest; but of every other
  9291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneglect I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I
  9292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdare not hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland if that had been
  9293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe case?”
  9294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In the first place,” replied Mr. Gardiner, “there is no absolute proof
  9296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat they are not gone to Scotland.”
  9297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! but their removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such
  9299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta presumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the
  9300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBarnet road.”
  9301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, then--supposing them to be in London. They may be there, though
  9303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptional purpose. It is
  9304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it
  9305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight strike them that they could be more economically, though less
  9306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpeditiously, married in London than in Scotland.”
  9307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their
  9309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage be private? Oh, no, no--this is not likely. His most particular
  9310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend, you see by Jane’s account, was persuaded of his never intending
  9311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He
  9312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia--what attraction has she
  9313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeyond youth, health, and good humour that could make him, for her sake,
  9314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what
  9315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trestraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a
  9316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know
  9317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your
  9318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has
  9319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s
  9320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever
  9321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would
  9322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in
  9323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a matter.”
  9324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him
  9326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to consent to live with him on any terms other than marriage?”
  9327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with
  9329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttears in her eyes, “that a sister’s sense of decency and virtue in such
  9330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say.
  9331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPerhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young; she has never
  9332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half-year,
  9333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnay, for a twelvemonth--she has been given up to nothing but amusement
  9334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle
  9335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.
  9336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSince the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love,
  9337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tflirtation, and officers have been in her head. She has been doing
  9338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything in her power by thinking and talking on the subject, to give
  9339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreater--what shall I call it? susceptibility to her feelings; which are
  9340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnaturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of
  9341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperson and address that can captivate a woman.”
  9342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so very ill of
  9344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
  9345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be
  9347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir former conduct, that she would think capable of such an attempt,
  9348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what
  9349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every
  9350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsense of the word; that he has neither integrity nor honour; that he is
  9351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas false and deceitful as he is insinuating.”
  9352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity
  9354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
  9355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring. “I told you, the other day,
  9357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you yourself, when last at
  9358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved
  9359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other
  9360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances which I am not at liberty--which it is not worth while to
  9361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From
  9362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat he said of Miss Darcy I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud,
  9363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He
  9364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found
  9365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther.”
  9366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But does Lydia know nothing of this? can she be ignorant of what you
  9368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Jane seem so well to understand?”
  9369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes!--that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw
  9371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was
  9372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home, the ----shire
  9373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight’s time. As that was the
  9374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcase, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it
  9375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could
  9376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit apparently be to any one, that the good opinion which all the
  9377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhood had of him should then be overthrown? And even when it was
  9378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening
  9379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther eyes to his character never occurred to me. That _she_ could be
  9380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a
  9381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequence as _this_ could ensue, you may easily believe, was far
  9382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough from my thoughts.”
  9383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I
  9385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuppose, to believe them fond of each other?”
  9386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either
  9388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside; and had anything of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware
  9389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat ours is not a family on which it could be thrown away. When first
  9390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all
  9391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere. Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for
  9392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe first two months; but he never distinguished _her_ by any particular
  9393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and
  9394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment,
  9395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”
  9396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
  9398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added
  9400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject, by
  9401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tits repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during
  9402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole of the journey. From Elizabeth’s thoughts it was never absent.
  9403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find
  9404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno interval of ease or forgetfulness.
  9405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey travelled as expeditiously as possible, and, sleeping one night
  9407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the road, reached Longbourn by dinner time the next day. It was a
  9408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied
  9409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby long expectations.
  9410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing
  9412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the steps of the house as they entered the paddock; and, when the
  9413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcarriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their
  9414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfaces, and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of
  9415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcapers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.
  9416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth jumped out; and, after giving each of them a hasty kiss,
  9418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running down from her
  9419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother’s apartment, immediately met her.
  9420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the
  9422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been
  9423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard of the fugitives.
  9424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not yet,” replied Jane. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope
  9426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything will be well.”
  9427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is my father in town?”
  9429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, he went on Tuesday, as I wrote you word.”
  9431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And have you heard from him often?”
  9433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We have heard only twice. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday to say
  9435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I
  9436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticularly begged him to do. He merely added that he should not write
  9437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain till he had something of importance to mention.”
  9438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And my mother--how is she? How are you all?”
  9440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly
  9442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshaken. She is up stairs and will have great satisfaction in seeing you
  9443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank
  9444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHeaven, are quite well.”
  9445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you--how are you?” cried Elizabeth. “You look pale. How much you
  9447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have gone through!”
  9448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their
  9450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were
  9451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach
  9452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the whole party. Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and
  9453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
  9454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth
  9456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon
  9457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound that Jane had no intelligence to give. The sanguine hope of
  9458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested had not yet
  9459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that
  9460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father,
  9461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce their marriage.
  9462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’
  9464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with
  9465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous
  9466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage;
  9467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tblaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the
  9468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\terrors of her daughter must principally be owing.
  9469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton,
  9471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith all my family, _this_ would not have happened; but poor dear Lydia
  9472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out
  9473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their
  9474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing if she had been
  9475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have the
  9476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcharge of her; but I was overruled, as I always am. Poor dear child!
  9477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd now here’s Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham,
  9478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twherever he meets him and then he will be killed, and what is to become
  9479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof us all? The Collinses will turn us out before he is cold in his
  9480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrave, and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we
  9481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall do.”
  9482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after
  9484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgeneral assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her
  9485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr.
  9486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
  9487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do not give way to useless alarm,” added he; “though it is right to be
  9489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.
  9490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more we
  9491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay gain some news of them; and till we know that they are not married,
  9492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as
  9493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlost. As soon as I get to town I shall go to my brother, and make
  9494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim come home with me to Gracechurch Street; and then we may consult
  9495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether as to what is to be done.”
  9496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! my dear brother,” replied Mrs. Bennet, “that is exactly what I
  9498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out,
  9499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twherever they may be; and if they are not married already, _make_ them
  9500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but
  9501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them,
  9502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter they are married. And, above all, keep Mr. Bennet from fighting.
  9503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTell him what a dreadful state I am in, that I am frighted out of my
  9504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twits--and have such tremblings, such flutterings, all over me--such
  9505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspasms in my side and pains in my head, and such beatings at heart, that
  9506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear Lydia not to
  9507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does
  9508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother, how kind you are! I
  9509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow you will contrive it all.”
  9510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours
  9512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well
  9513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her hopes as her fear; and after talking with her in this manner till
  9514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdinner was on the table, they all left her to vent all her feelings on
  9515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
  9516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThough her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real
  9518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to
  9519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toppose it, for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her
  9520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it
  9521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter that _one_ only of the household, and the one whom they could
  9522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost trust should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the
  9523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject.
  9524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been
  9526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance
  9527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore. One came from her books, and the other from her toilette. The
  9528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfaces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible
  9529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger
  9530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she had herself incurred in this business, had given more of
  9531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty. As for Mary, she was
  9532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance
  9533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table:
  9534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is a most unfortunate affair, and will probably be much talked of.
  9536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of
  9537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach other the balm of sisterly consolation.”
  9538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThen, perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added,
  9540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful
  9541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlesson: that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable; that one
  9542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfalse step involves her in endless ruin; that her reputation is no less
  9543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrittle than it is beautiful; and that she cannot be too much guarded in
  9544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”
  9545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed
  9547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make any reply. Mary, however, continued to console herself with such
  9548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkind of moral extractions from the evil before them.
  9549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for
  9551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf-an-hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of
  9552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe opportunity of making any inquiries, which Jane was equally eager to
  9553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfy. After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel
  9554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss
  9555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued
  9556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe subject, by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which
  9557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI have not already heard. Give me further particulars. What did Colonel
  9558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tForster say? Had they no apprehension of anything before the elopement
  9559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook place? They must have seen them together for ever.”
  9560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality,
  9562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tespecially on Lydia’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so
  9563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgrieved for him! His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He
  9564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_was_ coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had
  9565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension
  9566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfirst got abroad, it hastened his journey.”
  9567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of
  9569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?”
  9570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; but, when questioned by _him_, Denny denied knowing anything of
  9572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir plans, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not
