  9573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepeat his persuasion of their not marrying--and from _that_, I am
  9574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinclined to hope, he might have been misunderstood before.”
  9575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a
  9577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubt, I suppose, of their being really married?”
  9578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains? I felt
  9580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta little uneasy--a little fearful of my sister’s happiness with him
  9581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite
  9582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tright. My father and mother knew nothing of that; they only felt how
  9583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural
  9584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttriumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia’s last letter
  9585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems, of their
  9586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing in love with each other, many weeks.”
  9587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But not before they went to Brighton?”
  9589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, I believe not.”
  9591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And did Colonel Forster appear to think well of Wickham himself? Does
  9593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the know his real character?”
  9594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly
  9596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant. And since this sad
  9597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffair has taken place, it is said that he left Meryton greatly in debt;
  9598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut I hope this may be false.”
  9599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him,
  9601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis could not have happened!”
  9602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps it would have been better,” replied her sister. “But to expose
  9604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe former faults of any person without knowing what their present
  9605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings were, seemed unjustifiable. We acted with the best intentions.”
  9606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia’s note to his
  9608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twife?”
  9609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He brought it with him for us to see.”
  9611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth. These
  9613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere the contents:
  9614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR HARRIET,
  9616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help
  9618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlaughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am
  9619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmissed. I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who,
  9620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I
  9621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlove, and he is an angel. I should never be happy without him, so think
  9622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit no harm to be off. You need not send them word at Longbourn of my
  9623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater,
  9624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen I write to them and sign my name ‘Lydia Wickham.’ What a good joke
  9625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit will be! I can hardly write for laughing. Pray make my excuses to
  9626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPratt for not keeping my engagement, and dancing with him to-night.
  9627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTell him I hope he will excuse me when he knows all; and tell him I will
  9628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdance with him at the next ball we meet, with great pleasure. I shall
  9629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsend for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell
  9630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are
  9631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpacked up. Good-bye. Give my love to Colonel Forster. I hope you will
  9632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrink to our good journey.
  9633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your affectionate friend,
  9635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“LYDIA BENNET.”
  9637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had
  9639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfinished it. “What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment!
  9640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut at least it shows that _she_ was serious on the subject of their
  9641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjourney. Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her
  9642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside a _scheme_ of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!”
  9643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never saw anyone so shocked. He could not speak a word for full ten
  9645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tminutes. My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in
  9646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch confusion!”
  9647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! Jane,” cried Elizabeth, “was there a servant belonging to it who
  9649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not know the whole story before the end of the day?”
  9650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not know. I hope there was. But to be guarded at such a time is
  9652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery difficult. My mother was in hysterics, and though I endeavoured to
  9653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so
  9654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch as I might have done! But the horror of what might possibly happen
  9655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talmost took from me my faculties.”
  9656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your attendance upon her has been too much for you. You do not look
  9658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell. Oh that I had been with you! you have had every care and anxiety
  9659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tupon yourself alone.”
  9660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every
  9662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfatigue, I am sure; but I did not think it right for either of them.
  9663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tKitty is slight and delicate; and Mary studies so much, that her hours
  9664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof repose should not be broken in on. My aunt Phillips came to Longbourn
  9665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till
  9666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThursday with me. She was of great use and comfort to us all. And
  9667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Lucas has been very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to
  9668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcondole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters’, if
  9669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey should be of use to us.”
  9670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She had better have stayed at home,” cried Elizabeth; “perhaps she
  9672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_meant_ well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see
  9673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo little of one’s neighbours. Assistance is impossible; condolence
  9674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinsufferable. Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied.”
  9675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then proceeded to inquire into the measures which her father had
  9677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintended to pursue, while in town, for the recovery of his daughter.
  9678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He meant I believe,” replied Jane, “to go to Epsom, the place where
  9680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey last changed horses, see the postilions and try if anything could
  9681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe made out from them. His principal object must be to discover the
  9682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnumber of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham. It had come
  9683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a fare from London; and as he thought that the circumstance of a
  9684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman and lady’s removing from one carriage into another might
  9685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe remarked he meant to make inquiries at Clapham. If he could anyhow
  9686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he
  9687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermined to make inquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible
  9688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto find out the stand and number of the coach. I do not know of any
  9689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother designs that he had formed; but he was in such a hurry to be gone,
  9690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding
  9691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout even so much as this.”
  9692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 48
  9696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next
  9699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him.
  9700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis family knew him to be, on all common occasions, a most negligent and
  9701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdilatory correspondent; but at such a time they had hoped for exertion.
  9702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were forced to conclude that he had no pleasing intelligence to
  9703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsend; but even of _that_ they would have been glad to be certain. Mr.
  9704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.
  9705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant
  9707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinformation of what was going on, and their uncle promised, at parting,
  9708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn, as soon as he could,
  9709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only
  9710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecurity for her husband’s not being killed in a duel.
  9711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few
  9713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdays longer, as the former thought her presence might be serviceable
  9714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her nieces. She shared in their attendance on Mrs. Bennet, and was a
  9715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat comfort to them in their hours of freedom. Their other aunt also
  9716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisited them frequently, and always, as she said, with the design of
  9717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcheering and heartening them up--though, as she never came without
  9718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treporting some fresh instance of Wickham’s extravagance or irregularity,
  9719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe seldom went away without leaving them more dispirited than she found
  9720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.
  9721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAll Meryton seemed striving to blacken the man who, but three months
  9723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore, had been almost an angel of light. He was declared to be in debt
  9724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto every tradesman in the place, and his intrigues, all honoured with
  9725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe title of seduction, had been extended into every tradesman’s family.
  9726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEverybody declared that he was the wickedest young man in the world;
  9727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand everybody began to find out that they had always distrusted the
  9728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappearance of his goodness. Elizabeth, though she did not credit above
  9729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf of what was said, believed enough to make her former assurance of
  9730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther sister’s ruin more certain; and even Jane, who believed still less
  9731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof it, became almost hopeless, more especially as the time was now come
  9732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen, if they had gone to Scotland, which she had never before entirely
  9733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdespaired of, they must in all probability have gained some news of
  9734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.
  9735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday his wife received a
  9737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter from him; it told them that, on his arrival, he had immediately
  9738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street;
  9739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival,
  9740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now
  9741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetermined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet
  9742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first
  9743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming to London, before they procured lodgings. Mr. Gardiner himself
  9744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not expect any success from this measure, but as his brother was
  9745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it. He added that Mr.
  9746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London and promised
  9747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto write again very soon. There was also a postscript to this effect:
  9748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if
  9750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossible, from some of the young man’s intimates in the regiment,
  9751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhether Wickham has any relations or connections who would be likely to
  9752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow in what part of town he has now concealed himself. If there were
  9753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanyone that one could apply to with a probability of gaining such a
  9754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclue as that, it might be of essential consequence. At present we have
  9755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to guide us. Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do everything in
  9756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this power to satisfy us on this head. But, on second thoughts, perhaps,
  9757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy could tell us what relations he has now living, better than any
  9758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother person.”
  9759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference to her
  9761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tauthority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information
  9762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved. She had never
  9763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard of his having had any relations, except a father and mother, both
  9764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof whom had been dead many years. It was possible, however, that some of
  9765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this companions in the ----shire might be able to give more information;
  9766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand though she was not very sanguine in expecting it, the application
  9767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas a something to look forward to.
  9768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tEvery day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious
  9770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpart of each was when the post was expected. The arrival of letters
  9771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas the grand object of every morning’s impatience. Through letters,
  9772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhatever of good or bad was to be told would be communicated, and every
  9773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsucceeding day was expected to bring some news of importance.
  9774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for
  9776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane
  9777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad received directions to open all that came for him in his absence,
  9778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his
  9779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise. It was as
  9780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollows:
  9781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR SIR,
  9783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I feel myself called upon, by our relationship, and my situation
  9785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin life, to condole with you on the grievous affliction you are now
  9786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuffering under, of which we were yesterday informed by a letter from
  9787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire. Be assured, my dear sir, that Mrs. Collins and myself
  9788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsincerely sympathise with you and all your respectable family, in
  9789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour present distress, which must be of the bitterest kind, because
  9790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproceeding from a cause which no time can remove. No arguments shall be
  9791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanting on my part that can alleviate so severe a misfortune--or that
  9792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay comfort you, under a circumstance that must be of all others the
  9793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost afflicting to a parent’s mind. The death of your daughter would
  9794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been a blessing in comparison of this. And it is the more to
  9795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe lamented, because there is reason to suppose as my dear Charlotte
  9796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinforms me, that this licentiousness of behaviour in your daughter has
  9797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence; though, at the same time,
  9798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the consolation of yourself and Mrs. Bennet, I am inclined to think
  9799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat her own disposition must be naturally bad, or she could not be
  9800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tguilty of such an enormity, at so early an age. Howsoever that may be,
  9801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou are grievously to be pitied; in which opinion I am not only joined
  9802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby Mrs. Collins, but likewise by Lady Catherine and her daughter, to
  9803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhom I have related the affair. They agree with me in apprehending that
  9804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis false step in one daughter will be injurious to the fortunes of
  9805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall the others; for who, as Lady Catherine herself condescendingly says,
  9806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill connect themselves with such a family? And this consideration leads
  9807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme moreover to reflect, with augmented satisfaction, on a certain event
  9808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof last November; for had it been otherwise, I must have been involved
  9809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin all your sorrow and disgrace. Let me then advise you, dear sir, to
  9810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsole yourself as much as possible, to throw off your unworthy child
  9811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom your affection for ever, and leave her to reap the fruits of her
  9812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town heinous offense.
  9813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am, dear sir, etc., etc.”
  9815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner did not write again till he had received an answer from
  9817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tColonel Forster; and then he had nothing of a pleasant nature to send.
  9818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was not known that Wickham had a single relationship with whom he
  9819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkept up any connection, and it was certain that he had no near one
  9820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliving. His former acquaintances had been numerous; but since he
  9821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been in the militia, it did not appear that he was on terms of
  9822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticular friendship with any of them. There was no one, therefore,
  9823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho could be pointed out as likely to give any news of him. And in the
  9824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twretched state of his own finances, there was a very powerful motive for
  9825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecrecy, in addition to his fear of discovery by Lydia’s relations, for
  9826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit had just transpired that he had left gaming debts behind him to a
  9827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery considerable amount. Colonel Forster believed that more than a
  9828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand pounds would be necessary to clear his expenses at Brighton.
  9829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe owed a good deal in town, but his debts of honour were still more
  9830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformidable. Mr. Gardiner did not attempt to conceal these particulars
  9831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom the Longbourn family. Jane heard them with horror. “A gamester!”
  9832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t she cried. “This is wholly unexpected. I had not an idea of it.”
  9833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner added in his letter, that they might expect to see their
  9835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather at home on the following day, which was Saturday. Rendered
  9836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspiritless by the ill-success of all their endeavours, he had yielded
  9837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his brother-in-law’s entreaty that he would return to his family, and
  9838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleave it to him to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable
  9839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor continuing their pursuit. When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did
  9840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering
  9841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat her anxiety for his life had been before.
  9842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What, is he coming home, and without poor Lydia?” she cried. “Sure he
  9844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill not leave London before he has found them. Who is to fight Wickham,
  9845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand make him marry her, if he comes away?”
  9846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs Mrs. Gardiner began to wish to be at home, it was settled that she
  9848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the children should go to London, at the same time that Mr. Bennet
  9849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcame from it. The coach, therefore, took them the first stage of their
  9850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjourney, and brought its master back to Longbourn.
  9851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her
  9853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDerbyshire friend that had attended her from that part of the world. His
  9854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tname had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and
  9855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe kind of half-expectation which Mrs. Gardiner had formed, of their
  9856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing. Elizabeth had
  9857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived none since her return that could come from Pemberley.
  9858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe present unhappy state of the family rendered any other excuse for
  9860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe lowness of her spirits unnecessary; nothing, therefore, could be
  9861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfairly conjectured from _that_, though Elizabeth, who was by this time
  9862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttolerably well acquainted with her own feelings, was perfectly aware
  9863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, had she known nothing of Darcy, she could have borne the dread of
  9864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia’s infamy somewhat better. It would have spared her, she thought,
  9865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone sleepless night out of two.
  9866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen Mr. Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual
  9868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tphilosophic composure. He said as little as he had ever been in the
  9869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thabit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him
  9870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taway, and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of
  9871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit.
  9872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was not till the afternoon, when he had joined them at tea, that
  9874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly
  9875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, “Say
  9876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing,
  9877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand I ought to feel it.”
  9878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You must not be too severe upon yourself,” replied Elizabeth.
  9880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone
  9882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have
  9883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.
  9884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt will pass away soon enough.”
  9885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Do you suppose them to be in London?”
  9887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?”
  9889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And Lydia used to want to go to London,” added Kitty.
  9891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is happy then,” said her father drily; “and her residence there
  9893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill probably be of some duration.”
  9894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThen after a short silence he continued:
  9896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me
  9898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast May, which, considering the event, shows some greatness of mind.”
  9899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to fetch her mother’s
  9901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttea.
  9902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is a parade,” he cried, “which does one good; it gives such an
  9904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telegance to misfortune! Another day I will do the same; I will sit in my
  9905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlibrary, in my nightcap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble as
  9906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI can; or, perhaps, I may defer it till Kitty runs away.”
  9907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not going to run away, papa,” said Kitty fretfully. “If I should
  9909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.”
  9910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_You_ go to Brighton. I would not trust you so near it as Eastbourne
  9912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor fifty pounds! No, Kitty, I have at last learnt to be cautious, and
  9913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou will feel the effects of it. No officer is ever to enter into
  9914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy house again, nor even to pass through the village. Balls will be
  9915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabsolutely prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters.
  9916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd you are never to stir out of doors till you can prove that you have
  9917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner.”
  9918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tKitty, who took all these threats in a serious light, began to cry.
  9920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, well,” said he, “do not make yourself unhappy. If you are a good
  9922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgirl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of
  9923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem.”
  9924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 49
  9928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTwo days after Mr. Bennet’s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking
  9931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper
  9932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming towards them, and, concluding that she came to call them to their
  9933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother, went forward to meet her; but, instead of the expected summons,
  9934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, “I beg your pardon,
  9935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmadam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some
  9936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.”
  9937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What do you mean, Hill? We have heard nothing from town.”
  9939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dear madam,” cried Mrs. Hill, in great astonishment, “don’t you know
  9941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here
  9942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis half-hour, and master has had a letter.”
  9943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAway ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech. They
  9945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tran through the vestibule into the breakfast-room; from thence to the
  9946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlibrary; their father was in neither; and they were on the point of
  9947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseeking him up stairs with their mother, when they were met by the
  9948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbutler, who said:
  9949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you are looking for my master, ma’am, he is walking towards the
  9951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle copse.”
  9952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tUpon this information, they instantly passed through the hall once
  9954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore, and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately
  9955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.
  9956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  9959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcame up with him, and eagerly cried out:
  9960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, papa, what news--what news? Have you heard from my uncle?”
  9962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes I have had a letter from him by express.”
  9964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, and what news does it bring--good or bad?”
  9966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What is there of good to be expected?” said he, taking the letter from
  9968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this pocket. “But perhaps you would like to read it.”
  9969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand. Jane now came up.
  9971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

  9973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout.”
  9974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.
  9976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR BROTHER,
  9978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“At last I am able to send you some tidings of my niece, and such as,
  9980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tupon the whole, I hope it will give you satisfaction. Soon after you
  9981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleft me on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out in what part of
  9982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon they were. The particulars I reserve till we meet; it is enough
  9983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto know they are discovered. I have seen them both--”
  9984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Then it is as I always hoped,” cried Jane; “they are married!”
  9986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth read on:
  9988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
  9989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have seen them both. They are not married, nor can I find there
  9990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas any intention of being so; but if you are willing to perform the
  9991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengagements which I have ventured to make on your side, I hope it will
  9992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot be long before they are. All that is required of you is, to assure

  9996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tduring your life, one hundred pounds per annum. These are conditions
  9997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich, considering everything, I had no hesitation in complying with,
  9998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas far as I thought myself privileged, for you. I shall send this by
  9999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpress, that no time may be lost in bringing me your answer. You
 10000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill easily comprehend, from these particulars, that Mr. Wickham’s
 10001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstances are not so hopeless as they are generally believed to be.
 10002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe world has been deceived in that respect; and I am happy to say there
 10003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be some little money, even when all his debts are discharged, to
 10004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettle on my niece, in addition to her own fortune. If, as I conclude

 10006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe whole of this business, I will immediately give directions to

 10011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbest that my niece should be married from this house, of which I hope
 10012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou will approve. She comes to us to-day. I shall write again as soon as
 10013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything more is determined on. Yours, etc.,
 10014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“EDW. GARDINER.”
 10016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished. “Can it be

 10022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tConsider how important every moment is in such a case.”
 10032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike the trouble
 10034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyourself.”
 10035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd so saying, he turned back with them, and walked towards the house.
 10039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And may I ask--” said Elizabeth; “but the terms, I suppose, must be
 10041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomplied with.”
 10042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And they _must_ marry! Yet he is _such_ a man!”
 10046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, yes, they must marry. There is nothing else to be done. But there
 10048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare two things that I want very much to know; one is, how much money
 10049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour uncle has laid down to bring it about; and the other, how am I ever
 10050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto pay him.”
 10051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I mean, that no man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a
 10055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am
 10056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgone.”
 10057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh!
 10060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit must be my uncle’s doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has
 10061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdistressed himself. A small sum could not do all this.”
 10062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No,” said her father; “Wickham’s a fool if he takes her with a farthing
 10064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tless than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so ill of him,
 10065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the very beginning of our relationship.”

 10067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be

 10069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet made no answer, and each of them, deep in thought, continued
 10071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilent till they reached the house. Their father then went on to the
 10072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlibrary to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.
 10073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere by themselves. “How strange this is! And for _this_ we are to be
 10076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness,
 10077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice. Oh, Lydia!”
 10078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would
 10080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot marry Lydia if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind
 10081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten
 10082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced. He has children
 10083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten thousand
 10084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpounds?”
 10085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If he were ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said

 10089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never
 10090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal
 10091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprotection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as
 10092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyears of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is
 10093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now,
 10094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she

 10107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood

 10110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit known to her. He was writing and, without raising his head, coolly
 10111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treplied:
