 10118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went up stairs
 10120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttogether. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication
 10121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news,
 10122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As
 10123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner’s hope of Lydia’s being soon
 10124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarried, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its
 10125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight, as she
 10126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter
 10127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her
 10128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.
 10129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried. “This is delightful indeed! She will
 10131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen!
 10132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMy good, kind brother! I knew how it would be. I knew he would manage
 10133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teverything! How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the
 10134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about
 10135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him
 10136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell,
 10137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tKitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear
 10138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!”
 10139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of
 10141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr.
 10142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.
 10143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great
 10145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeasure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to
 10146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassist Mr. Wickham with money.”
 10147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but
 10149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children
 10150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have
 10151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever had anything from him, except a few presents. Well! I am so happy!
 10152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn a short time I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well
 10153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in
 10154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and
 10155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou write for me. We will settle with your father about the money
 10156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.”
 10157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and
 10159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had
 10160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her
 10161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather was at leisure to be consulted. One day’s delay, she observed,
 10162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite
 10163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso obstinate as usual. Other schemes, too, came into her head.
 10164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the
 10166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call
 10167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage.
 10168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAn airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do
 10169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything for you in Meryton? Oh! Here comes Hill! My dear Hill, have you
 10170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall
 10171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”
 10172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy. Elizabeth received her
 10174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcongratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took
 10175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom.
 10176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPoor Lydia’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was
 10178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno worse, she had need to be thankful. She felt it so; and though, in
 10179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking forward, neither rational happiness nor worldly prosperity could
 10180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had
 10181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had
 10182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgained.
 10183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 50
 10187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet had very often wished before this period of his life that,
 10190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum for
 10191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived
 10192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that
 10193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever
 10194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of
 10195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be
 10196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther husband might then have rested in its proper place.
 10197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone
 10199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law, and he
 10200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance,
 10201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.
 10202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly
 10204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuseless, for, of course, they were to have a son. The son was to join
 10205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow
 10206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters
 10207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuccessively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs.
 10208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he
 10209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then
 10210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy, and her
 10211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thusband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their
 10212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincome.
 10213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFive thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and
 10215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe children. But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the
 10216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlatter depended on the will of the parents. This was one point, with
 10217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregard to Lydia, at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet
 10218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him. In
 10219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tterms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother,
 10220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect
 10221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapprobation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the
 10222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengagements that had been made for him. He had never before supposed
 10223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would
 10224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present
 10225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrangement. He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser by the
 10226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket
 10227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tallowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her
 10228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthrough her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within
 10229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat sum.
 10230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThat it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was
 10232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanother very welcome surprise; for his wish at present was to have as
 10233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle trouble in the business as possible. When the first transports
 10234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he
 10235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnaturally returned to all his former indolence. His letter was soon
 10236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdispatched; for, though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick
 10237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin its execution. He begged to know further particulars of what he
 10238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas indebted to his brother, but was too angry with Lydia to send any
 10239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmessage to her.
 10240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe good news spread quickly through the house, and with proportionate
 10242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeed through the neighbourhood. It was borne in the latter with decent
 10243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tphilosophy. To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage
 10244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof conversation had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the
 10245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiest alternative, been secluded from the world, in some distant
 10246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfarmhouse. But there was much to be talked of in marrying her; and the
 10247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood-natured wishes for her well-doing which had proceeded before from
 10248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall the spiteful old ladies in Meryton lost but a little of their spirit
 10249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin this change of circumstances, because with such an husband her misery
 10250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas considered certain.
 10251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was a fortnight since Mrs. Bennet had been downstairs; but on this
 10253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in
 10254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits oppressively high. No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her
 10255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttriumph. The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object
 10256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of
 10257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those
 10258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and
 10259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tservants. She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a
 10260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproper situation for her daughter, and, without knowing or considering
 10261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and
 10262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timportance.
 10263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings could quit it--or the
 10265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is
 10266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo far off! I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for
 10267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPulvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”
 10268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the
 10270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tservants remained. But when they had withdrawn, he said to her: “Mrs.
 10271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet, before you take any or all of these houses for your son and
 10272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into _one_ house in this
 10273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbourhood they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage the
 10274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.”
 10275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tA long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm. It
 10277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon led to another; and Mrs. Bennet found, with amazement and horror,
 10278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his
 10279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdaughter. He protested that she should receive from him no mark of
 10280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection whatever on the occasion. Mrs. Bennet could hardly comprehend
 10281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit. That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable
 10282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege without which her
 10283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all she could believe
 10284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossible. She was more alive to the disgrace which her want of new
 10285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of
 10286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they
 10287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook place.
 10288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of
 10290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for
 10291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the
 10292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its
 10293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the
 10294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspot.
 10295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe had no fear of its spreading farther through his means. There were
 10297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfew people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended;
 10298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut, at the same time, there was no one whose knowledge of a sister’s
 10299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrailty would have mortified her so much--not, however, from any fear
 10300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof disadvantage from it individually to herself, for, at any rate,
 10301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere seemed a gulf impassable between them. Had Lydia’s marriage been
 10302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that
 10303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy would connect himself with a family where, to every other
 10304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjection, would now be added an alliance and relationship of the
 10305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnearest kind with a man whom he so justly scorned.
 10306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom such a connection she could not wonder that he would shrink. The
 10308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his
 10309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a
 10310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tblow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she
 10311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no
 10312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there
 10313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that
 10314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they
 10315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould meet.
 10316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhat a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the
 10318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago, would now
 10319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been most gladly and gratefully received! He was as generous, she
 10320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoubted not, as the most generous of his sex; but while he was mortal,
 10321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere must be a triumph.
 10322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in
 10324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisposition and talents, would most suit her. His understanding and
 10325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes. It
 10326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas an union that must have been to the advantage of both; by her ease
 10327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved;
 10328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand from his judgement, information, and knowledge of the world, she
 10329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust have received benefit of greater importance.
 10330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what
 10332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnubial felicity really was. An union of a different tendency, and
 10333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprecluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their
 10334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily.
 10335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHow Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence,
 10337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could not imagine. But how little of permanent happiness could
 10338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbelong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions
 10339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
 10340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
 10342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother. To Mr. Bennet’s
 10344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurance of his eagerness to
 10345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpromote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties
 10346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the subject might never be mentioned to him again. The principal
 10347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpurport of his letter was to inform them that Mr. Wickham had resolved
 10348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton quitting the militia.
 10349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as
 10351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this marriage was fixed on. And I think you will agree with me, in
 10352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsidering the removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on
 10353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this account and my niece’s. It is Mr. Wickham’s intention to go into
 10354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe regulars; and among his former friends, there are still some who
 10355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare able and willing to assist him in the army. He has the promise of an
 10356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tensigncy in General ----‘s regiment, now quartered in the North. It
 10357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom. He
 10358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpromises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each
 10359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent. I have
 10360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twritten to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements,
 10361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham
 10362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin and near Brighton, with assurances of speedy payment, for which I
 10363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave pledged myself. And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying
 10364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsimilar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin
 10365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta list according to his information? He has given in all his debts; I
 10366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has our directions,
 10367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand all will be completed in a week. They will then join his regiment,
 10368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs.
 10369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner, that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she
 10370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleaves the South. She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to
 10371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou and her mother.--Yours, etc.,
 10372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“E. GARDINER.”
 10374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal
 10376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom the ----shire as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do. But Mrs. Bennet
 10377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not so well pleased with it. Lydia’s being settled in the North,
 10378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjust when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company,
 10379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in
 10380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a
 10381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted
 10382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith everybody, and had so many favourites.
 10383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking
 10385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she
 10386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General ----‘s
 10387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregiment.”
 10388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being
 10390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmitted into her family again before she set off for the North,
 10391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived at first an absolute negative. But Jane and Elizabeth,
 10392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and
 10393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents,
 10394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\turged him so earnestly yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her
 10395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was
 10396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished. And their
 10397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother had the satisfaction of knowing that she would be able to show
 10398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther married daughter in the neighbourhood before she was banished to the
 10399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNorth. When Mr. Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent
 10400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this permission for them to come; and it was settled, that as soon as
 10401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn. Elizabeth was
 10402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme, and
 10403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would
 10404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave been the last object of her wishes.
 10405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 51
 10409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir sister’s wedding day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her
 10412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprobably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to
 10413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeet them at ----, and they were to return in it by dinner-time. Their
 10414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets, and Jane more especially,
 10415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she
 10416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister
 10417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust endure.
 10418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey came. The family were assembled in the breakfast room to receive
 10420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet as the carriage drove up to
 10421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed,
 10422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanxious, uneasy.
 10423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and
 10425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and
 10426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twelcomed her with rapture; gave her hand, with an affectionate smile,
 10427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy with an
 10428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talacrity which shewed no doubt of their happiness.
 10429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite
 10431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely
 10432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was
 10433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to provoke him. Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet
 10434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas shocked. Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy,
 10435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand fearless. She turned from sister to sister, demanding their
 10436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcongratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly
 10437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tround the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and
 10438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobserved, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been
 10439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere.
 10440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham was not at all more distressed than herself, but his manners
 10442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere always so pleasing, that had his character and his marriage been
 10443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he
 10444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclaimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth had
 10445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down,
 10446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence
 10447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof an impudent man. She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the
 10448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttwo who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.
 10449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThere was no want of discourse. The bride and her mother could neither
 10451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near
 10452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood,
 10453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith a good humoured ease which she felt very unable to equal in her
 10454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treplies. They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the
 10455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld. Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led
 10456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvoluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for
 10457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe world.
 10458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away;
 10460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit seems but a fortnight I declare; and yet there have been things
 10461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure
 10462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I
 10463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought it would be very good fun if I was.”
 10464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer father lifted up his eyes. Jane was distressed. Elizabeth looked
 10466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of
 10467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she chose to be insensible, gaily continued, “Oh! mamma, do the
 10468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeople hereabouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might not;
 10469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was determined he
 10470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshould know it, and so I let down the side-glass next to him, and took
 10471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toff my glove, and let my hand just rest upon the window frame, so that
 10472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like anything.”
 10473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could bear it no longer. She got up, and ran out of the room;
 10475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to
 10476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dining parlour. She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with
 10477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanxious parade, walk up to her mother’s right hand, and hear her say
 10478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her eldest sister, “Ah! Jane, I take your place now, and you must go
 10479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlower, because I am a married woman.”
 10480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment
 10482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom which she had been so wholly free at first. Her ease and good
 10483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspirits increased. She longed to see Mrs. Phillips, the Lucases, and
 10484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham”
 10485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t by each of them; and in the mean time, she went after dinner to show her
 10486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tring, and boast of being married, to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
 10487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast
 10489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\troom, “and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I
 10490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half
 10491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get
 10492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thusbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go.”
 10493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very true; and if I had my will, we should. But my dear Lydia, I don’t
 10495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?”
 10496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, lord! yes;--there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all
 10498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthings. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We
 10499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some
 10500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tballs, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.”
 10501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.
 10503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters
 10505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the
 10506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twinter is over.”
 10507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not
 10509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparticularly like your way of getting husbands.”
 10510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTheir visitors were not to remain above ten days with them. Mr. Wickham
 10512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad received his commission before he left London, and he was to join
 10513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this regiment at the end of a fortnight.
 10514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNo one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and
 10516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and
 10517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving very frequent parties at home. These parties were acceptable to
 10518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did
 10519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink, than such as did not.
 10520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected
 10522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him. She had scarcely needed her
 10523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresent observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that
 10524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love, rather
 10525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring
 10526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain
 10527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and
 10528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity
 10529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof having a companion.
 10530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia was exceedingly fond of him. He was her dear Wickham on every
 10532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasion; no one was to be put in competition with him. He did every
 10533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on
 10534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe first of September, than any body else in the country.
 10535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOne morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two
 10537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telder sisters, she said to Elizabeth:
 10538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe. You
 10540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere not by, when I told mamma and the others all about it. Are not you
 10541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcurious to hear how it was managed?”
 10542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said
 10544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton the subject.”
 10545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were
 10547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarried, you know, at St. Clement’s, because Wickham’s lodgings were in
 10548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven
 10549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\to’clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others
 10550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere to meet us at the church. Well, Monday morning came, and I was in
 10551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a fuss! I was so afraid, you know, that something would happen to
 10552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tput it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was
 10553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as
 10554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in
 10555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten, for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed
 10556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto know whether he would be married in his blue coat.”
 10557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual; I thought it would never
 10559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe over; for, by the bye, you are to understand, that my uncle and aunt
 10560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you’ll believe
 10561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a
 10562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or anything. To be sure London was
 10563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trather thin, but, however, the Little Theatre was open. Well, and so
 10564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjust as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon
 10565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once
 10566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey get together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I
 10567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we
 10568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere beyond the hour, we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he
 10569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcame back again in ten minutes’ time, and then we all set out. However,
 10570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI recollected afterwards that if he had been prevented going, the
 10571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well.”
 10572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.
 10574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes!--he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But gracious
 10576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme! I quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised
 10577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!”
 10578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If it was to be secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the
 10580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.”
 10581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will
 10583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\task you no questions.”
 10584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Thank you,” said Lydia, “for if you did, I should certainly tell you
 10586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall, and then Wickham would be angry.”
 10587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her
 10589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpower, by running away.
 10590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible; or at least
 10592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was impossible not to try for information. Mr. Darcy had been at
 10593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther sister’s wedding. It was exactly a scene, and exactly among people,
 10594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere he had apparently least to do, and least temptation to go.
 10595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tConjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her
 10596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbrain; but she was satisfied with none. Those that best pleased her, as
 10597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplacing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable. She
 10598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper,
 10599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what
 10600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia had dropt, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been
 10601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintended.
 10602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be
 10604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto know how a person unconnected with any of us, and (comparatively
 10605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeaking) a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such
 10606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta time. Pray write instantly, and let me understand it--unless it is,
 10607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems
 10608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with
 10609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tignorance.”
 10610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not that I _shall_, though,” she added to herself, as she finished
 10612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe letter; “and my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable
 10613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it
 10614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout.”
 10615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to
 10617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad
 10618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof it;--till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any
 10619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.
 10620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 52
 10624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as
 10627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as she possibly could. She was no sooner in possession of it
 10628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan, hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to
 10629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches and prepared to
 10630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not
 10631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontain a denial.
 10632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Gracechurch street, Sept. 6.
 10634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR NIECE,
 10636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning
 10638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto answering it, as I foresee that a _little_ writing will not comprise
 10639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat I have to tell you. I must confess myself surprised by your
 10640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplication; I did not expect it from _you_. Don’t think me angry,
 10641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thowever, for I only mean to let you know that I had not imagined such
 10642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinquiries to be necessary on _your_ side. If you do not choose to
 10643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstand me, forgive my impertinence. Your uncle is as much surprised
 10644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas I am--and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned
 10645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould have allowed him to act as he has done. But if you are really
 10646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinnocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit.
 10647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most
 10649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunexpected visitor. Mr. Darcy called, and was shut up with him several
 10650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thours. It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so
 10651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdreadfully racked as _yours_ seems to have been. He came to tell Mr.
 10652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were,
 10653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand that he had seen and talked with them both; Wickham repeatedly,
 10654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLydia once. From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day
 10655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for
 10656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthem. The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to
 10657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to
 10658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide
 10659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin him. He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and
 10660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private
 10661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tactions open to the world. His character was to speak for itself. He
 10662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalled it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy
 10663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan evil which had been brought on by himself. If he _had another_
 10664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmotive, I am sure it would never disgrace him. He had been some days
 10665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin town, before he was able to discover them; but he had something to
 10666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdirect his search, which was more than _we_ had; and the consciousness
 10667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof this was another reason for his resolving to follow us.
 10668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There is a lady, it seems, a Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago
 10670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoverness to Miss Darcy, and was dismissed from her charge on some cause
 10671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof disapprobation, though he did not say what. She then took a large
 10672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thouse in Edward-street, and has since maintained herself by letting
 10673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlodgings. This Mrs. Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with
 10674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham; and he went to her for intelligence of him as soon as he got to
 10675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown. But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he
 10676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted. She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery and
 10677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcorruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be found.
 10678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham indeed had gone to her on their first arrival in London, and had
 10679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe been able to receive them into her house, they would have taken up
 10680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir abode with her. At length, however, our kind friend procured the
 10681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twished-for direction. They were in ---- street. He saw Wickham, and
 10682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafterwards insisted on seeing Lydia. His first object with her, he
 10683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledged, had been to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful
 10684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsituation, and return to her friends as soon as they could be prevailed
 10685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton to receive her, offering his assistance, as far as it would go. But
 10686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where she was. She cared
 10687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor none of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear
 10688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof leaving Wickham. She was sure they should be married some time or
 10689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother, and it did not much signify when. Since such were her feelings,
 10690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which,
 10691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never
 10692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen _his_ design. He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment,
 10693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton account of some debts of honour, which were very pressing; and
 10694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscrupled not to lay all the ill-consequences of Lydia’s flight on her
 10695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town folly alone. He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as
 10696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it. He
 10697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have
 10698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to live on.
 10699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy asked him why he had not married your sister at once. Though
 10701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able
 10702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by
 10703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage. But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still
 10704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage in
 10705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome other country. Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely
 10706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be proof against the temptation of immediate relief.
 10707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They met several times, for there was much to be discussed. Wickham of
 10709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcourse wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be
 10710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonable.
 10711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Every thing being settled between _them_, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to
 10713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch
 10714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstreet the evening before I came home. But Mr. Gardiner could not be
 10715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen, and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was
 10716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstill with him, but would quit town the next morning. He did not judge
 10717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your
 10718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the
 10719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeparture of the former. He did not leave his name, and till the next
 10720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tday it was only known that a gentleman had called on business.
 10721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“On Saturday he came again. Your father was gone, your uncle at home,
 10723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together.
 10724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They met again on Sunday, and then _I_ saw him too. It was not all
 10726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to
 10727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn. But our visitor was very obstinate. I fancy, Lizzy, that
 10728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all. He has been
 10729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccused of many faults at different times, but _this_ is the true one.
 10730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and
 10731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it), your
 10732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncle would most readily have settled the whole.
 10733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either
 10735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved. But at last your uncle
 10736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his
 10737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tniece, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it,
 10738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter
 10739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation
 10740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where
 10741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was due. But, Lizzy, this must go no farther than yourself, or Jane
 10742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat most.
 10743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young
 10745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeople. His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably
 10746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to her own
 10747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettled upon _her_, and his commission purchased. The reason why all
 10748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above. It
 10749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that
 10750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham’s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he
 10751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been received and noticed as he was. Perhaps there was some truth
 10752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin _this_; though I doubt whether _his_ reserve, or _anybody’s_ reserve,
 10753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan be answerable for the event. But in spite of all this fine talking,
 10754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would
 10755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever have yielded, if we had not given him credit for _another
 10756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest_ in the affair.
 10757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who
 10759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in
 10760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were
 10761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen to receive the last finish.
 10762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I believe I have now told you every thing. It is a relation which
 10764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not
 10765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafford you any displeasure. Lydia came to us; and Wickham had constant
 10766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmission to the house. _He_ was exactly what he had been, when I
 10767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was
 10768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsatisfied with her behaviour while she staid with us, if I had not
 10769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperceived, by Jane’s letter last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming
 10770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thome was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell
 10771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou can give you no fresh pain. I talked to her repeatedly in the most
 10772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tserious manner, representing to her all the wickedness of what she had
 10773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone, and all the unhappiness she had brought on her family. If she
 10774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen. I was
 10775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsometimes quite provoked, but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and
 10776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, and for their sakes had patience with her.
 10777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy was punctual in his return, and as Lydia informed you,
 10779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattended the wedding. He dined with us the next day, and was to leave
 10780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttown again on Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be very angry with me, my
 10781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold
 10782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough to say before) how much I like him. His behaviour to us has,
 10783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire. His
 10784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little
 10785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore liveliness, and _that_, if he marry _prudently_, his wife may teach
 10786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim. I thought him very sly;--he hardly ever mentioned your name. But
 10787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tslyness seems the fashion.
 10788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Pray forgive me if I have been very presuming, or at least do not
 10790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpunish me so far as to exclude me from P. I shall never be quite happy
 10791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill I have been all round the park. A low phaeton, with a nice little
 10792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpair of ponies, would be the very thing.
 10793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I must write no more. The children have been wanting me this half
 10795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thour.
 10796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yours, very sincerely,
 10798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“M. GARDINER.”
 10800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits,
 10802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the
 10803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreatest share. The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had
 10804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproduced of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister’s
 10805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmatch, which she had feared to encourage as an exertion of goodness too
 10806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the
 10807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpain of obligation, were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true!
 10808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all
 10809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which
 10810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and
 10811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdespise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason
 10812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith, persuade, and finally bribe, the man whom he always most wished to
 10813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tavoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce. He had
 10814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem. Her
 10815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theart did whisper that he had done it for her. But it was a hope shortly
 10816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchecked by other considerations, and she soon felt that even her vanity
 10817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her--for
 10818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta woman who had already refused him--as able to overcome a sentiment so
 10819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnatural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham. Brother-in-law
 10820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Wickham! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection. He had,
 10821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto be sure, done much. She was ashamed to think how much. But he had
 10822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgiven a reason for his interference, which asked no extraordinary
 10823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstretch of belief. It was reasonable that he should feel he had been
 10824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and
 10825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she
 10826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould, perhaps, believe that remaining partiality for her might assist
 10827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially
 10828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcerned. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that they were
 10829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunder obligations to a person who could never receive a return. They
 10830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\towed the restoration of Lydia, her character, every thing, to him. Oh!
 10831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever
 10832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him. For
 10833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself she was humbled; but she was proud of him. Proud that in a cause
 10834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof compassion and honour, he had been able to get the better of himself.
 10835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe read over her aunt’s commendation of him again and again. It
 10836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas hardly enough; but it pleased her. She was even sensible of some
 10837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she
 10838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted
 10839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween Mr. Darcy and herself.
 10840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was roused from her seat, and her reflections, by some one’s
 10842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapproach; and before she could strike into another path, she was
 10843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tovertaken by Wickham.
 10844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he,
 10846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas he joined her.
 10847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat the interruption must be unwelcome.”
 10850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I should be sorry indeed, if it were. We were always good friends; and
 10852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnow we are better.”
 10853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“True. Are the others coming out?”
 10855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to
 10857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton. And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that

 10859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe replied in the affirmative.
 10861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much

 10866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tout well. At such a distance as _that_, you know, things are strangely
 10873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmisrepresented.”
 10874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips. Elizabeth hoped she had
 10876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilenced him; but he soon afterwards said:
 10877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other

 10881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said
 10882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth. “It must be something particular, to take him there at this

 10884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I
 10886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunderstood from the Gardiners that you had.”
 10887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And do you like her?”
 10891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 10893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year
 10895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad

 10897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”
 10899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did you go by the village of Kympton?”
 10901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not recollect that we did.”
 10903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I mention it, because it is the living which I ought to have had. A
 10905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmost delightful place!--Excellent Parsonage House! It would have suited
 10906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme in every respect.”
 10907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How should you have liked making sermons?”
 10909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty,
 10911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to
 10912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepine;--but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The
 10913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquiet, the retirement of such a life would have answered all my ideas
 10914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the

 10916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have heard from authority, which I thought _as good_, that it was
 10918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tleft you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.”
 10919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have. Yes, there was something in _that_; I told you so from the
