 10922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I _did_ hear, too, that there was a time, when sermon-making was not
 10924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually
 10925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeclared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business
 10926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been compromised accordingly.”
 10927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember
 10929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.”
 10930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast
 10932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister’s sake, to provoke him,
 10933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile:
 10934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let
 10936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus quarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one
 10937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmind.”
 10938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe held out her hand; he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though
 10940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.
 10941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 53
 10945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation that he
 10948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth,
 10949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she
 10950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad said enough to keep him quiet.
 10951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe day of his and Lydia’s departure soon came, and Mrs. Bennet was
 10953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means
 10954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to
 10955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinue at least a twelvemonth.
 10956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”
 10958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, lord! I don’t know. Not these two or three years, perhaps.”
 10960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Write to me very often, my dear.”
 10962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for
 10964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twriting. My sisters may write to _me_. They will have nothing else to
 10965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo.”
 10966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife’s. He
 10968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiled, looked handsome, and said many pretty things.
 10969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He is as fine a fellow,” said Mr. Bennet, as soon as they were out of
 10971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe house, “as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to
 10972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus all. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas
 10973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”
 10974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
 10976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with
 10978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone’s friends. One seems so forlorn without them.”
 10979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is the consequence, you see, Madam, of marrying a daughter,” said
 10981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth. “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are
 10982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsingle.”
 10983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is no such thing. Lydia does not leave me because she is married,
 10985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut only because her husband’s regiment happens to be so far off. If
 10986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”
 10987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly
 10989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an
 10990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarticle of news which then began to be in circulation. The housekeeper
 10991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her
 10992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmaster, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several
 10993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tweeks. Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets. She looked at Jane, and
 10994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsmiled and shook her head by turns.
 10995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 10996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,” (for Mrs.
 10997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPhillips first brought her the news). “Well, so much the better. Not
 10998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am
 10999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure _I_ never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome
 11000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what _may_ happen?
 11001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to
 11002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmention a word about it. And so, is it quite certain he is coming?”
 11003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mrs. Nicholls was in
 11005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton last night; I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose
 11006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certain true. He
 11007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomes down on Thursday at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was
 11008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on
 11009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”
 11010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing
 11012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcolour. It was many months since she had mentioned his name to
 11013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said:
 11014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present
 11016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treport; and I know I appeared distressed. But don’t imagine it was from
 11017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that
 11018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI _should_ be looked at. I do assure you that the news does not affect
 11019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he comes
 11020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid of
 11021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_myself_, but I dread other people’s remarks.”
 11022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth did not know what to make of it. Had she not seen him in
 11024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDerbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no
 11025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial
 11026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming
 11027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere _with_ his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come
 11028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout it.
 11029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot
 11031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome to a house which he has legally hired, without raising all this
 11032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeculation! I _will_ leave him to himself.”
 11033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her
 11035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily
 11036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperceive that her spirits were affected by it. They were more disturbed,
 11037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore unequal, than she had often seen them.
 11038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents,
 11040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
 11041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “you
 11043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill wait on him of course.”
 11044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I
 11046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twent to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in
 11047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing, and I will not be sent on a fool’s errand again.”
 11048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention
 11050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to

 11052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“‘Tis an etiquette I despise,” said he. “If he wants our society,
 11054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlet him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend my hours
 11055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin running after my neighbours every time they go away and come back

 11057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t

 11059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton him. But, however, that shan’t prevent my asking him to dine here, I

 11064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tConsoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her

 11066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before
 11067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_they_ did. As the day of his arrival drew near,--
 11068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said Jane to her sister. “It
 11070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference, but I can
 11071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well;
 11072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she
 11073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsays. Happy shall I be, when his stay at Netherfield is over!”
 11074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it
 11076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction
 11077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have
 11078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways so much.”
 11079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants,
 11081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety
 11082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand fretfulness on her side might be as long as it could. She counted
 11083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent;

 11085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him, from her dressing-room window,

 11087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy. Jane resolutely
 11089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went
 11090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the window--she looked,--she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down
 11091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain by her sister.
 11092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”
 11094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not
 11096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow.”
 11097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with
 11099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim before. Mr. what’s-his-name. That tall, proud man.”
 11100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!--and so it does, I vow. Well, any friend of
 11102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley’s will always be welcome here, to be sure; but else I must
 11103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay that I hate the very sight of him.”
 11104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern. She knew but little
 11106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness
 11107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time
 11108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafter receiving his explanatory letter. Both sisters were uncomfortable
 11109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough. Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their
 11110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother talked on, of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be
 11111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivil to him only as Mr. Bingley’s friend, without being heard by either
 11112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof them. But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not be
 11113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to shew Mrs.
 11114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tGardiner’s letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him.
 11115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused,
 11116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand whose merit she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive
 11117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinformation, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted
 11118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an
 11119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just as
 11120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat Jane felt for Bingley. Her astonishment at his coming--at his
 11121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again,
 11122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered
 11123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour in Derbyshire.
 11124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe colour which had been driven from her face, returned for half a

 11127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and
 11128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishes must still be unshaken. But she would not be secure.
 11129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let me first see how he behaves,” said she; “it will then be early
 11131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tenough for expectation.”
 11132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to
 11134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of

 11137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen’s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with
 11138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any
 11139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsymptom of resentment or any unnecessary complaisance.
 11140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11141	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down
 11142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagain to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command. She

 11146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresence be what he was before her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but

 11148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley, she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period

 11151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed,
 11152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tespecially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of
 11153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther curtsey and address to his friend.
 11154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter
 11156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy,
 11157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill
 11158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplied.
 11159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did, a question

 11162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not seated by her; perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but
 11163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit had not been so in Derbyshire. There he had talked to her friends,

 11165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist

 11169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey last met, were plainly expressed. She was disappointed, and angry

 11171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Could I expect it to be otherwise!” said she. “Yet why did he come?”

 11174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to

 11176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe inquired after his sister, but could do no more.
 11178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,” said Mrs. Bennet.
 11180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe readily agreed to it.
 11182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People _did_ say
 11184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope
 11185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood,
 11186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsince you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my
 11187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have
 11188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen it in the papers. It was in The Times and The Courier, I know;
 11189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said, ‘Lately,

 11191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsyllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything.
 11192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was my brother Gardiner’s drawing up too, and I wonder how he came to
 11193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?”
 11194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth
 11196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could
 11197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot tell.
 11198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,”
 11200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t continued her mother, “but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very

 11203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have
 11204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard of his leaving the ----shire, and of his being gone into the
 11205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tregulars. Thank Heaven! he has _some_ friends, though perhaps not so
 11206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmany as he deserves.”
 11207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such
 11209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmisery of shame, that she could hardly keep her seat. It drew from her,

 11211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in
 11212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe country at present. A few weeks, he believed.
 11213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said her mother,
 11215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please on Mr.
 11216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet’s manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and
 11217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill save all the best of the covies for you.”
 11218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s misery increased, at such unnecessary, such officious
 11220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present as had
 11221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tflattered them a year ago, every thing, she was persuaded, would be
 11222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant, she felt
 11223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for
 11224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoments of such painful confusion.
 11225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to
 11227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe in company with either of them. Their society can afford no pleasure
 11228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either
 11229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone or the other again!”
 11230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no
 11232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcompensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing
 11233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow much the beauty of her sister re-kindled the admiration of her
 11234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer lover. When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little;
 11235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention. He
 11236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfound her as handsome as she had been last year; as good natured, and
 11237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas unaffected, though not quite so chatty. Jane was anxious that no
 11238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded
 11239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she talked as much as ever. But her mind was so busily engaged,
 11240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat she did not always know when she was silent.
 11241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her
 11243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at
 11244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLongbourn in a few days time.
 11245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added, “for when
 11247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with
 11248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tus, as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure
 11249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep
 11250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour engagement.”
 11251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of
 11253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this concern at having been prevented by business. They then went away.
 11254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine
 11256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did
 11257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man
 11258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride
 11259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof one who had ten thousand a year.
 11260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 54
 11264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits;
 11267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects that
 11268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust deaden them more. Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
 11269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she,
 11271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“did he come at all?”
 11272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
 11274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He could be still amiable, still pleasing, to my uncle and aunt, when
 11276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If
 11277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the no longer cares for me, why silent? Teasing, teasing, man! I will
 11278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink no more about him.”
 11279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach
 11281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look, which showed her
 11282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetter satisfied with their visitors, than Elizabeth.
 11283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly
 11285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teasy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by
 11286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly
 11287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseen that, on both sides, we meet only as common and indifferent
 11288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquaintance.”
 11289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, very indifferent indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly. “Oh, Jane,
 11291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttake care.”
 11292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak, as to be in danger now?”
 11294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with
 11296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou as ever.”
 11297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
 11299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in
 11301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes, which the good
 11302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had
 11303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trevived.
 11304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOn Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two
 11306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality
 11307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas sportsmen, were in very good time. When they repaired to the
 11308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take
 11309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe place, which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by
 11310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther sister. Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore
 11311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto invite him to sit by herself. On entering the room, he seemed to
 11312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was
 11313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdecided. He placed himself by her.
 11314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.
 11316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe bore it with noble indifference, and she would have imagined that
 11317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes
 11318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing
 11319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talarm.
 11320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHis behaviour to her sister was such, during dinner time, as showed an
 11322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded
 11323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, that if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his
 11324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\town, would be speedily secured. Though she dared not depend upon the
 11325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour. It
 11326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in
 11327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno cheerful humour. Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her as the table
 11328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcould divide them. He was on one side of her mother. She knew how little
 11329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to
 11330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadvantage. She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse, but
 11331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and
 11332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcold was their manner whenever they did. Her mother’s ungraciousness,
 11333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind;
 11334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell
 11335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the
 11336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily.
 11337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of
 11339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away
 11340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout enabling them to enter into something more of conversation than
 11341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance. Anxious
 11342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room, before the
 11343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her
 11344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tuncivil. She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all
 11345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
 11346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If he does not come to me, _then_,” said she, “I shall give him up for
 11348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever.”
 11349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have
 11351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanswered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table,
 11352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhere Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee,
 11353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin so close a confederacy that there was not a single vacancy near her
 11354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich would admit of a chair. And on the gentlemen’s approaching, one of
 11355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper:
 11356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The men shan’t come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them;
 11358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo we?”
 11359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with
 11361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough
 11362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto help anybody to coffee; and then was enraged against herself for
 11363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing so silly!
 11364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to
 11366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex, who would not
 11367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprotest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?
 11368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThere is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!”
 11369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee cup
 11371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself; and she seized the opportunity of saying:
 11372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
 11374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, she will remain there till Christmas.”
 11376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?”
 11378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough,
 11380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese three weeks.”
 11381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse
 11383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith her, he might have better success. He stood by her, however, for
 11384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsome minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering
 11385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Elizabeth again, he walked away.
 11386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen the tea-things were removed, and the card-tables placed, the ladies
 11388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall rose, and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him,
 11389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen all her views were overthrown by seeing him fall a victim to her
 11390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated
 11391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith the rest of the party. She now lost every expectation of pleasure.
 11392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were confined for the evening at different tables, and she had
 11393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side
 11394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.
 11395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to
 11397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupper; but their carriage was unluckily ordered before any of the
 11398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tothers, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.
 11399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “What
 11401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay you to the day? I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well,
 11402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The
 11403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvenison was roasted to a turn--and everybody said they never saw so
 11404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfat a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the
 11405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLucases’ last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged, that the partridges
 11406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French
 11407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater
 11408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And
 11409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat do you think she said besides? ‘Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her
 11410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Netherfield at last.’ She did indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good
 11411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta creature as ever lived--and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls,
 11412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”
 11413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits; she had seen enough of
 11415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley’s behaviour to Jane, to be convinced that she would get him at
 11416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy
 11417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at
 11418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
 11419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. “The
 11421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparty seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we
 11422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay often meet again.”
 11423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth smiled.
 11425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me.
 11427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an
 11428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable and sensible young man, without having a wish beyond it. I am
 11429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tperfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had
 11430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tany design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed
 11431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally
 11432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasing, than any other man.”
 11433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and
 11435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tare provoking me to it every moment.”
 11436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How hard it is in some cases to be believed!”
 11438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And how impossible in others!”
 11440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I
 11442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledge?”
 11443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to
 11445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinstruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive
 11446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”
 11447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 55
 11451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tA few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His
 11454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in
 11455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tten days time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably
 11456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many
 11457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
 11458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”
 11460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe should be particularly happy at any time, etc. etc.; and if she would
 11462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgive him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
 11463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Can you come to-morrow?”
 11465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was
 11467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepted with alacrity.
 11468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe came, and in such very good time that the ladies were none of them
 11470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdressed. In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughter’s room, in her dressing
 11471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgown, and with her hair half finished, crying out:
 11472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come--Mr. Bingley is
 11474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome. He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss
 11475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss
 11476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy’s hair.”
 11477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is
 11479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforwarder than either of us, for she went up stairs half an hour ago.”
 11480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come be quick, be quick!
 11482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhere is your sash, my dear?”
 11483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down
 11485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout one of her sisters.
 11486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the
 11488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevening. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his
 11489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcustom, and Mary went up stairs to her instrument. Two obstacles of
 11490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at
 11491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any
 11492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpression on them. Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last
 11493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tKitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter mamma? What do
 11494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou keep winking at me for? What am I to do?”
 11495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Nothing child, nothing. I did not wink at you.” She then sat still
 11497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfive minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she
 11498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuddenly got up, and saying to Kitty, “Come here, my love, I want to
 11499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeak to you,” took her out of the room. Jane instantly gave a look
 11500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her
 11501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tentreaty that _she_ would not give in to it. In a few minutes, Mrs.
 11502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet half-opened the door and called out:
 11503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
 11505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was forced to go.
 11507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We may as well leave them by themselves you know;” said her mother, as
 11509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon as she was in the hall. “Kitty and I are going up stairs to sit in
 11510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy dressing-room.”
 11511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained
 11513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tquietly in the hall, till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned
 11514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinto the drawing-room.
 11515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual. Bingley was every
 11517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter. His
 11518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their
 11519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the
 11520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command
 11521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
 11522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went
 11524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taway, an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs.
 11525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
 11526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter this day, Jane said no more of her indifference. Not a word passed
 11528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbetween the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in
 11529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy
 11530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treturned within the stated time. Seriously, however, she felt tolerably
 11531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpersuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s
 11532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcurrence.
 11533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent
 11535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe morning together, as had been agreed on. The latter was much more
 11536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tagreeable than his companion expected. There was nothing of presumption
 11537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into
 11538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the
 11539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother had ever seen him. Bingley of course returned with him to dinner;
 11540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand in the evening Mrs. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get
 11541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery body away from him and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter
 11542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto write, went into the breakfast room for that purpose soon after tea;
 11543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be
 11544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
 11545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut on returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she
 11547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother
 11548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been too ingenious for her. On opening the door, she perceived her
 11549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in
 11550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tearnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of
 11551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboth, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would
 11552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but _hers_ she
 11553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought was still worse. Not a syllable was uttered by either; and
 11554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as
 11555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and whispering a few
 11556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twords to her sister, ran out of the room.
 11557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give
 11559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure; and instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest
 11560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\temotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
 11561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“‘Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh!
 11563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhy is not everybody as happy?”
 11564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth,
 11566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta delight, which words could but poorly express. Every sentence of
 11567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. But she would not
 11568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tallow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be
 11569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaid for the present.
 11570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must go instantly to my mother;” she cried. “I would not on any
 11572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccount trifle with her affectionate solicitude; or allow her to hear it
 11573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom anyone but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh! Lizzy, to
 11574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear
 11575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily! how shall I bear so much happiness!”
 11576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the
 11578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcard party, and was sitting up stairs with Kitty.
 11579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease
 11581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many
 11582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevious months of suspense and vexation.
 11583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious
 11585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumspection! of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance! the
 11586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiest, wisest, most reasonable end!”
 11587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her
 11589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather had been short and to the purpose.
 11590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
 11592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“With my mother up stairs. She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
 11594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes
 11596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand affection of a sister. Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed
 11597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther delight in the prospect of their relationship. They shook hands with
 11598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen
 11599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections;
 11600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his
 11601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for
 11602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbasis the excellent understanding, and super-excellent disposition of
 11603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and
 11604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself.
 11605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIt was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of
 11607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet’s mind gave a glow of such sweet animation to her face, as
 11608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade her look handsomer than ever. Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped
 11609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther turn was coming soon. Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent or
 11610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspeak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings,
 11611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough she talked to Bingley of nothing else for half an hour; and when
 11612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed
 11613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow really happy he was.
 11614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNot a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their
 11616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he
 11617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturned to his daughter, and said:
 11618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.”
 11620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his
 11622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoodness.
 11623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are a good girl;” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in
 11625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your
 11626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdoing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are
 11627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so
 11628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teasy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will
 11629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways exceed your income.”
 11630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be
 11632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunpardonable in me.”
 11633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you
 11635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely
 11636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh! my dear, dear Jane, I am so
 11637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappy! I am sure I shan’t get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it
 11638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not
 11639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when
 11640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was
 11641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat you should come together. Oh! he is the handsomest young man that
 11642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever was seen!”
 11643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, Lydia, were all forgotten. Jane was beyond competition her
 11645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfavourite child. At that moment, she cared for no other. Her younger
 11646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness
 11647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich she might in future be able to dispense.
 11648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty
 11650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbegged very hard for a few balls there every winter.
 11651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn;
 11653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after
 11654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough
 11655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdetested, had given him an invitation to dinner which he thought himself
 11656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobliged to accept.
 11657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for
 11659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhile he was present, Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else;
 11660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut she found herself considerably useful to both of them in those hours
 11661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof separation that must sometimes occur. In the absence of Jane, he
 11662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways attached himself to Elizabeth, for the pleasure of talking of
 11663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of
 11664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelief.
 11665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he
 11667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not believed
 11668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit possible.”
 11669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for
 11671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit?”
 11672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It must have been his sister’s doing. They were certainly no friends to
 11674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have
 11675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see,
 11676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will
 11677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlearn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again; though we
 11678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan never be what we once were to each other.”
 11679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever
 11681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again
 11682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
 11683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November,
 11685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being
 11686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindifferent would have prevented his coming down again!”
 11687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“He made a little mistake to be sure; but it is to the credit of his
 11689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmodesty.”
 11690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and
 11692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe little value he put on his own good qualities. Elizabeth was pleased
 11693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for,
 11694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she
 11695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
 11696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried
 11698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane. “Oh! Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed
 11699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabove them all! If I could but see _you_ as happy! If there _were_ but
 11700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch another man for you!”
 11701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as
 11703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your
 11704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very
 11705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgood luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”
 11706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a
 11708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsecret. Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Phillips,
 11709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her
 11710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tneighbours in Meryton.
 11711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the
 11713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworld, though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away,
 11714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
 11715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 56
 11719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tOne morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been
 11722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the
 11723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window, by the
 11724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up
 11725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors, and besides, the
 11726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tequipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses
 11727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who
 11728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that
 11729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsomebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid
 11730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the
 11731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshrubbery. They both set off, and the conjectures of the remaining three
 11732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown
 11733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topen and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
 11734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey were of course all intending to be surprised; but their
 11736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tastonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs.
 11737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even
 11738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinferior to what Elizabeth felt.
 11739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no
 11741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the
 11742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thead, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her
 11743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tname to her mother on her ladyship’s entrance, though no request of
 11744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduction had been made.
 11745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such
 11747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thigh importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting
 11748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor a moment in silence, she said very stiffly to Elizabeth,
 11749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your
 11751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmother.”
 11752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
 11754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And _that_ I suppose is one of your sisters.”
 11756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to Lady Catherine.
 11758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married,
 11759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand my eldest is somewhere about the grounds, walking with a young man
 11760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twho, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
 11761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine after a short
 11763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsilence.
 11764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my lady, I dare say; but I
 11766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassure you it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
 11767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This must be a most inconvenient sitting room for the evening, in
 11769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsummer; the windows are full west.”
 11770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner, and then
 11772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadded:
 11773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“May I take the liberty of asking your ladyship whether you left Mr. and
 11775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Collins well.”
 11776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.”
 11778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from
 11780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling. But no
 11781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tletter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.
 11782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her ladyship to take some
 11784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trefreshment; but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely,
 11785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeclined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,
 11786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness
 11788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you
 11789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill favour me with your company.”
 11790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her ladyship about the
 11792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifferent walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
 11793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth obeyed, and running into her own room for her parasol,
 11795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the
 11796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and
 11797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent
 11798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking rooms, walked on.
 11799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her
 11801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twaiting-woman was in it. They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk
 11802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for
 11803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and
 11804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable.
 11805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in
 11807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther face.
 11808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following
 11810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmanner:--
 11811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my
 11813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjourney hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I
 11814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcome.”
 11815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
 11817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed, you are mistaken, Madam. I have not been at all able to account
 11819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the honour of seeing you here.”
 11820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bennet,” replied her ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to
 11822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow, that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere _you_ may
 11823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchoose to be, you shall not find _me_ so. My character has ever been
 11824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcelebrated for its sincerity and frankness, and in a cause of such
 11825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most
 11826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talarming nature reached me two days ago. I was told that not only your
 11827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that
 11828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, that Miss Elizabeth Bennet, would, in all likelihood, be soon
