 11829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafterwards united to my nephew, my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I
 11830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_know_ it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him
 11831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved
 11832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to
 11833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou.”
 11834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring
 11836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming
 11837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso far. What could your ladyship propose by it?”
 11838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”
 11840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth
 11842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it; if, indeed, such a report
 11843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis in existence.”
 11844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If! Do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been
 11846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindustriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a
 11847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treport is spread abroad?”
 11848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I never heard that it was.”
 11850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And can you likewise declare, that there is no foundation for it?”
 11852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. You may
 11854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\task questions which I shall not choose to answer.”
 11855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has
 11857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”
 11858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”
 11860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his
 11862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treason. But your arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation,
 11863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You
 11864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmay have drawn him in.”
 11865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.”
 11867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such
 11869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlanguage as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world,
 11870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.”
 11871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But you are not entitled to know mine; nor will such behaviour as this,
 11873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tever induce me to be explicit.”
 11874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the
 11876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpresumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is
 11877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengaged to my daughter. Now what have you to say?”
 11878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Only this; that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will
 11880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmake an offer to me.”
 11881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied:
 11883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy,
 11885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthey have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of
 11886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_his_ mother, as well as of hers. While in their cradles, we planned
 11887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe union: and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would
 11888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe accomplished in their marriage, to be prevented by a young woman of
 11889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to
 11890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe family! Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends? To his
 11891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of
 11892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpropriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say that from his earliest
 11893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thours he was destined for his cousin?”
 11894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes, and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is
 11896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not
 11897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to
 11898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry Miss de Bourgh. You both did as much as you could in planning the
 11899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither
 11900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make
 11901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanother choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?”
 11902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Because honour, decorum, prudence, nay, interest, forbid it. Yes,
 11904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or
 11905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will
 11906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe censured, slighted, and despised, by everyone connected with him.
 11907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYour alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned
 11908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby any of us.”
 11909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth. “But the wife of Mr.
 11911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily
 11912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause
 11913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto repine.”
 11914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude
 11916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that
 11917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscore? Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came
 11918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\there with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will
 11919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI be dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person’s
 11920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhims. I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.”
 11921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_That_ will make your ladyship’s situation at present more pitiable;
 11923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut it will have no effect on me.”
 11924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I will not be interrupted. Hear me in silence. My daughter and my
 11926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnephew are formed for each other. They are descended, on the maternal
 11927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tside, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable,
 11928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thonourable, and ancient--though untitled--families. Their fortune on
 11929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tboth sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of
 11930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?
 11931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections,
 11932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor fortune. Is this to be endured! But it must not, shall not be. If you
 11933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere in
 11934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich you have been brought up.”
 11935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that
 11937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s daughter; so far we are
 11938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tequal.”
 11939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“True. You _are_ a gentleman’s daughter. But who was your mother?
 11941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWho are your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their
 11942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcondition.”
 11943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does
 11945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.”
 11946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Tell me once for all, are you engaged to him?”
 11948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThough Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady
 11950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine, have answered this question, she could not but say, after a
 11951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment’s deliberation:
 11952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am not.”
 11954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine seemed pleased.
 11956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And will you promise me, never to enter into such an engagement?”
 11958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I will make no promise of the kind.”
 11960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Miss Bennet I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more
 11962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that
 11963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI will ever recede. I shall not go away till you have given me the
 11964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tassurance I require.”
 11965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And I certainly _never_ shall give it. I am not to be intimidated into
 11967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything so wholly unreasonable. Your ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry
 11968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make their
 11969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage at all more probable? Supposing him to be attached to me, would
 11970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy refusing to accept his hand make him wish to bestow it on his cousin?
 11971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAllow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have
 11972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsupported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the
 11973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplication was ill-judged. You have widely mistaken my character, if
 11974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these. How far your
 11975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnephew might approve of your interference in his affairs, I cannot tell;
 11976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut you have certainly no right to concern yourself in mine. I must beg,
 11977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttherefore, to be importuned no farther on the subject.”
 11978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not so hasty, if you please. I have by no means done. To all the
 11980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobjections I have already urged, I have still another to add. I am
 11981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister’s infamous
 11982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telopement. I know it all; that the young man’s marrying her was a
 11983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpatched-up business, at the expence of your father and uncles. And is
 11984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a girl to be my nephew’s sister? Is her husband, is the son of his
 11985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlate father’s steward, to be his brother? Heaven and earth!--of what are
 11986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou thinking? Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?”
 11987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You can now have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered.
 11989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have insulted me in every possible method. I must beg to return to
 11990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe house.”
 11991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnd she rose as she spoke. Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned
 11993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tback. Her ladyship was highly incensed.
 11994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You have no regard, then, for the honour and credit of my nephew!
 11996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tUnfeeling, selfish girl! Do you not consider that a connection with you
 11997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmust disgrace him in the eyes of everybody?”
 11998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 11999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say. You know my sentiments.”
 12000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are then resolved to have him?”
 12002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have said no such thing. I am only resolved to act in that manner,
 12004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without
 12005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treference to _you_, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me.”
 12006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It is well. You refuse, then, to oblige me. You refuse to obey the
 12008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclaims of duty, honour, and gratitude. You are determined to ruin him in
 12009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world.”
 12010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “have any
 12012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossible claim on me, in the present instance. No principle of either
 12013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be violated by my marriage with Mr. Darcy. And with regard to the
 12014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former
 12015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_were_ excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment’s
 12016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconcern--and the world in general would have too much sense to join in
 12017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe scorn.”
 12018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And this is your real opinion! This is your final resolve! Very well.
 12020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI shall now know how to act. Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that your
 12021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tambition will ever be gratified. I came to try you. I hoped to find you
 12022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonable; but, depend upon it, I will carry my point.”
 12023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn this manner Lady Catherine talked on, till they were at the door of
 12025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe carriage, when, turning hastily round, she added, “I take no leave
 12026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof you, Miss Bennet. I send no compliments to your mother. You deserve
 12027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tno such attention. I am most seriously displeased.”
 12028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her
 12030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself. She
 12031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\theard the carriage drive away as she proceeded up stairs. Her mother
 12032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpatiently met her at the door of the dressing-room, to ask why Lady
 12033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine would not come in again and rest herself.
 12034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She did not choose it,” said her daughter, “she would go.”
 12036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“She is a very fine-looking woman! and her calling here was prodigiously
 12038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcivil! for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were
 12039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twell. She is on her road somewhere, I dare say, and so, passing through
 12040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMeryton, thought she might as well call on you. I suppose she had
 12041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?”
 12042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was forced to give into a little falsehood here; for to
 12044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledge the substance of their conversation was impossible.
 12045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 57
 12049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw
 12052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth into, could not be easily overcome; nor could she, for many
 12053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thours, learn to think of it less than incessantly. Lady Catherine, it
 12054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tappeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings,
 12055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr.
 12056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy. It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report
 12057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine;
 12058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttill she recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley,
 12059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand _her_ being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the
 12060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply
 12061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe idea. She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her
 12062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsister must bring them more frequently together. And her neighbours
 12063	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Lucas Lodge, therefore (for through their communication with the
 12064	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine), had
 12065	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly set that down as almost certain and immediate, which she had looked
 12066	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforward to as possible at some future time.
 12067	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12068	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn revolving Lady Catherine’s expressions, however, she could not help
 12069	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting
 12070	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin this interference. From what she had said of her resolution to
 12071	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevent their marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate
 12072	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan application to her nephew; and how _he_ might take a similar
 12073	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trepresentation of the evils attached to a connection with her, she dared
 12074	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot pronounce. She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his
 12075	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose
 12076	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat he thought much higher of her ladyship than _she_ could do; and it
 12077	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas certain that, in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_,
 12078	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would
 12079	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taddress him on his weakest side. With his notions of dignity, he would
 12080	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprobably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak
 12081	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
 12082	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12083	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIf he had been wavering before as to what he should do, which had often
 12084	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseemed likely, the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might
 12085	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsettle every doubt, and determine him at once to be as happy as dignity
 12086	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunblemished could make him. In that case he would return no more. Lady
 12087	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine might see him in her way through town; and his engagement to
 12088	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBingley of coming again to Netherfield must give way.
 12089	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12090	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise should come to his
 12091	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend within a few days,” she added, “I shall know how to understand
 12092	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit. I shall then give over every expectation, every wish of his
 12093	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconstancy. If he is satisfied with only regretting me, when he might
 12094	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave obtained my affections and hand, I shall soon cease to regret him
 12095	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat all.”
 12096	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12097	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
 12098	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12099	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had
 12100	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen, was very great; but they obligingly satisfied it, with the same
 12101	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tkind of supposition which had appeased Mrs. Bennet’s curiosity; and
 12102	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject.
 12103	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12104	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe next morning, as she was going downstairs, she was met by her
 12105	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfather, who came out of his library with a letter in his hand.
 12106	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12107	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy,” said he, “I was going to look for you; come into my room.”
 12108	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12109	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe followed him thither; and her curiosity to know what he had to
 12110	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell her was heightened by the supposition of its being in some manner
 12111	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconnected with the letter he held. It suddenly struck her that it
 12112	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight be from Lady Catherine; and she anticipated with dismay all the
 12113	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsequent explanations.
 12114	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12115	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe followed her father to the fire place, and they both sat down. He
 12116	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen said,
 12117	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12118	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me
 12119	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texceedingly. As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its
 12120	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontents. I did not know before, that I had two daughters on the brink
 12121	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof matrimony. Let me congratulate you on a very important conquest.”
 12122	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12123	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe colour now rushed into Elizabeth’s cheeks in the instantaneous
 12124	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconviction of its being a letter from the nephew, instead of the aunt;
 12125	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand she was undetermined whether most to be pleased that he explained
 12126	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself at all, or offended that his letter was not rather addressed to
 12127	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself; when her father continued:
 12128	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12129	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You look conscious. Young ladies have great penetration in such matters
 12130	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas these; but I think I may defy even _your_ sagacity, to discover the
 12131	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tname of your admirer. This letter is from Mr. Collins.”
 12132	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12133	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“From Mr. Collins! and what can _he_ have to say?”
 12134	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12135	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Something very much to the purpose of course. He begins with
 12136	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcongratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of
 12137	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping
 12138	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLucases. I shall not sport with your impatience, by reading what he says
 12139	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton that point. What relates to yourself, is as follows: ‘Having thus
 12140	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toffered you the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on

 12142	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof which we have been advertised by the same authority. Your daughter
 12143	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after
 12144	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther elder sister has resigned it, and the chosen partner of her fate may
 12145	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in
 12146	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis land.’
 12147	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12148	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Can you possibly guess, Lizzy, who is meant by this? ‘This young
 12149	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with every thing the heart of
 12150	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmortal can most desire,--splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive
 12151	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpatronage. Yet in spite of all these temptations, let me warn my cousin
 12152	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur by a precipitate
 12153	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tclosure with this gentleman’s proposals, which, of course, you will be
 12154	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinclined to take immediate advantage of.’
 12155	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12156	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Have you any idea, Lizzy, who this gentleman is? But now it comes out:
 12157	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12158	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“‘My motive for cautioning you is as follows. We have reason to imagine
 12159	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look on the match with
 12160	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta friendly eye.’
 12161	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12162	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“_Mr. Darcy_, you see, is the man! Now, Lizzy, I think I _have_
 12163	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsurprised you. Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man within
 12164	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie
 12165	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore effectually to what they related? Mr. Darcy, who never looks at any
 12166	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twoman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at you in his
 12167	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlife! It is admirable!”
 12168	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12169	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth tried to join in her father’s pleasantry, but could only force
 12170	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone most reluctant smile. Never had his wit been directed in a manner so
 12171	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlittle agreeable to her.
 12172	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12173	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Are you not diverted?”
 12174	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12175	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! yes. Pray read on.”
 12176	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12177	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“‘After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her ladyship last
 12178	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnight, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she
 12179	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that on the score of some
 12180	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfamily objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her
 12181	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsent to what she termed so disgraceful a match. I thought it my duty
 12182	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and
 12183	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run
 12184	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.’ Mr.
 12185	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollins moreover adds, ‘I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia’s sad
 12186	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbusiness has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their
 12187	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tliving together before the marriage took place should be so generally
 12188	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknown. I must not, however, neglect the duties of my station, or refrain
 12189	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom declaring my amazement at hearing that you received the young
 12190	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcouple into your house as soon as they were married. It was an
 12191	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tencouragement of vice; and had I been the rector of Longbourn, I should
 12192	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery strenuously have opposed it. You ought certainly to forgive them,
 12193	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas a Christian, but never to admit them in your sight, or allow their
 12194	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnames to be mentioned in your hearing.’ That is his notion of Christian
 12195	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforgiveness! The rest of his letter is only about his dear Charlotte’s
 12196	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsituation, and his expectation of a young olive-branch. But, Lizzy, you
 12197	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlook as if you did not enjoy it. You are not going to be _missish_,
 12198	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI hope, and pretend to be affronted at an idle report. For what do we
 12199	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlive, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our
 12200	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tturn?”
 12201	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12202	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh!” cried Elizabeth, “I am excessively diverted. But it is so
 12203	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstrange!”
 12204	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12205	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yes--_that_ is what makes it amusing. Had they fixed on any other man
 12206	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit would have been nothing; but _his_ perfect indifference, and _your_
 12207	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpointed dislike, make it so delightfully absurd! Much as I abominate
 12208	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twriting, I would not give up Mr. Collins’s correspondence for any
 12209	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsideration. Nay, when I read a letter of his, I cannot help giving
 12210	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim the preference even over Wickham, much as I value the impudence and
 12211	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thypocrisy of my son-in-law. And pray, Lizzy, what said Lady Catherine
 12212	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout this report? Did she call to refuse her consent?”
 12213	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12214	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo this question his daughter replied only with a laugh; and as it had
 12215	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen asked without the least suspicion, she was not distressed by
 12216	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this repeating it. Elizabeth had never been more at a loss to make her
 12217	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings appear what they were not. It was necessary to laugh, when she
 12218	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould rather have cried. Her father had most cruelly mortified her, by
 12219	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat he said of Mr. Darcy’s indifference, and she could do nothing but
 12220	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twonder at such a want of penetration, or fear that perhaps, instead of
 12221	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this seeing too little, she might have fancied too much.
 12222	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12223	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12224	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12225	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 58
 12226	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12227	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12228	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tInstead of receiving any such letter of excuse from his friend, as
 12229	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth half expected Mr. Bingley to do, he was able to bring Darcy
 12230	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twith him to Longbourn before many days had passed after Lady Catherine’s
 12231	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisit. The gentlemen arrived early; and, before Mrs. Bennet had time
 12232	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto tell him of their having seen his aunt, of which her daughter sat
 12233	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin momentary dread, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed
 12234	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir all walking out. It was agreed to. Mrs. Bennet was not in the
 12235	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thabit of walking; Mary could never spare time; but the remaining five
 12236	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tset off together. Bingley and Jane, however, soon allowed the others
 12237	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto outstrip them. They lagged behind, while Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy
 12238	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere to entertain each other. Very little was said by either; Kitty
 12239	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas too much afraid of him to talk; Elizabeth was secretly forming a
 12240	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdesperate resolution; and perhaps he might be doing the same.
 12241	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12242	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey walked towards the Lucases, because Kitty wished to call upon
 12243	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMaria; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern,
 12244	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhen Kitty left them she went boldly on with him alone. Now was the
 12245	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmoment for her resolution to be executed, and, while her courage was
 12246	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thigh, she immediately said:
 12247	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12248	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature; and, for the sake of giving
 12249	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trelief to my own feelings, care not how much I may be wounding yours. I
 12250	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcan no longer help thanking you for your unexampled kindness to my
 12251	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpoor sister. Ever since I have known it, I have been most anxious to
 12252	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledge to you how gratefully I feel it. Were it known to the rest
 12253	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my family, I should not have merely my own gratitude to express.”
 12254	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12255	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am sorry, exceedingly sorry,” replied Darcy, in a tone of surprise
 12256	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand emotion, “that you have ever been informed of what may, in a
 12257	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistaken light, have given you uneasiness. I did not think Mrs. Gardiner
 12258	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas so little to be trusted.”
 12259	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12260	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You must not blame my aunt. Lydia’s thoughtlessness first betrayed to
 12261	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme that you had been concerned in the matter; and, of course, I could
 12262	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnot rest till I knew the particulars. Let me thank you again and again,
 12263	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the name of all my family, for that generous compassion which induced
 12264	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou to take so much trouble, and bear so many mortifications, for the
 12265	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsake of discovering them.”
 12266	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12267	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“If you _will_ thank me,” he replied, “let it be for yourself alone.
 12268	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThat the wish of giving happiness to you might add force to the other
 12269	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny. But your
 12270	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_family_ owe me nothing. Much as I respect them, I believe I thought
 12271	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly of _you_.”
 12272	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12273	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word. After a short pause,
 12274	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther companion added, “You are too generous to trifle with me. If your
 12275	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once. _My_
 12276	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffections and wishes are unchanged, but one word from you will silence
 12277	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme on this subject for ever.”
 12278	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12279	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, feeling all the more than common awkwardness and anxiety of
 12280	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this situation, now forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not
 12281	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvery fluently, gave him to understand that her sentiments had undergone
 12282	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso material a change, since the period to which he alluded, as to make
 12283	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther receive with gratitude and pleasure his present assurances. The
 12284	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappiness which this reply produced, was such as he had probably never
 12285	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfelt before; and he expressed himself on the occasion as sensibly and as
 12286	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twarmly as a man violently in love can be supposed to do. Had Elizabeth
 12287	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeen able to encounter his eye, she might have seen how well the
 12288	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texpression of heartfelt delight, diffused over his face, became him;
 12289	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut, though she could not look, she could listen, and he told her of
 12290	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeelings, which, in proving of what importance she was to him, made his
 12291	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffection every moment more valuable.
 12292	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12293	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThey walked on, without knowing in what direction. There was too much to
 12294	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe thought, and felt, and said, for attention to any other objects. She
 12295	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon learnt that they were indebted for their present good understanding
 12296	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto the efforts of his aunt, who did call on him in her return through
 12297	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLondon, and there relate her journey to Longbourn, its motive, and the
 12298	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubstance of her conversation with Elizabeth; dwelling emphatically on
 12299	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery expression of the latter which, in her ladyship’s apprehension,
 12300	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpeculiarly denoted her perverseness and assurance; in the belief that
 12301	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch a relation must assist her endeavours to obtain that promise
 12302	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom her nephew which she had refused to give. But, unluckily for her
 12303	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tladyship, its effect had been exactly contrariwise.
 12304	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12305	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It taught me to hope,” said he, “as I had scarcely ever allowed myself
 12306	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto hope before. I knew enough of your disposition to be certain that,
 12307	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad you been absolutely, irrevocably decided against me, you would have
 12308	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledged it to Lady Catherine, frankly and openly.”
 12309	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12310	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth coloured and laughed as she replied, “Yes, you know enough
 12311	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my frankness to believe me capable of _that_. After abusing you so
 12312	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabominably to your face, I could have no scruple in abusing you to all
 12313	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour relations.”
 12314	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12315	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What did you say of me, that I did not deserve? For, though your
 12316	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccusations were ill-founded, formed on mistaken premises, my
 12317	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbehaviour to you at the time had merited the severest reproof. It was
 12318	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunpardonable. I cannot think of it without abhorrence.”
 12319	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12320	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that
 12321	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevening,” said Elizabeth. “The conduct of neither, if strictly examined,
 12322	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twill be irreproachable; but since then, we have both, I hope, improved
 12323	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin civility.”
 12324	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12325	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot be so easily reconciled to myself. The recollection of what I
 12326	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthen said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of
 12327	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly painful to me. Your
 12328	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treproof, so well applied, I shall never forget: ‘had you behaved in a
 12329	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmore gentlemanlike manner.’ Those were your words. You know not, you can
 12330	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tscarcely conceive, how they have tortured me;--though it was some time,
 12331	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI confess, before I was reasonable enough to allow their justice.”
 12332	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12333	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an
 12334	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\timpression. I had not the smallest idea of their being ever felt in such
 12335	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta way.”
 12336	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12337	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I can easily believe it. You thought me then devoid of every proper
 12338	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfeeling, I am sure you did. The turn of your countenance I shall never
 12339	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforget, as you said that I could not have addressed you in any possible
 12340	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway that would induce you to accept me.”
 12341	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12342	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh! do not repeat what I then said. These recollections will not do at
 12343	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall. I assure you that I have long been most heartily ashamed of it.”
 12344	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12345	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy mentioned his letter. “Did it,” said he, “did it soon make you
 12346	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink better of me? Did you, on reading it, give any credit to its
 12347	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontents?”
 12348	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12349	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe explained what its effect on her had been, and how gradually all her
 12350	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer prejudices had been removed.
 12351	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12352	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I knew,” said he, “that what I wrote must give you pain, but it was
 12353	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnecessary. I hope you have destroyed the letter. There was one part
 12354	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tespecially, the opening of it, which I should dread your having the
 12355	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpower of reading again. I can remember some expressions which might
 12356	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tjustly make you hate me.”
 12357	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12358	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The letter shall certainly be burnt, if you believe it essential to the
 12359	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpreservation of my regard; but, though we have both reason to think my
 12360	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\topinions not entirely unalterable, they are not, I hope, quite so easily
 12361	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tchanged as that implies.”
 12362	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12363	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“When I wrote that letter,” replied Darcy, “I believed myself perfectly
 12364	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalm and cool, but I am since convinced that it was written in a
 12365	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdreadful bitterness of spirit.”
 12366	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12367	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“The letter, perhaps, began in bitterness, but it did not end so. The
 12368	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadieu is charity itself. But think no more of the letter. The feelings
 12369	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof the person who wrote, and the person who received it, are now
 12370	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso widely different from what they were then, that every unpleasant
 12371	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircumstance attending it ought to be forgotten. You must learn some
 12372	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof my philosophy. Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you
 12373	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasure.”
 12374	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12375	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot give you credit for any philosophy of the kind. Your
 12376	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tretrospections must be so totally void of reproach, that the contentment
 12377	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tarising from them is not of philosophy, but, what is much better, of
 12378	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinnocence. But with me, it is not so. Painful recollections will intrude
 12379	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich cannot, which ought not, to be repelled. I have been a selfish
 12380	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing all my life, in practice, though not in principle. As a child I
 12381	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temper. I
 12382	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas given good principles, but left to follow them in pride and conceit.
 12383	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tUnfortunately an only son (for many years an only child), I was spoilt
 12384	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby my parents, who, though good themselves (my father, particularly, all
 12385	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat was benevolent and amiable), allowed, encouraged, almost taught
 12386	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme to be selfish and overbearing; to care for none beyond my own family
 12387	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcircle; to think meanly of all the rest of the world; to wish at least
 12388	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto think meanly of their sense and worth compared with my own. Such I
 12389	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas, from eight to eight and twenty; and such I might still have been
 12390	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut for you, dearest, loveliest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you! You
 12391	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttaught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous. By you,
 12392	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI was properly humbled. I came to you without a doubt of my reception.
 12393	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYou showed me how insufficient were all my pretensions to please a woman
 12394	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tworthy of being pleased.”
 12395	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12396	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Had you then persuaded yourself that I should?”
 12397	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12398	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Indeed I had. What will you think of my vanity? I believed you to be
 12399	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twishing, expecting my addresses.”
 12400	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12401	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My manners must have been in fault, but not intentionally, I assure
 12402	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou. I never meant to deceive you, but my spirits might often lead me
 12403	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twrong. How you must have hated me after _that_ evening?”
 12404	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12405	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Hate you! I was angry perhaps at first, but my anger soon began to take
 12406	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta proper direction.”
 12407	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12408	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am almost afraid of asking what you thought of me, when we met at
 12409	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley. You blamed me for coming?”
 12410	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12411	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“No indeed; I felt nothing but surprise.”
 12412	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12413	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Your surprise could not be greater than _mine_ in being noticed by you.
 12414	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMy conscience told me that I deserved no extraordinary politeness, and I
 12415	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfess that I did not expect to receive _more_ than my due.”
 12416	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12417	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My object then,” replied Darcy, “was to show you, by every civility in
 12418	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy power, that I was not so mean as to resent the past; and I hoped to
 12419	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tobtain your forgiveness, to lessen your ill opinion, by letting you
 12420	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsee that your reproofs had been attended to. How soon any other wishes
 12421	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduced themselves I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an
 12422	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thour after I had seen you.”
 12423	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12424	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe then told her of Georgiana’s delight in her acquaintance, and of her
 12425	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisappointment at its sudden interruption; which naturally leading to
 12426	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe cause of that interruption, she soon learnt that his resolution of
 12427	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollowing her from Derbyshire in quest of her sister had been formed
 12428	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore he quitted the inn, and that his gravity and thoughtfulness
 12429	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must
 12430	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomprehend.
 12431	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12432	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tShe expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to
 12433	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teach, to be dwelt on farther.
 12434	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12435	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAfter walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know
 12436	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that
 12437	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was time to be at home.
 12438	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12439	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What could become of Mr. Bingley and Jane!” was a wonder which
 12440	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tintroduced the discussion of their affairs. Darcy was delighted with
 12441	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of
 12442	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit.
 12443	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12444	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must ask whether you were surprised?” said Elizabeth.
 12445	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12446	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Not at all. When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen.”
 12447	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12448	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“That is to say, you had given your permission. I guessed as much.” And
 12449	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthough he exclaimed at the term, she found that it had been pretty much
 12450	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe case.
 12451	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12452	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“On the evening before my going to London,” said he, “I made a
 12453	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconfession to him, which I believe I ought to have made long ago. I
 12454	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttold him of all that had occurred to make my former interference in his
 12455	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffairs absurd and impertinent. His surprise was great. He had never had
 12456	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe slightest suspicion. I told him, moreover, that I believed myself
 12457	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmistaken in supposing, as I had done, that your sister was indifferent
 12458	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto him; and as I could easily perceive that his attachment to her was
 12459	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunabated, I felt no doubt of their happiness together.”
 12460	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12461	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could not help smiling at his easy manner of directing his
 12462	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend.
 12463	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12464	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Did you speak from your own observation,” said she, “when you told him
 12465	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat my sister loved him, or merely from my information last spring?”
 12466	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12467	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“From the former. I had narrowly observed her during the two visits
 12468	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich I had lately made here; and I was convinced of her affection.”
 12469	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12470	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And your assurance of it, I suppose, carried immediate conviction to
 12471	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim.”
 12472	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12473	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It did. Bingley is most unaffectedly modest. His diffidence had
 12474	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tprevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but
 12475	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this reliance on mine made every thing easy. I was obliged to confess
 12476	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him. I could not
 12477	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tallow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months
 12478	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlast winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him. He was
 12479	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tangry. But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained
 12480	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin any doubt of your sister’s sentiments. He has heartily forgiven me
 12481	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnow.”
 12482	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12483	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth longed to observe that Mr. Bingley had been a most delightful
 12484	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfriend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked
 12485	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself. She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laughed at,
 12486	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand it was rather too early to begin. In anticipating the happiness
 12487	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he
 12488	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcontinued the conversation till they reached the house. In the hall they
 12489	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tparted.
 12490	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12491	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12492	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12493	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 59
 12494	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12495	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12496	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question
 12497	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered their room,
 12498	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand from all the others when they sat down to table. She had only to
 12499	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay in reply, that they had wandered about, till she was beyond her own
 12500	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknowledge. She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor anything
 12501	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\telse, awakened a suspicion of the truth.
 12502	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12503	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe evening passed quietly, unmarked by anything extraordinary. The
 12504	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacknowledged lovers talked and laughed, the unacknowledged were silent.
 12505	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth;
 12506	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather _knew_ that she was happy
 12507	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthan _felt_ herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment,
 12508	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthere were other evils before her. She anticipated what would be felt
 12509	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the family when her situation became known; she was aware that no
 12510	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tone liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a
 12511	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.
 12512	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12513	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAt night she opened her heart to Jane. Though suspicion was very far
 12514	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Miss Bennet’s general habits, she was absolutely incredulous here.
 12515	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12516	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You are joking, Lizzy. This cannot be!--engaged to Mr. Darcy! No, no,
 12517	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou shall not deceive me. I know it to be impossible.”
 12518	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12519	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is a wretched beginning indeed! My sole dependence was on you; and
 12520	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not. Yet, indeed, I am
 12521	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin earnest. I speak nothing but the truth. He still loves me, and we are
 12522	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tengaged.”
 12523	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12524	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane looked at her doubtingly. “Oh, Lizzy! it cannot be. I know how much
 12525	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou dislike him.”
 12526	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12527	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You know nothing of the matter. _That_ is all to be forgot. Perhaps I
 12528	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid not always love him so well as I do now. But in such cases as
 12529	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthese, a good memory is unpardonable. This is the last time I shall ever
 12530	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremember it myself.”
 12531	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12532	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bennet still looked all amazement. Elizabeth again, and more
 12533	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tseriously assured her of its truth.
 12534	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12535	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good Heaven! can it be really so! Yet now I must believe you,” cried
 12536	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane. “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would--I do congratulate you--but are you
 12537	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcertain? forgive the question--are you quite certain that you can be
 12538	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thappy with him?”
 12539	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12540	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“There can be no doubt of that. It is settled between us already, that
 12541	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twe are to be the happiest couple in the world. But are you pleased,
 12542	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tJane? Shall you like to have such a brother?”
 12543	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12544	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Very, very much. Nothing could give either Bingley or myself more
 12545	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdelight. But we considered it, we talked of it as impossible. And do you
 12546	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treally love him quite well enough? Oh, Lizzy! do anything rather than
 12547	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarry without affection. Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought
 12548	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto do?”
 12549	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12550	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Oh, yes! You will only think I feel _more_ than I ought to do, when I
 12551	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell you all.”
 12552	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12553	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“What do you mean?”
 12554	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12555	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Why, I must confess that I love him better than I do Bingley. I am
 12556	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tafraid you will be angry.”
 12557	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12558	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dearest sister, now _be_ serious. I want to talk very seriously. Let
 12559	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tme know every thing that I am to know, without delay. Will you tell me
 12560	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thow long you have loved him?”
 12561	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12562	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began.
 12563	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds
 12564	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat Pemberley.”
 12565	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12566	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAnother entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the
 12567	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdesired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances
 12568	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof attachment. When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing
 12569	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfurther to wish.
 12570	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12571	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself.
 12572	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI always had a value for him. Were it for nothing but his love of you,
 12573	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley’s friend and your
 12574	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thusband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me. But
 12575	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me. How little did you
 12576	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton! I owe all that I know
 12577	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof it to another, not to you.”
 12578	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12579	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy. She had been unwilling
 12580	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made
 12581	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther equally avoid the name of his friend. But now she would no longer
 12582	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconceal from her his share in Lydia’s marriage. All was acknowledged,
 12583	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand half the night spent in conversation.
 12584	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12585	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
 12586	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12587	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next
 12588	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmorning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with
 12589	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tour dear Bingley! What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always
 12590	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcoming here? I had no notion but he would go a-shooting, or something or
 12591	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother, and not disturb us with his company. What shall we do with him?
 12592	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s
 12593	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway.”
 12594	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12595	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet
 12596	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an
 12597	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tepithet.
 12598	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12599	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and
 12600	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information;
 12601	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mrs. Bennet, have you no more lanes
 12602	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”
 12603	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12604	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said Mrs. Bennet, “to walk
 12605	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Oakham Mount this morning. It is a nice long walk, and Mr. Darcy has
 12606	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tnever seen the view.”
 12607	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12608	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am
 12609	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure it will be too much for Kitty. Won’t it, Kitty?” Kitty owned that
 12610	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe had rather stay at home. Darcy professed a great curiosity to see
 12611	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented. As she went
 12612	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying:
 12613	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12614	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that
 12615	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisagreeable man all to yourself. But I hope you will not mind it: it is
 12616	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking
 12617	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto him, except just now and then. So, do not put yourself to
 12618	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinconvenience.”
 12619	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12620	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDuring their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet’s consent should be
 12621	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tasked in the course of the evening. Elizabeth reserved to herself the
 12622	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tapplication for her mother’s. She could not determine how her mother
 12623	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur
 12624	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man. But whether she
 12625	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twere violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it
 12626	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit
 12627	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto her sense; and she could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear
 12628	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her
 12629	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdisapprobation.
 12630	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12631	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t                          * * * * *
 12632	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12633	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIn the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw
 12634	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was
 12635	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textreme. She did not fear her father’s opposition, but he was going to
 12636	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe made unhappy; and that it should be through her means--that _she_,
 12637	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be
 12638	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfilling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her--was a wretched
 12639	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when,
 12640	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlooking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile. In a few minutes
 12641	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while
 12642	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpretending to admire her work said in a whisper, “Go to your father, he
 12643	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twants you in the library.” She was gone directly.
 12644	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12645	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHer father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious.
 12646	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing? Are you out of your senses, to be
 12647	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccepting this man? Have not you always hated him?”
 12648	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12649	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHow earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more
 12650	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonable, her expressions more moderate! It would have spared her from
 12651	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\texplanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give;
 12652	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbut they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion,
 12653	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her attachment to Mr. Darcy.
 12654	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12655	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Or, in other words, you are determined to have him. He is rich, to be
 12656	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane.
 12657	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut will they make you happy?”
 12658	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12659	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my
 12660	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tindifference?”
 12661	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12662	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but
 12663	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthis would be nothing if you really liked him.”
 12664	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12665	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes, “I love him.
 12666	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tIndeed he has no improper pride. He is perfectly amiable. You do not
 12667	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknow what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in
 12668	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuch terms.”
 12669	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12670	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent. He is the kind
 12671	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse anything, which he
 12672	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcondescended to ask. I now give it to _you_, if you are resolved on
 12673	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thaving him. But let me advise you to think better of it. I know
 12674	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour disposition, Lizzy. I know that you could be neither happy nor
 12675	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trespectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband; unless you looked
 12676	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tup to him as a superior. Your lively talents would place you in the
 12677	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreatest danger in an unequal marriage. You could scarcely escape
 12678	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdiscredit and misery. My child, let me not have the grief of seeing
 12679	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_you_ unable to respect your partner in life. You know not what you are
 12680	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tabout.”
 12681	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12682	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and
 12683	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object
 12684	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of
 12685	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection
 12686	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’
 12687	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsuspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did
 12688	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconquer her father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
