 12689	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12690	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to
 12691	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsay. If this be the case, he deserves you. I could not have parted with
 12692	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”
 12693	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12694	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tTo complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy
 12695	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad voluntarily done for Lydia. He heard her with astonishment.
 12696	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12697	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“This is an evening of wonders, indeed! And so, Darcy did every thing;
 12698	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmade up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow’s debts, and got him
 12699	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this commission! So much the better. It will save me a world of trouble
 12700	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand economy. Had it been your uncle’s doing, I must and _would_ have
 12701	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpaid him; but these violent young lovers carry every thing their own
 12702	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tway. I shall offer to pay him to-morrow; he will rant and storm about
 12703	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\this love for you, and there will be an end of the matter.”
 12704	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12705	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHe then recollected her embarrassment a few days before, on his reading
 12706	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Collins’s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her
 12707	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tat last to go--saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come
 12708	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”
 12709	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12710	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after
 12711	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thalf an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join
 12712	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe others with tolerable composure. Every thing was too recent for
 12713	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgaiety, but the evening passed tranquilly away; there was no longer
 12714	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tanything material to be dreaded, and the comfort of ease and familiarity
 12715	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twould come in time.
 12716	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12717	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWhen her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her,
 12718	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand made the important communication. Its effect was most extraordinary;
 12719	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to
 12720	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tutter a syllable. Nor was it under many, many minutes that she could
 12721	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcomprehend what she heard; though not in general backward to credit
 12722	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhat was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a
 12723	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlover to any of them. She began at length to recover, to fidget about in
 12724	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
 12725	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12726	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Good gracious! Lord bless me! only think! dear me! Mr. Darcy! Who would
 12727	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thave thought it! And is it really true? Oh! my sweetest Lizzy! how rich
 12728	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand how great you will be! What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages
 12729	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou will have! Jane’s is nothing to it--nothing at all. I am so
 12730	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleased--so happy. Such a charming man!--so handsome! so tall!--Oh, my
 12731	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdear Lizzy! pray apologise for my having disliked him so much before. I
 12732	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thope he will overlook it. Dear, dear Lizzy. A house in town! Every thing
 12733	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat is charming! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year! Oh,
 12734	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLord! What will become of me. I shall go distracted.”
 12735	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12736	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted: and
 12737	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself,
 12738	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsoon went away. But before she had been three minutes in her own room,
 12739	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther mother followed her.
 12740	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12741	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else! Ten
 12742	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthousand a year, and very likely more! ‘Tis as good as a Lord! And a
 12743	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tspecial licence. You must and shall be married by a special licence. But
 12744	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmy dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of,
 12745	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthat I may have it to-morrow.”
 12746	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12747	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThis was a sad omen of what her mother’s behaviour to the gentleman
 12748	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thimself might be; and Elizabeth found that, though in the certain
 12749	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpossession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations’
 12750	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tconsent, there was still something to be wished for. But the morrow
 12751	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpassed off much better than she expected; for Mrs. Bennet luckily stood
 12752	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin such awe of her intended son-in-law that she ventured not to speak to
 12753	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her
 12754	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdeference for his opinion.
 12755	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12756	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get
 12757	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tacquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising
 12758	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tevery hour in his esteem.
 12759	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12760	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he. “Wickham, perhaps,
 12761	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tis my favourite; but I think I shall like _your_ husband quite as well
 12762	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tas Jane’s.”
 12763	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12764	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12765	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12766	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 60
 12767	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12768	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12769	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr.
 12770	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her. “How could
 12771	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou begin?” said she. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when
 12772	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first
 12773	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tplace?”
 12774	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12775	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which
 12776	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlaid the foundation. It is too long ago. I was in the middle before I
 12777	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknew that I _had_ begun.”
 12778	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12779	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners--my behaviour
 12780	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto _you_ was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke
 12781	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto you without rather wishing to give you pain than not. Now be sincere;
 12782	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdid you admire me for my impertinence?”
 12783	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12784	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“For the liveliness of your mind, I did.”
 12785	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12786	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You may as well call it impertinence at once. It was very little less.
 12787	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious
 12788	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattention. You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking,
 12789	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand looking, and thinking for _your_ approbation alone. I roused, and
 12790	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinterested you, because I was so unlike _them_. Had you not been really
 12791	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamiable, you would have hated me for it; but in spite of the pains you
 12792	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttook to disguise yourself, your feelings were always noble and just; and
 12793	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin your heart, you thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously
 12794	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcourted you. There--I have saved you the trouble of accounting for
 12795	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit; and really, all things considered, I begin to think it perfectly
 12796	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treasonable. To be sure, you knew no actual good of me--but nobody thinks
 12797	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof _that_ when they fall in love.”
 12798	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12799	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane while she was
 12800	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\till at Netherfield?”
 12801	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12802	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Dearest Jane! who could have done less for her? But make a virtue of it
 12803	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tby all means. My good qualities are under your protection, and you are
 12804	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me
 12805	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as may
 12806	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe; and I shall begin directly by asking you what made you so unwilling
 12807	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto come to the point at last. What made you so shy of me, when you first
 12808	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcalled, and afterwards dined here? Why, especially, when you called, did
 12809	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou look as if you did not care about me?”
 12810	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12811	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement.”
 12812	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12813	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“But I was embarrassed.”
 12814	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12815	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And so was I.”
 12816	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12817	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner.”
 12818	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12819	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“A man who had felt less, might.”
 12820	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12821	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that
 12822	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI should be so reasonable as to admit it! But I wonder how long you
 12823	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_would_ have gone on, if you had been left to yourself. I wonder when
 12824	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyou _would_ have spoken, if I had not asked you! My resolution of
 12825	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect.
 12826	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_Too much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort
 12827	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsprings from a breach of promise? for I ought not to have mentioned the
 12828	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject. This will never do.”
 12829	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12830	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady
 12831	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCatherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of
 12832	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tremoving all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to
 12833	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tyour eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour
 12834	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto wait for any opening of yours. My aunt’s intelligence had given me
 12835	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thope, and I was determined at once to know every thing.”
 12836	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12837	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy,
 12838	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to
 12839	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNetherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed?
 12840	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tor had you intended any more serious consequence?”
 12841	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12842	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“My real purpose was to see _you_, and to judge, if I could, whether I
 12843	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmight ever hope to make you love me. My avowed one, or what I avowed to
 12844	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmyself, was to see whether your sister were still partial to Bingley,
 12845	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
 12846	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12847	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to
 12848	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefall her?”
 12849	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12850	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I am more likely to want more time than courage, Elizabeth. But it
 12851	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tought to be done, and if you will give me a sheet of paper, it shall be
 12852	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdone directly.”
 12853	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12854	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you and
 12855	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadmire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. But
 12856	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”
 12857	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12858	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tFrom an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy
 12859	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thad been over-rated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s
 12860	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlong letter; but now, having _that_ to communicate which she knew would
 12861	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and
 12862	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as
 12863	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfollows:
 12864	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12865	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done,
 12866	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor your long, kind, satisfactory, detail of particulars; but to say the
 12867	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttruth, I was too cross to write. You supposed more than really existed.
 12868	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut _now_ suppose as much as you choose; give a loose rein to your
 12869	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfancy, indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the
 12870	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsubject will afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you
 12871	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tcannot greatly err. You must write again very soon, and praise him a
 12872	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgreat deal more than you did in your last. I thank you, again and again,
 12873	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfor not going to the Lakes. How could I be so silly as to wish it! Your
 12874	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tidea of the ponies is delightful. We will go round the Park every day. I
 12875	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tam the happiest creature in the world. Perhaps other people have said so
 12876	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbefore, but not one with such justice. I am happier even than Jane; she
 12877	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tonly smiles, I laugh. Mr. Darcy sends you all the love in the world that
 12878	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the can spare from me. You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas.
 12879	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tYours, etc.”
 12880	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12881	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style; and still
 12882	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdifferent from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in reply
 12883	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto his last.
 12884	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12885	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“DEAR SIR,
 12886	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12887	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will soon
 12888	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe the wife of Mr. Darcy. Console Lady Catherine as well as you can.
 12889	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBut, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew. He has more to give.
 12890	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12891	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yours sincerely, etc.”
 12892	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12893	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother, on his approaching
 12894	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmarriage, were all that was affectionate and insincere. She wrote even
 12895	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her
 12896	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tformer professions of regard. Jane was not deceived, but she was
 12897	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taffected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing
 12898	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
 12899	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12900	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThe joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information,
 12901	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas as sincere as her brother’s in sending it. Four sides of paper were
 12902	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinsufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of
 12903	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbeing loved by her sister.
 12904	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12905	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tBefore any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations
 12906	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the
 12907	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCollinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge. The reason of this
 12908	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsudden removal was soon evident. Lady Catherine had been rendered
 12909	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tso exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that
 12910	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tCharlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till
 12911	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe storm was blown over. At such a moment, the arrival of her friend
 12912	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their
 12913	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she
 12914	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsaw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of
 12915	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther husband. He bore it, however, with admirable calmness. He could even
 12916	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlisten to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away
 12917	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all
 12918	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmeeting frequently at St. James’s, with very decent composure. If he did
 12919	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.
 12920	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12921	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMrs. Phillips’s vulgarity was another, and perhaps a greater, tax on his
 12922	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tforbearance; and though Mrs. Phillips, as well as her sister, stood in
 12923	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttoo much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s good
 12924	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thumour encouraged, yet, whenever she _did_ speak, she must be vulgar.
 12925	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tNor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all
 12926	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlikely to make her more elegant. Elizabeth did all she could to shield
 12927	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep
 12928	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\thim to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse
 12929	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twithout mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising
 12930	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it
 12931	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tadded to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to
 12932	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing
 12933	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at
 12934	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley.
 12935	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12936	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12937	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12938	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tChapter 61
 12939	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12940	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12941	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tHappy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got
 12942	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trid of her two most deserving daughters. With what delighted pride
 12943	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may
 12944	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tbe guessed. I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the
 12945	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\taccomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many
 12946	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible,
 12947	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tamiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though perhaps it
 12948	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity
 12949	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and
 12950	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tinvariably silly.
 12951	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12952	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her
 12953	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrew him oftener from home than anything else could do. He delighted in
 12954	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tgoing to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
 12955	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12956	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth. So near
 12957	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to
 12958	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t_his_ easy temper, or _her_ affectionate heart. The darling wish of his
 12959	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsisters was then gratified; he bought an estate in a neighbouring county
 12960	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source
 12961	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
 12962	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12963	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tKitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with
 12964	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther two elder sisters. In society so superior to what she had generally
 12965	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tknown, her improvement was great. She was not of so ungovernable a
 12966	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttemper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example,
 12967	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less
 12968	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tignorant, and less insipid. From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s
 12969	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsociety she was of course carefully kept, and though Mrs. Wickham
 12970	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of
 12971	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tballs and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
 12972	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12973	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily
 12974	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdrawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet’s being quite
 12975	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tunable to sit alone. Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but
 12976	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tshe could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no
 12977	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlonger mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own,
 12978	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tit was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without
 12979	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tmuch reluctance.
 12980	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12981	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from
 12982	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthe marriage of her sisters. He bore with philosophy the conviction that
 12983	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude
 12984	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand falsehood had before been unknown to her; and in spite of every
 12985	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthing, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on
 12986	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto make his fortune. The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received
 12987	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrom Lydia on her marriage, explained to her that, by his wife at least,
 12988	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tif not by himself, such a hope was cherished. The letter was to this
 12989	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\teffect:
 12990	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12991	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“MY DEAR LIZZY,
 12992	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 12993	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half as well as I do my dear
 12994	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to have you so
 12995	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trich, and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us.
 12996	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tI am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much, and I do not
 12997	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthink we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help.
 12998	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAny place would do, of about three or four hundred a year; but however,
 12999	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdo not speak to Mr. Darcy about it, if you had rather not.
 13000	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13001	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t“Yours, etc.”
 13002	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13003	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tAs it happened that Elizabeth had _much_ rather not, she endeavoured in
 13004	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
 13005	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tSuch relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice
 13006	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tof what might be called economy in her own private expences, she
 13007	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tfrequently sent them. It had always been evident to her that such an
 13008	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tincome as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in
 13009	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to
 13010	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttheir support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or
 13011	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\therself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance
 13012	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttowards discharging their bills. Their manner of living, even when the
 13013	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\trestoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the
 13014	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\textreme. They were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap
 13015	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsituation, and always spending more than they ought. His affection for
 13016	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther soon sunk into indifference; hers lasted a little longer; and
 13017	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to
 13018	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treputation which her marriage had given her.
 13019	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13020	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tThough Darcy could never receive _him_ at Pemberley, yet, for
 13021	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tElizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession. Lydia was
 13022	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\toccasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself
 13023	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently
 13024	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tstaid so long, that even Bingley’s good humour was overcome, and he
 13025	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tproceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.
 13026	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13027	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tMiss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she
 13028	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tthought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she
 13029	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tdropt all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as
 13030	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tattentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility
 13031	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto Elizabeth.
 13032	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13033	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tPemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters
 13034	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twas exactly what Darcy had hoped to see. They were able to love each
 13035	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tother even as well as they intended. Georgiana had the highest opinion
 13036	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with
 13037	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tan astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive, manner of
 13038	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ttalking to her brother. He, who had always inspired in herself a respect
 13039	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\twhich almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open
 13040	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tpleasantry. Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen
 13041	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tin her way. By Elizabeth’s instructions, she began to comprehend that
 13042	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ta woman may take liberties with her husband which a brother will not
 13043	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\talways allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.
 13044	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13045	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tLady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew;
 13046	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character in
 13047	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him
 13048	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tlanguage so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time
 13049	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tall intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion,
 13050	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\the was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation;
 13051	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tand, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her
 13052	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tresentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity
 13053	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tto see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait
 13054	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ton them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had
 13055	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\treceived, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the
 13056	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tvisits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
 13057	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
 13058	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tWith the Gardiners, they were always on the most intimate terms.
 13059	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tDarcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever
 13060	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\tsensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing
 13061	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\ther into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
 13062	PrideandPrejudicebyJaneAusten.txt\t
